256.06 CONFLICTS OF INTEREST.
   (a)   Definitions. As used in this section:
      (1)   "Economic opportunity" means any purchase, sale, lease, contract,
option or other transaction or arrangement, including property or services,
wherein an elected or appointed official may gain an economic benefit.
      (2)   "Elected or appointed official" means any appointed official or
elected officer charged with duties under State law or under these Codified
Ordinances or any other resolution or motion of the Board of Trustees; any
member of a Village board or commission who is appointed by the President of
the Board; any elected official of the Village; the Village Manager; any
department head; or any other staff member authorized to make Village
expenditures.
      (3)   "Legislative matters" means any ordinance, resolution or motion or
other issue or proposal pending before the Board or any committee, subcommittee
or commission thereof.
(1976 Code § 2-76; Ord. 507. Passed 9-26-77; Ord. 592. Passed 6-14-82.)
   (b)   Restricted Activities.
      (1)   No elected or appointed official shall be interested, directly or
indirectly, in any contract, work or business of the Village, or in the sale of
any article, whenever the expense, price or consideration of the contract,
work, business or sale is paid either from the treasury or by any assessment
levied by any statute or ordinance. No elected or appointed official shall be
interested, directly or indirectly, in the purchase of any property which
belongs to the Village, is sold for taxes or assessments or is sold by virtue
of legal process at a suit of the Village.
      (2)   The Village may enter into a contract with any person, in which an
elected or appointed member of the Village corporate authorities has an
interest, direct or indirect, provided that the following requirements are met:
         A.   If the amount of the contract does not exceed two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) and the total of such contracts awarded to the same person in
a given year does not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), the contract may
be entered into without violating the conflict of interest laws.
         B.   If the amount of the contract exceeds two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) and the total of such contracts awarded to the same person in a given
year does not exceed one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500), such contract
may be entered into, provided that the interested official has less than a
seven and one-half percent ownership interest in the business.
         C.   If the amount of the contract exceeds one thousand five hundred
dollars ($1,500) and the annual aggregate of such contracts awarded to the same
person is less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000), such contract may
be entered into, provided that the interested official has less than a seven
and one-half percent ownership interest in the business and the contract is
awarded, after sealed bids, to the lowest responsible bidder.
         D.   If the contract is for the procurement of public utility
services, such contract does not constitute a conflict of interest, provided
that the interested official does not own more than a seven and one-half
percent ownership interest in the public utility company.
         E.   In each of the instances cited in paragraphs (b)(2)A. through (b)
(2)D. hereof, the interested official must disclose the nature and extent of
his or her interest, he or she must abstain from voting on the award of the
contract and the award of the contract must be approved by a majority vote of
the Board of Trustees.
      (3)   The Village may deposit funds in a bank in which a member of the
corporate authorities has an interest, provided that his or her ownership
interest in the bank does not exceed five percent of the aggregate ownership.
      (4)   No elected or appointed official shall accept any compensation for
the performance of his or her official duties other than that provided to him
or her by the Village.
      (5)   Every elected or appointed official shall file a financial
statement on or before April 15 of each year hereafter disclosing his or her
investments and interests in real property located in the Village or within the
one and one-half mile planning perimeter. Such statement shall be filed on a
form prescribed by the Village Clerk and shall be available for public
inspection. Such statement shall include information regarding any investment
or interest in any parcel of real estate, except the personal residence of the
elected or appointed official, and should include a statement of any economic
interest should there be any doubt on the part of the elected or appointed
official that the holding of such economic interest creates a conflict of
interest with his or her Municipal duties and responsibilities. Such official
shall file a copy of his or her statement of economic interest with the Clerk
within thirty days after he or she is required to file such statement with the
County Clerk as required by law.
(1976 Code § 2-77; Ord. 507. Passed 9-26-77.)
   (c)   Rules of Conduct.
      (1)   No member of the corporate authorities may solicit, accept or agree
to accept, gifts, loans, gratuities, discounts, favors, hospitality or services
under circumstances from which it could be reasonably inferred that a major
purpose of the donor is to influence the member in the performance of his or
her official duties. This provision does not apply to:
         A.   Any political contribution, in cash or in kind, if such
contribution is used for political purposes;
         B.   Any promotional contribution which would benefit the community;
         C.   The purchase of tickets or advertisements for political,
testimonial or goodwill dinners; or
         D.   A commercial reasonable loan made in the ordinary course of
business.
      (2)   No elected or appointed official shall accept any economic
opportunity, under circumstances where he or she knows that there is a
substantial possibility that the opportunity is being afforded to him or her
with the intent to influence his or her conduct in the performance of his or
her official duties.
      (3)   No elected or appointed official shall charge to or accept, from a
person known to have a legislative interest, a price, fee, compensation or
other consideration for the sale or lease of any property, or for the
furnishing of services, which is substantially in excess of that which the
legislator would charge in the ordinary course of business.
      (4)   No elected or appointed official, in order to further his or her
own economic interests, or those of any other person, shall disclose or use
confidential information acquired in the course of his or her official duties.
      (5)   No elected or appointed official shall receive compensation as an
elected or appointed official of any other unit of government in the State
without first obtaining the consent of the corporate authorities.
      (6)   No elected or appointed official may engage in other conduct which
is unbecoming to a public servant or which constitutes a breach of public
trust.
(1976 Code § 2-78; Ord. 507. Passed 9-26-77.)
   (d)   Ethical Principles.
      (1)   Where feasible, and taking into account the fact that legislative
service is part-time, an elected or appointed official should avoid accepting
or retaining an economic opportunity which presents a substantial threat to his
or her independence of judgment.
      (2)   When a member of the corporate authorities takes official action on
a legislative matter as to which he or she has a conflict situation created by
a personal, family or client legislative interest, he or she should consider
the possibility of eliminating the interest creating the conflict situation. If
that is not feasible, he or she should consider the possibility of abstaining
from such official action. In making his or her decision as to abstention, the
following factors should be considered:
         A.   Whether a substantial threat to his or her independence of
judgment is created by the conflict situation;
         B.   The effect of his or her participation on public confidence in
the integrity of the Village government;
         C.   Whether his or her participation is likely to have a significant
effect on the disposition of the matter; and
         D.   The need for his or her particular contribution, such as special
knowledge of the subject matter, to the effective functioning of the Village
government.
         He or she need not abstain if he or she decides to participate in a
manner contrary to the economic interest which creates the conflict situation.
         If he or she does abstain, he or she shall disclose that fact to the
Board of Trustees.
(1976 Code § 2-79; Ord. 507. Passed 9-26-77.)

256.28 EQUAL EMPLOYMENT.
   The Village is an equal employment opportunity employer and as such does not
discriminate on the basis of race, color, religion, creed, ancestry, national
origin, age, sex, marital status or physical or mental handicap.
(Res. R-47-84. Passed 11-12-84.)
256.29 SEXUAL HARASSMENT POLICY.
   (a)   Intent. It is the policy of the Village to preserve, protect and
enhance the dignity of all Village personnel and to provide a professional work
environment free from sexual intimidation, ridicule, insult and overtones
perpetrated upon or by any employee.
   (b)   Application of Policy. This Policy prohibiting sexual harassment
applies to all officers and employees of the Village, including, but not
limited to, full-time and part-time employees, permanent and temporary
employees, employees covered under Fire and Police Commission rules, and
elected and appointed officials.
   (c)   Sexual Harassment Defined. Sexual harassment is behavior with sexual
content or overtones that is unwelcome and personally offensive. For the
purposes of this Policy, "sexual harassment" means unwelcome sexual advances,
direct or implied requests for sexual favors, and other verbal and/or physical
conduct of a sexual nature:
      (1)   When submission to such conduct is made, explicitly or implicitly,
a term or condition of an individual's employment, evaluation, advancement or
promotion;
      (2)   When submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual is
used as the basis, or any part of the basis, affecting such individual's
career, job or employment conditions; or
      (3)   When such conduct has the purpose or effect of interfering with an
individual's performance or creating an intimidating, hostile or offensive
working environment.
   (d)   Prohibited Conduct.
      (1)   Sexual harassment includes conduct directed by men toward women, by
women toward men, by women toward women and by men toward men. Sexual
harassment consists of, but is not limited to, the following:
         A.   Verbal behavior: negative or offensive comments, jokes, kidding
or suggestions about another employee's gender or sexuality; threats relating
to sexual conduct; repeated unwelcome requests for dates; statements of a
sexual nature about other employees; obscene or lewd sexual comments; using
slang names or labels that can be considered derogatory or too familiar, such
as "honey," "sweetie," "dear," "darling," "boy," "girl" or other terms people
may find offensive; or talking about or calling attention to an employee's body
or characteristics in a sexually negative or embarrassing way.
         B.   Nonverbal behavior: sexually suggestive looks; sexually
suggestive or insulting sounds, such as whistles, catcalls or smacking or
kissing noises; or obscene or sexually suggestive bodily gestures.
         C.   Physical behavior: unwelcome physical contact, such as pats,
squeezes, hugs, kissing, pinching, purposeful rubbing against another person's
body or actual sexual assault or abuse;
         D.   Visual behavior: displaying pictures, cartoons, posters, pinups,
calendars, signs, etc., of a nude or of a sexual nature.
         E.   Other behavior, including, but not limited to, laughing at,
ignoring or not taking seriously an employee who experiences sexual harassment;
blaming the victim of sexual harassment for causing the problems; continuing
the offensive behavior after a co-worker has expressed objection to the
behavior; retaliating against an employee who rejects sexual advances by
denying promotions or other job related benefits; gossiping about or ridiculing
a victim or alleged harasser with respect to the alleged harassment; demanding
or requesting sexual favors tied to promises of better treatment or threats
concerning employment; discriminating against an employee for refusing to give
in to demands or requests for sexual favors; or rewarding or granting favors to
one who submits to demands or requests for sexual favors.
      (2)   No employee shall, directly or indirectly:
         A.   Threaten or insinuate that another employee's refusal to submit
to sexual advances will adversely affect that employee's relationship with the
Village, work status evaluation, wages, advancement, assigned duties or any
other condition of employment;
         B.   Promise, imply or grant preferential treatment in connection with
another employee engaging in sexual conduct; or
         C.   Abuse the dignity of another employee through insulting or
degrading sexual remarks or conduct.
   (e)   Reporting of Alleged Violations. An employee alleging a violation of
this Policy should report, as quickly as possible, in confidence, such
complaints. Such allegations may be brought to the attention of an immediate
supervisor, the Assistant Village Manager, the Village Manager or the Village
President. Persons receiving such complaints shall secure, in written form, the
following information:
      (1)   The name, department and position of the complainant;
      (2)   The name(s) of the person(s) alleged to be in violation of this
Policy, if known;
      (3)   The specific action or series of acts or actions constituting the
behavior alleged to be sexual harassment, including, but not limited to:
         A.   The length of time that such behavior has transpired.
         B.   The implied or actual employment action (i.e. failure to promote,
job assignments, refusal to hire, etc.) that may have occurred.
   (NOTE: Sexual harassment does not necessarily have to be linked to the grant
or denial of an economic quid pro quo. Sexual harassment leading to a
noneconomic injury is also prohibited.)
      (4)   The names of any witnesses or others with knowledge of such
behavior.
   Every effort will be made to promptly investigate any allegation of sexual
harassment in as confidential a manner as possible.
   (f)   Investigation of Alleged Violations; Determinations; Disciplinary
Action.
      (1)   The Village Manager or his or her designated agent shall
investigate complaints alleging violations of this Policy, except in an
instance in which the allegations involve, directly or by complicity, the
Village Manager, in which event the investigative responsibilities shall be
assigned by the Village President to another employee.
      (2)   A written record of the investigation shall be made, inclusive of
all notes made of conversations or verbal responses to questions posed by the
investigator to the complainant, witnesses or respondent. The entire written
record and report shall be provided to the Village Manager within ten working
days from the date the allegations were first reported in writing.
      (3)   The Village Manager shall, based upon the investigative report,
evidence and all known circumstances, make a determination as to whether sexual
harassment, as defined by this Policy, has occurred.
      (4)   If the determination is made that sexual harassment has occurred,
the Village Manager shall take immediate and appropriate disciplinary action
consistent with the nature and severity of the offense. Disciplinary action
shall be in accordance with the rules and regulations of the Village's
Personnel Manual, these Codified Ordinances and, when applicable, the rules of
the Fire and Police Commission.
      (5)   In all instances, whether a violation of this Policy is determined
to have occurred or not to have occurred, the respondent shall not retaliate in
any way against the complainant, witnesses or any other person involved in the
investigation.
      (6)   Complaints alleging violations of this Policy by:
         A.   The Village Manager. If the Village Manager is found, after an
appropriate investigation, to have violated this Policy, the Village President
shall present the investigative report and findings to the Board of Trustees.
If the Board concurs with the findings, the Board shall impose discipline in
accordance with the applicable rules and ordinances of the Village.
         B.   An elected official of the Village. If any elected official of
the Village is found to have violated this Policy, the investigative report and
findings shall be presented to the Village President and the Board of Trustees,
excluding the member alleged to have violated this Policy. If the members
concur with the findings, they shall impose the appropriate discipline.
         C.   Non-employees. In instances of sexual harassment alleged to have
been committed in the workplace or in a work related situation by a
nonemployee, the Village Manager shall take all lawful action to insure the
safety and dignity of the employee and to end the incidence of harassment.
   (g)   Other Remedies. The filing of a sexual harassment complaint with the
appropriate Village official under this Policy does not limit, extend, replace
or delay the right of any person to file a similar charge or complaint with any
Federal or state agency having authority to hear matters of sexual harassment
complaints.
(Ord. 895. Passed 4-22-96.)
256.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of Section
256.06 shall, in addition to the penalty provided in Section
202.99, be subject to further action by the corporate authorities as they may
deem appropriate in accordance with law.
(1976 Code § 2-80; Ord. 507. Passed 9-26-77.)

CHAPTER 260
Planning and Zoning Commission
   EDITOR'S NOTE: This chapter, previously a codification of Ordinance 192,
passed November 13, 1956, as amended, and titled: Planning Commission, was
repealed by Ordinance 813, passed May 9, 1994, which also changed the name of
the Commission to the Planning and Zoning Commission and provided that the
duties of the former Planning Commission and the Zoning Board of Appeals would
be assumed by the Planning and Zoning Commission. Section 14.04 of the
Village's Zoning Ordinance was amended accordingly. The Planning and Zoning
Commission was reestablished by Ordinance 1758, passed August 23, 2021, as set
forth in this chapter.
260.01   Establishment.
260.02   Jurisdiction.
260.03   Meetings.
260.04   Finality of decisions.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Establishment and composition - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 24, § 11-12-4
   Powers and duties - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 24, § 11-12-5
   Adoption of comprehensive plan and official plan - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 24, §
11-12-6
   Initiating comprehensive plans; hearings - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 24, § 11-12-7
   Thoroughfare Plan - see P. & Z.
Ch. 1210
   Land Use Plan - see P. & Z.
Ch. 1212
260.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Planning and Zoning Commission. Said
Planning and Zoning Commission shall consist of five members appointed by the
President and the Village Board of the Village of Richton Park.
   (b)   Each member shall be appointed to serve for a term of five years.
Vacancies shall be filled by the Village Board for an unexpired term. Members
may be removed by the Village Board for cause after written charges have been
filed and after a public hearing has been held if demanded by the member so
charged.
   (c)   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall be deemed to be the "Board of
Appeals," as described in 65 ILCS 5/11-13-1 et. seq., and the "Plan
Commission," as described in 65 ILCS 5/11-12-1 et. seq.
   (d)   One of the members of said Planning and Zoning Commission at the time
of his appointment shall be designated by the Village Board as Chairman of said
Planning and Zoning Commission and shall hold said office until a successor is
appointed. Such Chairman, or in his absence, the Acting Chairman, may
administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses.
   (e)   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall have a secretary and may
employ a court reporter who shall make and keep a record of all of its meetings
and official acts.
(Ord. 1758. Passed 8-23-21.)
260.02 JURISDICTION.
   The Planning and Zoning Commission is hereby vested with the following
jurisdiction and authority:
   (a)   Prepare and recommend to the Board of Trustees a comprehensive plan,
which shall be known as the Official Plan of the Village which shall include
the all territory within the Village limits and within one and one-half miles
of the Village limits not within another municipality.
   (b)   Prepare and recommend to the Village Board from time to time changes
to the Official Plan.
   (c)   Prepare and recommend from time to time recommendations for
implementation of the Official Plan.
   (d)   To hold public hearings on proposed amendments to the Village Zoning
Ordinance and Development Code.
   (e)   Review of requests of plats of subdivision as outlined in the Village
Development Code.
   (f)   Review of site plans as required by the Village Zoning Ordinance and
Development Code.
   (g)   Review of other matters in regards to development and zoning as
required by the Village Zoning Ordinance and Development Code.
   (h)   Review of other policy issues that the Village Board may forward to
the Planning and Zoning Commission for recommendation.
   (i)   To hear and decide appeals from any order, requirement, decision or
determination made by the Zoning Administrator under this chapter.
   (j)   To hear and pass upon application for variations from the terms
provided in the Zoning Ordinance in the manner prescribed by, and subject to,
the standards established herein.
(Ord. 1758. Passed 8-23-21.)
260.03 MEETINGS.
   (a)   All meetings of the Planning and Zoning Commission shall be held at
the call of the Chairman and at such other times the Planning and Zoning
Commission may determine. If a public hearing is required, there shall be at
least fifteen days, but not more than thirty days notice of the time and place
of such meeting published in a paper of general circulation in the Village of
Richton Park; said notice to contain a statement of the particular purpose of
such meeting and a brief description of the location of the property or purpose
under consideration at such hearing.
   (b)   All meetings of the Planning and Zoning Commission shall be open to
the public and be in compliance with the Open Meetings Act.
   (c)   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall keep minutes of its
proceedings showing the vote of each member upon every question, or if absent
or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall also keep records of its
examinations and other official actions. Findings of fact shall be included in
the minutes of each case when required and the reasons for granting or denying
such application shall be specified. Every rule, regulation and every order,
requirement, decision, or determination of the Planning and Zoning Commission
shall immediately be filed in the office of the Zoning Administrator and shall
be public record.
   (d)   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall adopt its own rules of
procedure and may require submission to each record, plats and other
information necessary to make its determinations. A copy of said rules and
procedure, and all recommendations thereto, and shall be filed in the office of
the Zoning Administrator.
   (e)   The minutes of the Planning and Zoning Commission shall be open for
public examination at the Zoning Administrator's office during normal business
hours.
   (f)   Expenses incurred by the Planning and Zoning Commission are to be
itemized and shall be borne by the Village of Richton Park.
(Ord. 1758. Passed 8-23-21.)
260.04 FINALITY OF DECISIONS.
   All decisions and findings of the Planning and Zoning Commission, on appeals
or upon application for a variance after a hearing shall, in all instances, be
final administrative determination and shall be subject to review by court as
by law may be provided. Other decisions may be advisory or final as per other
sections of the Zoning Ordinance and Development Code.
(Ord. 1758. Passed 8-23-21.)
CHAPTER 262
Zoning Board of Appeals
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The Zoning Board of Appeals was abolished by Ordinance 813,
passed May 9, 1994, which provided that the duties of such Board would be
assumed by the Planning and Zoning Commission of the Village, previously known
as the Planning Commission of the Village. Section 14.04 of the Village's
Zoning Ordinance was amended accordingly.

264.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established, by and for the Village, the Police Commission.
(Ord. 423. Passed 2-14-74; 1976 Code §2-55; Ord. 1862. Passed 4-28-25.)
264.02 COMPOSITION.
   The Police Commission shall consist of three members who are officers of the
Village, as provided by statute.
(Ord. 423. Passed 2-14-74; 1976 Code §2-56; Ord. 1862. Passed 4-28-25.)
264.03 QUALIFICATIONS.
   The members of the Police Commission shall have the qualifications as are
now, or may hereafter be, required of them by law.
(Ord. 423. Passed 2-14-74; 1976 Code §2-57; Ord. 1862. Passed 4-28-25.)
264.04 APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL OF MEMBERS; TERMS OF OFFICE.
   (a)   The members of the Police Commission shall be appointed by the
President of the Board of Trustees by and with the consent of the Board.
   (b)   Each member shall serve a term of office of three years or until his
or her successor is appointed and qualified, provided that no such appointments
are made by any President of the Board of Trustees within thirty days before
the expiration of his or her term of office and provided, further, that the
President shall appoint the first members. One of such first members shall be
appointed to serve until the end of the current Municipal year in which such
appointment is made, another shall serve until the end of the Municipal year
next ensuing and the third shall serve until the end of the Municipal year
second next ensuing. Each of the first members shall serve until his or her
successor is appointed and qualified.
   (c)   Members are subject to removal from office in the same manner as other
officers of the Village.
(Ord. 423. Passed 2-14-74; 1976 Code §2-58.)
   (d)   A vacancy in an unexpired term of office shall be filled in the same
manner as the original appointment. (1976 Code §2-59.)
(Ord. 1862. Passed 4-28-25.)
264.05 CHAIRMAN.
   For each Municipal year, the members of the Police Commission shall elect a
Chairman.
(1976 Code §2-60; Ord. 1862. Passed 4-28-25.)
264.06 OATHS AND BONDS OF MEMBERS. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 264.06 was repealed by Ordinance 652, passed October
8, 1984.)
264.07 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Police Commission shall have such powers and duties as are now or may
hereafter be given to it by ordinance and statute.
(Ord. 423. Passed 2-14-74; 1976 Code §2-62; Ord. 1862. Passed 4-28-25.)
264.08 QUORUM.
   A majority of the members of the Police Commission shall constitute a quorum
for the conduct of business.
(1976 Code §2-63; Ord. 1862. Passed 4-28-25.)
264.09 COMPENSATION OF MEMBERS.
   The members of the Police Commission shall receive such compensation as the
Board of Trustees determines by ordinance.
(Ord. 423. Passed 2-14-74; 1976 Code §2-64; Ord. 1862. Passed 4-28-25.)

Police Pension Board and Fund

   CROSS REFERENCES
   Pensions - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 24, § 10-2.1-17

270.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established, by and for the Village, a Police Pension Fund
and a Police Pension Board to administer such Fund in accordance with Illinois
R.S. Chapter 108-1/2, Article 3, as amended.
(Ord. 426. Passed 2-28-74; 1976 Code §15-41.)
270.02 APPOINTMENT, POWERS AND DUTIES AND COMPENSATION OF BOARD MEMBERS;
OPERATION.
   The Police Pension Board shall be appointed and elected as provided in these
Codified Ordinances and shall exercise the powers and perform the duties
required of it by law. All moneys and securities belonging to the Police
Pension Fund shall be held by the Village Treasurer subject to the order of the
Board. An annual list of beneficiaries and a report of funds shall be made as
required by law. Members of such Board shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 426. Passed 2-28-74; 1976 Code § 15-42.)
270.03 POLICY RE DISABILITY PENSIONERS.
   The policy of the Village, in regard to its disability pensioners under the
Police Pension Fund, shall be:
   (a)   That each such disability pensioner shall be permitted to continue his
or her health insurance benefits during the entire time of each such
disability, at the disability pensioner's sole expense;
   (b)   That the Village's responsibility shall be limited to the statutory
requirement that it notify the appropriate carrier, if any, at the time such
disability begins. The Village shall in no case pay any portion of such
disability pensioner's health insurance expenses.
(Res. R-33-91. Passed 9-9-91.)
CHAPTER 272
Economic Development Commission
272.01   Establishment.
272.02   Responsibilities.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Board of Local Improvements - see ADM.
Ch. 266
272.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established in and for the Village an advisory commission to
be known as the Economic Development Commission. The Commission shall be made
up of, but shall not be limited to, members from the Village's residential,
commercial, real estate and financial communities.
(Res. R-80-5. Passed 1-28-80.)
272.02 RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Economic Development Commission is hereby authorized and directed to:
   (a)   Review the history and existing studies and planning ordinances of the
Village;
   (b)   Conduct such studies as are necessary to gather information within the
area of economic development;
   (c)   Review and recommend areas for economic development within the Village
and the types of development recommended for these areas;
   (d)   Conduct a comprehensive review of the financial alternatives which are
available and feasible for the Village to use to encourage economic growth,
including, but not limited to, industrial revenue bonds, community development
block grant funds, Federal economic development programs, tax incremental
financing, commercial development bonds and MFT for road construction in
commercial areas;
   (e)   Study both long term and short term activities to be recommended to
the Board of Trustees; and
   (f)   Study any and all other matters that are pertinent to the subject of
economic development as may seem appropriate.
(Res. R-80-5. Passed 1-28-80.)

CHAPTER 276
Parks and Recreation Commission
276.01   Establishment.
276.02   Purpose of Department.
276.03   Membership.
276.04   Organization.
276.05   Meetings.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Illinois Vehicle Code - see TRAF.
Ch. 410
   Open burning - see GEN. OFF.
606.03
   Animals - see GEN. OFF.
Ch. 608
   Parks and recreation - see GEN. OFF.
Ch. 662
   Fireworks - see F.P.
1610.05(b)
276.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established, by and for the Village, a Parks and Recreation
Commission.
(Ord. 1708-A. Passed 10-23-19.)
276.02 PURPOSE OF DEPARTMENT.
   The Parks and Recreation Department of the Village of Richton Park is
established to enhance the current as well as the future quality of life for
its residents by providing safe and attractive parks as well as a challenging
set of recreational and cultural offerings.
(Ord. 1708-A. Passed 10-23-19.)
276.03 MEMBERSHIP.
   (a)   The Parks and Recreation Commission shall consist of eleven members to
be appointed by the President of the Board of Trustees and confirmed by the
Board to serve respectively for a three-year term. The successor to each member
so appointed shall serve for a term of three years beginning May 1 of the year
in which he or she is appointed and until his or her successor is duly
appointed and qualified.
   (b)   All members serving on the Commission shall be residents of the
Village.
   (c)   As vacancies occur on the Commission, the President shall appoint
persons, confirmed by the Board, to fill vacancies.
   (d)   Commission meetings should have the presence of a Parks and Recreation
Department staff or designee.
(Ord. 1708-A. Passed 10-23-19.)
276.04 ORGANIZATION.
   (a)   At the first regular board meeting following January 1 of every year
or as soon as practicable thereafter, the Commission shall elect a Chairperson
and Vice-Chairperson from among its eligible voting members to serve for a
period of one year. The Chairperson shall be the chief officer of the
Commission. In their absence, or upon written direction from the Chairperson,
the Vice-Chairperson shall fulfill duties as designated by the Chairperson.
   (b)   A member shall be eligible to be elected as Chairperson, or as Vice-
Chairperson, if they meet one or more of the following guidelines:
      (1)   Actively participated in or involved with at least 75% of parks and
recreation programs or special events offered in the last calendar year.
      (2)   Attended at least 75% of Commission meetings in the last calendar
year.
   (c)   The Parks and Recreation Commission may appoint subcommittees that
they deem appropriate to provide expertise and advice on any matter within the
dominion of the particular commission.
      (1)   The subcommittee shall consist of not less than three members, nor
more than seven, including at least two current Parks and Recreation
Commissioners. A Parks and Recreation staff member shall function in an “ex
officio” capacity as a liaison to the Committee and shall have no vote.
         A.   Subcommittees shall be composed of Commission members, as well as
other residents appointed by the President of the Board of Trustees or
designated agent.
         B.   The chairperson of any subcommittee shall be a voting member of
the commission that established the subcommittee.
      (2)   The role of any subcommittee shall be to provide expertise and
advice to the Commission and its members only. Subcommittee members may not
advise the Board of Trustees. Subcommittee members may not speak on behalf of
the Commission without prior approval of a majority of the members of the
Commission.
(Ord. 1708-A. Passed 10-23-19.)
276.05 MEETINGS.
   (a)   All meetings of the Commission, including committee meetings and
public hearings, shall be open to the public and comply with the Open Meetings
Act.
   (b)   Regular meetings of the Commission shall be monthly commencing at a
time and location agreed upon by the Commission.
      (1)   The Chairperson, working with the Parks and Recreation Department
staff, may cancel or reschedule any regular meeting because of a lack of a
quorum of voting members or the lack of agenda items by written notice within a
reasonable time prior to the scheduled meeting date.
   (c)   Special meetings of the Commission may be called at the discretion of
the Chairperson or by request of a majority of Commission members.
   (d)   (1)   An agenda, together with a notice of the time and place of any
such meeting scheduled or rescheduled, shall be provided to the Commission
members and posted on the Village's website at least 48 business hours in
advance of the holding of the meeting except in the case of an emergency
meeting.
         A.   Provided the Commission member has provided notice prior to the
scheduled meeting, a Commissioner can be excused from a meeting for any of the
following reasons:
            1.   Illness of the member or of a family member;
            2.   Work commitment of the member that interferes with the
attendance of the member at a meeting;
            3.   Previously scheduled vacation of the member, notice of which
was provided to the respective board or commission in advance of the meeting.
         B.   Commission members, by a majority vote, may excuse a fellow
Commissioner's absence from meetings for any of the following reasons:
            1.   Attendance of the member at a funeral, religious service or
ceremony, wedding, or other similarly significant event; or
            2.   Other reasons for which the member has given notice to the
chairperson of his or her unavailability if the unavailability is expected to
last for longer than thirty days.
      (2)   The Parks and Recreation Commission acting as a whole shall monitor
the attendance records of Commission members and shall make recommendations to
the President or Board of Trustees for the removal of a member for cause.
(Ord. 1708-A. Passed 10-23-19.)
CHAPTER 277
Parks and Recreation Commission
Scholarship Committee By-Laws
277.01   Establishment.
277.02   Official name.
277.03   Purpose.
277.04   Membership.
277.05   Membership selection.
277.06   Meetings; organization.
277.07   Duties and responsibilities.
277.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established, by and for the Village as a Subcommittee of the
Richton Park Parks and Recreation Commission, a scholarship committee.
(Ord. 1649. Passed 7-10-17.)
277.02 OFFICIAL NAME.
   The official name of the Committee shall be the Richton Park Parks and
Recreation Commission Scholarship Committee (hereafter called the “Scholarship
Committee”).
(Ord. 1649. Passed 7-10-17.)
277.03 PURPOSE.
   The Scholarship Committee supports the advancement of higher education for
the residents of Richton Park by providing financial assistance for qualifying
and deserving residents through the coordination of the funding, application
design, delivery and selection process for all scholarships.
(Ord. 1649. Passed 7-10-17.)
277.04 MEMBERSHIP.
   (a)   The Scholarship Committee shall function impartially and award all
scholarships on an objective and nondiscriminatory basis.
   (b)   The Scholarship Committee shall consist of not less than three
members, nor more than seven, including at least two current Parks and
Recreation Commissioners. A Parks and Recreation staff member shall function in
an “ex officio” capacity as a liaison to the Committee and shall have no vote.
   (c)   Scholarship Committee members shall be residents of Richton Park.
(Ord. 1649. Passed 7-10-17.)
277.05 MEMBERSHIP SELECTION.
   (a)   Scholarship Committee members shall be appointed by the President of
the Board of Trustees or designated agent and selected from nominations
received in one of the following ways:
      (1)   A resident seeking a volunteer opportunity.
      (2)   A referral from other Scholarship Committee members.
      (3)   A referral from a member of the Parks and Recreation Commission.
      (4)   An invitation from the Village President.
      (5)   An invitation from a member of the Board of Trustees.
   (b)   Scholarship Committee members shall serve until retired by request of
the Village President or by their own request.
(Ord. 1649. Passed 7-10-17.)
277.06 MEETINGS; ORGANIZATION.
   (a)   The Scholarship Committee shall convene a minimum of three meetings
per year.
   (b)   The Scholarship Committee shall consist of the following officers:
       (1)   Chairperson.
      (2)   Vice Chairperson.
      (3)   Recording Secretary.
   (c)   These officers shall be elected by the body of the Scholarship
Committee for a term of one year. Elections shall be held as the first order of
business of the first meeting of the year.
(Ord. 1649. Passed 7-10-17.)
277.07 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (a)   The Scholarship Committee shall convene a minimum of three meetings
per year. Attendance at all meetings is mandatory. The meetings shall be for
the following purposes:
      (1)   Scholarship application and award criteria review and update.
      (2)   Evaluation of all scholarship applications, determination of
awards, approval of award and rejection letter content.
      (3)   Plan and execute scholarship fundraising events.
   (b)   It shall be the duty and responsibility of all Scholarship Committee
members to contribute to the planning and execution of all scholarship
fundraising ideas and events.
   (c)   It shall be the duty and responsibility of the Scholarship Committee
to perform the following duties to coordinate the application, delivery and
selection process for scholarships:
      (1)   Annually review and update all scholarship application forms for
publication.
      (2)   Review all received applications without regard to race, sex,
religion, age, national origin or sexual orientation to determine if they meet
the qualifications for evaluation presented in the scholarship application
packet.
         A.   The Scholarship Committee will not award scholarships to
applicants who do not meet the requirements stated in the application packet.
         B.   The Scholarship Committee reserves the right not to award any
scholarships in a given year if applications do not meet the criteria as
presented in the application packet.
      (3)   Rate all qualifying applications using a comprehensive process
based on objective standards. Areas that shall be reviewed include:
         A.   Prior academic performance,
         B.   Performance on tests designed to measure ability and aptitude for
higher education,
         C.   Recommendations from counselors, principals, teachers, employers,
and other individuals not related to the potential awardee,
         D.   Conclusions based on each applicant's personal essay as to
motivation and character.
      (4)   Determine the monetary awards to be given to the individual
applicants based upon available funds and the Scholarship Committees' rating of
each application.
   (d)   Members of the Scholarship Committee and members of their families
(spouse, ancestors, children, grandchildren, great grandchildren, and the
spouses of children, grandchildren, and great grandchildren) shall not be
eligible for any scholarship award.
(Ord. 1649. Passed 7-10-17.)
CHAPTER 278
Parks and Recreation Commission - Teen Advisory Committee
278.01   Establishment.
278.02   Purpose.
278.03   Membership.
278.04   Meetings; Reports.
278.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established, by and for the Village, a Subcommittee of the
Richton Park Parks and Recreation Commission to be called the Teen Advisory
Committee.
(Ord. 1755. Passed 6-14-21; Ord. 1853A. Passed 12-9-24.)
278.02 PURPOSE.
   The Teen Advisory Committee will work with the Parks and Recreation
Commission to develop, recommend, and implement the following:
   (a)   Recreational and special events for teens;
   (b)   Trips and similar events for teens; and
   (c)   Assisting as volunteers to support community related events.
(Ord. 1755. Passed 6-14-21; Ord. 1853A. Passed 12-9-24.)
278.03 MEMBERSHIP.
   (a)   The Teen Advisory Committee shall consist of the following:
      (1)   Not less than five nor more than ten members, who are in grades
nine through 12, and are residents of the Village; and
      (2)   Up to five members who are non-residents of the Village.
   (b)   Committee members must have a cumulative grade point average of at
least 2.5 or equivalent and must furnish at least two letters of recommendation
prior to appointment.
   (c)   Committee members shall be appointed by the President with the advice
and consent of the Board of Trustees.
   (d)   Committee members shall serve for a one-year term.
(Ord. 1755. Passed 6-14-21; Ord. 1853A. Passed 12-9-24.)
278.04 MEETINGS; REPORTS.
   (a)   Under the supervision of the Director of Parks and Recreation, the
Committee shall meet from time to time.
   (b)   The Committee shall, from time to time, provide the President and
Board of Trustees with a report of its activities.
(Ord. 1755. Passed 6-14-21; Ord. 1853A. Passed 12-9-24.)

CHAPTER 286
Beautification Committee
286.01   Establishment.
286.02   Official name.
286.03   Membership.
286.04   Membership selection.
286.05   Meetings; organization.
286.06   Duties and responsibilities; eligibility for awards.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Weeds and grasses - see GEN. OFF.
634.10; B. & H.
1480.04 (BOCA § PM-303.4)
   Removal of graffiti - see GEN. OFF.

   Trees - see S.U. & P.S.

   Yard wastes - see S.U. & P.S.

286.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established, by and for the Village, a Beautification
Committee.
286.02 OFFICIAL NAME.
   The official name of the Committee shall be the Beautification Committee.
(Ord. 892. Passed 3-25-95.)
    286.03   MEMBERSHIP.
   (a)   The Committee shall consist of not less than nine nor more than twenty
members, plus the Code Enforcement Officer and a Village Hall staff member
designated by the Village Manager. The Code Enforcement Officer and the staff
member shall function in advisory positions only.
   (b)   Members may be from outside the Village of Richton Park, but in no
case shall their number exceed one-third of the voting membership. People
owning businesses in the Village but who do not reside in the Village are
exempt from this restriction and shall be counted as residents for the purpose
of qualifying for membership.
(Ord. 892. Passed 3-25-95 Ord. 1647. Passed 6-26-17.)
286.04 MEMBERSHIP SELECTION.
   (a)   Members shall be selected in one of the following ways:
      (1)   Volunteers from the community.
      (2)   An invitation from the Village President.
      (3)   An invitation from any member of the Board of Trustees.
      (4)   A referral from other members.
   (b)   An effort shall be made to keep the membership as diverse and as
representative of the community at large as possible and, ideally, shall
consist of residents from each of the existing subdivisions, business areas and
industrial parks that make up the Village.
   (c)   Members shall serve until retired by request of the Village President
or by their own request.
(Ord. 892. Passed 3-25-95.)
286.05 MEETINGS; ORGANIZATION.
   (a)   The Committee shall convene from May 1 through August 31, each year.
   (b)   The Committee shall consist of the following officers:
      (1)   Chairperson
      (2)   Vice Chairperson
      (3)   Recording Secretary
   (c)   These officers shall be elected by the body of the Committee for a
term of one year. Elections shall be held as the first order of business of the
first meeting of the year.
   (d)   The Code Enforcement Officer and staff person shall be ex-officio
members of the Committee. They shall have no vote and shall function only in an
advisory manner. The staff person, however, may perform property inspections,
but shall have no vote in the selection of award winners.
   (e)   The Code Enforcement Officer shall not be involved in the property
inspection process.
(Ord. 892. Passed 3-25-95.)
286.06 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES; ELIGIBILITY FOR AWARDS.
   (a)   It shall be the duty and responsibility of the Committee to perform
the following duties:
      (1)   Plan each year's beautification award campaign.
      (2)   Determine the type of awards to be given to the individual winners.
      (3)   Observe all properties in the Village and make recommendations to
the general body of the Committee which of those properties observed they feel
should be considered for special recognition.
      (4)   Once all of the recommendations are made, score each property
according to prior criteria established by the Committee. Properties that score
the highest shall be awarded recognition. In the event that any particular
property's score is equal to that of another like property, duplicate
recognition shall be awarded.
      (5)   Report to the Board of Trustees, in writing, the winners of the
campaign.
   (b)   Members of the Committee and their relatives shall not be eligible for
any award.
(Ord. 892. Passed 3-25-95.)
CHAPTER 288
Foreign Fire Insurance Board
EDITOR’S NOTE: Ordinance 920, passed November 11, 1996, which previously
established this chapter, was repealed and replaced by Ordinance 1822, passed
October 23, 2023.
288.01   Establishment.
288.02   Definitions.
288.03   Organization; powers and responsibilities.
288.04   Officers.
288.05   Meetings; quorum; minutes.
288.06   Designation of authorized representative.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Insurance for volunteer firemen - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 24 §§ 10-5-1 et seq.
   Fire Department - see ADM.
Ch. 252
   Fire and Police Commission - see ADM.
Ch. 264
   Foreign fire insurance companies - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 832
288.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established, by and for the Village, a Foreign Fire
Insurance Board.
(Ord. 1822. Passed 10-23-23.)
288.02 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, the following terms shall be given the meanings
herein ascribed to them.
   (a)   “Board” means the Foreign Fire Insurance Board created by this
chapter.
   (b)   “Department” means the Village of Richton Park Fire Department.
   (c)   “Fund” means the Foreign Fire Insurance Tax Fund, pursuant to 65 ILCS
5/11-10-1.
   (d)   “Members of the Department” means all fire-fighters employed by the
Village, whether full-time, part-time or paid-on-call. Any member of the
Richton Park Fire Department who has not completed the applicable probationary
period or is not in good standing in accordance with regulations shall not be
eligible to be an officer of the Board.
(Ord. 1822. Passed 10-23-23.)
288.03 ORGANIZATION; POWERS AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (a)   The Board shall consist of seven trustees; the Fire Chief, who shall
hold office by virtue of rank, and six members, who shall be elected at large
by the sworn members of the Department. If there is an insufficient number of
candidates to fill all these positions, the number of Board members may be
reduced, but not to fewer than three trustees. All sworn members of the
Department shall be eligible to be elected as officers of the Foreign Fire
Insurance Board. The members of this Board shall annually elect officers. These
officers shall be a chairman, a treasurer, and any other officers deemed
necessary by the Board.
   (b)   The members of the Board shall make all needful rules and regulations
with respect to the Foreign Fire Insurance Board and the management of the
funds to be paid to the Board. In particular, the Board:
      (1)   May establish, manage, and maintain an account for the holding and
expenditure of all funds paid to the Board.
      (2)   May contract for the purchase of goods and services using funds
paid to the Board. Contracting for services includes, but is not limited to,
the procurement and payment of all accounting, legal, collection, or other
professional services deemed by the Board to be necessary to the execution of
its duties under this division using funds paid to the Board.
      (3)   May sue all parties necessary to enforce its rights under this
section.
      (4)   Shall develop and maintain a listing of those items that the Board
feels are appropriate expenditures under this Act. The treasurer shall receive
the funds paid as provided in Section 288.01 and shall pay out the funds upon
the order of the foreign fire insurance board for the maintenance, use, and
benefit of the department or as otherwise permitted by this division. These
funds shall be audited to verify that the funds have been expended by that
Board only for the maintenance, use, and benefit of the Department using funds
paid to the Board. Contracting for services includes, but is not limited to,
the procurement and payment of all accounting, legal, collection, or other
professional services deemed by the Board to be necessary to the execution of
its duties under this division using funds paid to the Board.
   (c)   Disputes between a Fire Chief and the remaining members of a Foreign
Fire Insurance Board concerning whether any expenditure of funds by the Board
is for the maintenance, use, or benefit of the Department or for any other
purpose authorized by this Division shall be resolved through binding
arbitration, pursuant to a written arbitration agreement established by the
Foreign Fire Insurance Board, that is recognized under the Uniform Arbitration
Act. Arbitrations held pursuant to a written arbitration agreement are the
exclusive remedy available for resolving such disputes.
(Ord. 1822. Passed 10-23-23.)
288.04 OFFICERS.
   (a)   Chairman. The Chairman shall preside over all meetings of the Board.
The Chairman shall have such other powers as he or she may be given from time
to time by action of the Village President and the Board of Trustees,
consistent with the Illinois Municipal Code and these Codified Ordinances.
   (b)   Secretary. The Secretary shall keep an accurate record of all
resolutions, proceedings, minutes and actions of the Board and shall attest all
official documents with his or her signature. The Secretary shall keep these
minutes in a manner identical to the manner in which the Village Board minutes
are kept. The Secretary shall have custody of all documents, records, books and
papers belonging to the Board, except as provided by statute or ordinance. The
Secretary shall also perform any other such duties and functions as are
assigned from time to time by the President of the Board, the Village President
and the Board of Trustees.
   (c)   Treasurer. The Treasurer shall:
      (1)   Have charge of the receipt, custody and disbursement of all funds
received by the Village from the foreign fire insurance gross receipts tax, and
deposited in a special fund called the Foreign Fire Insurance Tax Fund (Fund);
      (2)   Deposit all monies in the Fund in the name of the Village of
Richton Park Fire Department in such banks, savings and loan associations or
other depositories as shall be approved by the Village President and the Board
of Trustees;
      (3)   Invest said funds as are not immediately required in such
securities as the Village Treasurer shall specifically or generally select from
time to time, provided, however, that all investments shall be made only in
those securities which may be purchased under the provisions of Illinois law;
      (4)   Maintain the financial books and records of the Board, keep a
current record of all financial transactions affecting the Fund and countersign
all checks involving the expenditures of moneys of the Fund;
      (5)   Receive all funds appropriated by the Village Board and pay out
money and otherwise make expenditures upon the order of the Board;
      (6)   Perform all duties incident to the office of Treasurer and such
other duties as from time to time may be required by law; and
      (7)   Give a sufficient bond to the Village of Richton Park, which shall
be approved by the Village President, conditioned upon the faithful performance
by the Treasurer of his or her duties under State statutes, Village ordinances
and the rules and regulations adopted by the Board. Said bond shall be paid for
from the Fund.
(Ord. 1822. Passed 10-23-23.)
288.05 MEETINGS; QUORUM; MINUTES.
   (a)   The Board shall be subject to the Open Meetings Act. In accordance
with the Act, the Board shall establish a regular time and place for its
meetings and shall publish all required notices. Four members of the Board
shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. Each member, except
for the Chief of the Fire Department, shall be entitled to one vote on every
matter brought to a vote. The affirmative vote of a majority of the quorum
shall constitute approval of the business before it.
   (b)   The President of the Board may call a special meeting at any time. The
President shall call a special meeting upon the written request of two members
of the Board. The request shall include a description of the subject matter of
the special meeting and shall be signed by all of the requesting members.
   (c)   Any person shall be entitled to appear and be heard on any matter
before the Board. A copy of minutes of all meetings shall be filed with the
Village Clerk.
(Ord. 1822. Passed 10-23-23.)
288.06 DESIGNATION OF AUTHORIZED REPRESENTATIVE.
   In accordance with 65 ILCS 5/11-10-2.5, the Village hereby designates the
Illinois Municipal League as its authorized representative to collect the fees
on behalf of the Village of Richton Park Foreign Fire Insurance Board.
(Ord. 1822. Passed 10-23-23.)
CHAPTER 290
Special Events Committee
290.01   Establishment.
290.02   Composition.
290.03   Responsibilities.
290.04   Meetings; no compensation.
290.05   Staff liaison.
290.06   Periodic report.
290.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established in and for the Village an advisory committee to
be known as the Special Events Committee. The Committee shall be made up of
five members appointed by the President, with the advice and consent of the
Board of Trustees and Village department directors. Initial appointments shall
be three members for three years and two members for two years. Thereafter, all
appointments shall be for three year terms.
(Ord. 1329. Passed 11-12-07.)
290.02 COMPOSITION.
   The appointed members of the Committee shall be residents of the Village or
members of the Village's commercial real estate and financial communities.
(Ord. 1329. Passed 11-12-07.)
290.03 RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Special Events Committee is hereby authorized and directed to:
   (a)   Within budget limits approved by the Board of Trustees, plan for
various special events in the Village, including such matters as the tourist
attractions, fun runs, parades and community gatherings.
   (b)   Study the feasibility and make recommendations to the Village Board
relating to new special events, analyze the results of completed special events
from a community acceptance and financial point of view and make
recommendations to the Board of Trustees regarding the continuation of such
events.
   (c)   Study and make recommendations to the Board of Trustees regarding such
other matters as may be referred to the Committee by the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 1329. Passed 11-12-07; Ord. 1511. Passed 2-13-12.)
290.04 MEETINGS; NO COMPENSATION.
   (a)   The Committee shall meet on an ad hoc basis at the call of the
Chairperson or any two members of the Committee.
   (b)   Appointed members of the Committee shall serve without compensation.
   (c)   All Committee meetings shall be conducted in accordance with the
Illinois Open Meetings Act.
(Ord. 1329. Passed 11-12-07.)
290.05 STAFF LIAISON.
   The Village Manager shall assign one or more Village staffmembers to serve
as Chair to the Committee.
(Ord. 1329. Passed 11-12-07.)
290.06 PERIODIC REPORT.
   From time to time the Committee, through the Chairperson, shall report to
the Board of Trustees as to the nature and extent of matters under
consideration by the Committee.
(Ord. 1329. Passed 11-12-07.)
CHAPTER 291
Sister Cities Committee
291.01   Creation; purpose.
291.02   Membership; appointment.
291.03   Responsibilities.
291.01   CREATION; PURPOSE.
   There is hereby created the Village of Richton Park an ad hoc Sister Cities
Committee. The purpose of the Committee is to develop and coordinate an active
Sister Cities program for the benefit of the Village, its residents and its
businesses.
(Ord. 1510A. Passed 2-13-12.)
291.02   MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT.
   (a)   The Committee shall consist of an indefinite number of members.
   (b)   Members shall be selected in one of the following ways:
      (1)   Volunteers from the community.
      (2)   Invitation from either the Village President or any member of the
Board of Trustees.
      (3)   A referral from other Committee members.
   (c)   An effort shall be made to keep the membership as diverse and
representative of the community at large as possible and ideally shall consist
of residents from each of the Village’s subdivisions.
   (d)   Members shall serve until retired by request of the Village President
or at their own request.
   (e)   The Community Relations Director shall be the staff liaison to the
Committee.
(Ord. 1510A. Passed 2-13-12.)
291.03   RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Committee shall have the following responsibilities:
   (a)   To work with Village staff in order to develop and recommend policies
for the operation of the Sister Cities program.
   (b)   To assist the Village in coordinating present and future Sister City
relationships.
   (c)   To recommend promotion and fundraising activities fro the Sister
Cities program as appropriate.
   (d)   To research and recommend to the President and Board of Trustees
potential Sister Cities.
   (e)   To work with other local governmental bodies to achieve the social and
educational benefits arising out of establishing a Sister City relationship.
   (f)   To recommend programs and affiliations with potential Sister Cities.
(Ord. 1510A. Passed 2-13-12.)
CHAPTER 292
Veteran's Commission
292.01   Establishment; duties.
292.02   Membership.
292.03   Organization; rules of procedure.
292.01 ESTABLISHMENT; DUTIES.
   There is hereby established for the Village a Veteran's Commission to
perform the following duties and functions:
   (a)   Serve as a centralized point of contact for veterans and their
families to bring matters of interest to the attention of the Village;
   (b)   To advise the President and Board of Trustees on matters pertaining to
veterans and how to best increase the participation and effectiveness of
veterans within the community;
   (c)   Increase awareness of educational, employment and other community
resource opportunities available to veterans who live in the Village;
   (d)   Support the development of suitable memorials for veterans;
   (e)   Perform such other functions and duties as may be assigned by the
Village President from time to time.
(Ord. 1675. Passed 7-9-18.)
292.02 MEMBERSHIP.
   The Veteran's Commission shall consist of seven members appointed by the
Village President and confirmed by the Board of Trustees. Initially, three
members will be appointed for a one-year term; two members will be appointed
for a two-year term; and two members will be appointed for a three-year term.
Thereafter, all members of the Commission shall serve three- year terms and
until his or her successor is appointed and qualified.
(Ord. 1675. Passed 7-9-18.)
292.03 ORGANIZATION; RULES OF PROCEDURE.
   (a)   The members of the Commission shall appoint a chairperson and vice-
chairperson to serve one -year terms. Elections shall be held during the
Commission's first meeting of the calendar year.
   (b)   The Commission shall meet in accordance with such schedule as the
Commission may designate from time to time.
   (c)   All meetings of the Commission shall be in accordance with the
requirements of the Illinois Open Meetings Act. Robert's Rules of Order shall
be used as a guide to the Commission in conducting its meetings.
(Ord. 1675. Passed 7-9-18.)

Illinois Vehicle Code

   Powers of local authorities - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 95-1/2, § 11-208
