422.03
426.01 VILLAGE VEHICLE LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   No person, firm or entity having its principal office or place of
business in the Village ("covered person"), shall use or cause or permit any of
his, her or its agents or employees to use any motor vehicle in the
transportation of persons or property upon the streets, avenues, bridges or
alleys of the Village unless a Village motor vehicle license, as evidenced by a
Village license decal or plate, has first been issued for such vehicle as
provided for in this Chapter. Vehicles owned by the Village are exempt from the
requirements of this Chapter.
   (b)   Individuals residing in the Village are exempt from the requirements
of this Chapter.
(Ord. 968. Passed 1-12-98; Ord. 1034. Passed 4-10-00; Ord. 1332. Passed 11-12-
07; Ord. 1404. Passed 3-9-09; Ord. 1513. Passed 2-27-12; Ord. 1552. Passed 6-
24-13; Ord. 1631. Passed 12-12-16; Ord. 1840. Passed 5-30-24.)
426.02 APPLICATION; ISSUANCE AND TRANSFER OF VEHICLE LICENSE.
   (a)   Generally. Any covered person shall make application to the Village
Clerk upon a form provided therefor, giving the name and address of the
applicant, a description of the vehicle for which the license is desired, the
place where such vehicle is kept when not in use, and such other information as
may be prescribed. Upon payment of the fee specified in Section
426.03 , the Clerk shall issue or cause to be issued a vehicle license decal or
metal plate, attested to by the Clerk, authorizing the use of such vehicle in
the Village until the expiration of such decal or plate.
   (b)   Vehicle Used for Charitable Purposes. Any person or nonprofit entity
that wishes to obtain a Village vehicle license decal or metal plate for a
motor vehicle that is primarily used in conducting the official activities of a
religious or charitable not-for-profit organization shall make application to
the Clerk upon a form provided for that purpose, setting forth the name and
address of the applicant, a description of the vehicle, proof of the vehicle's
having a current State CV license plate, the place where the vehicle is kept
when not is use, proof that the vehicle will be used for religious or
charitable purposes and that it is currently registered as a charitable vehicle
under Section 3-808 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, as amended, and such other
information as may be prescribed. Upon payment of the fee set forth in Section
426.03 , the Clerk shall issue or cause to be issued a vehicle license decal or
metal plate authorizing the use of such vehicle in the Village until the
expiration of such decal or plate.
(Ord. 1034. Passed 4-10-00; Ord. 1332. Passed 11-12-07; Ord. 1404. Passed 3-9-
09; Ord. 1513. Passed 2-27-12; Ord. 1552. Passed 6-24-13; Ord. 1631. Passed 12-
12-16; Ord. 1703. Passed 9-23-19; Ord. 1840. Passed 5-30-24.)
426.03 LICENSE FEES; EXPIRATION OF DECALS OR PLATES.
   (a)   The license fees to be paid to the Village under this chapter are as
follows:
 
Type of Vehicle                                          Fees
                                                         Full Year Half Year
(1) Motor vehicles, private passenger                    $50.00    $25.00
(2) Motor vehicles, two-wheel                            $41.25    $20.62
(3) Motor vehicles, truck (A and B State license plates) $56.00    $28.00
(4) Motor vehicles, truck (C or higher State license     $78.50    $39.25
    plates)
(5) Motorized recreational vehicles (RV State license    $50.50    $25.25
    plates)
 
   (b)   Expiration and Late Fees. All Village motor vehicles license decals or
plates expire on May 31 of each year. In addition to any penalty prescribed for
a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, and in addition to the
payment of the fees herein prescribed, any person, firm, or entity that fails
to obtain a required Village motor vehicle license decal or metal plate by May
31 of each year shall pay a late charge in the amount of twenty-five dollars
($25.00) before June 30 of each year, and fifty dollars ($50.00) after June 30
of each year, until such person purchases a Village license decal or plate as
provided herein. The maximum late charge to be paid in any fiscal year is fifty
dollars ($50.00). Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein,
there shall be a grace period of five business days following May 31 of each
year during which period no late charge shall be imposed upon the purchase of a
Village license decal or plate as provided herein.
   (c)   Vehicles Acquired After December 1. The license fee to be paid for a
vehicle purchased or lawfully acquired after December 1 in any current year
shall be one-half of the annual license fee provided in this section. An
applicant for a reduced fee license under this subsection, in addition to the
application provided in Section 426.02, furnish an affidavit, in a form
satisfactory to the Village Clerk or the Village Collector, stating that the
vehicle for which the decal or plate is applied for was purchased or otherwise
obtained by the applicant on or after December 1 of the current year. The
applicant shall also exhibit to the Clerk or Collector the bill of sale, or
other evidence of sale, for the vehicle.
   (d)   New Covered Persons Locating in the Village. All covered persons shall
obtain and display Village motor vehicle license decals or plates on their
motor vehicles within 30 days after the date on which they occupy their new
principal place of business in the Village. Covered persons who establish their
principal place of business in the Village after December 1 in any current year
shall be one-half of the annual license fee provided in this section.
(Ord. 968. Passed 1-12-98; Ord. 1142. Passed 5-28-03; Ord. 1332. Passed 11-12-
07; Ord. 1404. Passed 3-9-09; Ord. 1513. Passed 2-27-12; Ord. 1552. Passed 6-
24-13; Ord. 1631. Passed 12-12-16; Ord. 1703. Passed 9-23-19; Ord. 1777. Passed
4-11-22; Ord. 1840. Passed 5-30-24.)
426.04 SALE OF VEHICLE; TRANSFER OF LICENSE TO BUYER.
   (a)   Expiration of Sticker. Immediately upon the sale of any motor vehicle
licensed under this Chapter, the vendor shall remove the vehicle license or
plate from such vehicle. Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) hereof,
such license shall no longer be valid and shall cease to apply upon the sale of
such vehicle.
   (b)   Transfer to Buyer. A Village vehicle license decal or plate may be
transferred to the purchaser of such vehicle upon written application to the
Village Clerk within three business days after the sale of such vehicle, by the
purchaser of such vehicle, payment of a ten dollar ($10.00) transfer fee, and
surrender of the old decal or plate.
   (c)   Transfer to New Vehicle. Whenever the owner of a motor vehicle sells
or otherwise disposes of such vehicle before the expiration of a Village
vehicle license decal or plate issued for such vehicle, such license may be
transferred to a different motor vehicle of the same class upon written
application to the Village Clerk within three business days after the sale of
such vehicle, giving such information as the Clerk may require, the payment of
a ten dollar ($10.00) transfer fee and surrender of the old decal or plate.
(Ord. 968. Passed 1-12-98; Ord. 1332. Passed 11-12-07; Ord. 1404. Passed 3-9-
09; Ord. 1513. Passed 2-27-12; Ord. 1631. Passed 12-12-16; Ord. 1840. Passed 5-
30-24.)
426.05 DECALS AND PLATES TO BE AFFIXED TO VEHICLE.
   (a)   Specifications for License Decals and Plates. Upon completion of the
application for a Village vehicle license and payment of the required fee, the
Village Clerk shall deliver to the applicant a Village vehicle license decal or
plate in a shape and form to be determined from year to year, which decal shall
bear the words "Richton Park," a number identical to the number of the
registration, the name of the class of which such vehicle belongs and the year
or years for which such decal is effective.
   (b)   Display of Decal. Upon delivery of a motor vehicle license decal, the
applicant shall permanently affix it to the lower right front of the windshield
of such vehicle, where it can readily be seen. The current and prior year
Village decals or plates shall be the only ones displayed at any one time.
   (c)   License for Motorcycles. Upon the completion of the application for a
Village vehicle license and payment of the required fee for a motor-driven
cycle, motorized pedalcycle or motorcycle, the Clerk shall deliver to the
applicant a metal plate bearing the information provided for in subsection (a)
hereof. Upon delivery of a motor vehicle license metal plate, the applicant
shall affix such metal plate in a conspicuous position upon the right handlebar
of such vehicle, free from any obstruction to the view of such metal plate, so
that the plate can easily be seen by a police officer upon the approach of such
vehicle.
   (d)   Village Operation Without Vehicle License. It is unlawful for any
person to use, or to cause or permit any agent or employee to use, any vehicle
upon any street, avenue or alley of the Village, unless a Village motor vehicle
license decal or plate is affixed and displayed as provided for in this
section.
(Ord. 968. Passed 1-12-98; Ord. 1332. Passed 11-12-07; Ord. 1404. Passed 3-9-
09; Ord. 1513. Passed 2-27-12; Ord. 1631. Passed 12-12-16; Ord. 1840. Passed 5-
30-24.)
426.06 VEHICLE DEALERS' REGISTRATION.
   If a dealer in any of the motor vehicles mentioned in this chapter makes an
application to the Village Clerk and states therein under oath that he or she
is a dealer in the same with a salesroom in the Village, the President of the
Board of Trustees shall issue to such dealer, upon payment of the applicable
fee set forth in Section
426.03(a), a distinctive registration decal or metal plate. Under authority of
such decal or plate the dealer may test or demonstrate different successive
cars during the year.
(Ord. 968. Passed 1-12-98; Ord. 1332. Passed 11-12-07; Ord. 1404. Passed 3-9-
09; Ord. 1513. Passed 2-27-12; Ord. 1631. Passed 12-12-16; Ord. 1840. Passed 5-
30-24.)
426.07 UNLAWFUL REMOVAL, THEFT OR USE OF DECAL OR PLATE.
   (a)   No person shall take, remove or carry away a Village decal or metal
plate without the consent of the owner of the vehicle for which the same was
issued.
   (b)   No person shall use a decal or plate not specifically issued for the
vehicle as provided in this chapter.
(Ord. 968. Passed 1-12-98; Ord. 1332. Passed 11-12-07; Ord. 1404. Passed 3-9-
09; Ord. 1513. Passed 2-27-12; Ord. 1631. Passed 12-12-16; Ord. 1840. Passed 5-
30-24.)
426.08 VIOLATION NOTICE.
   A Village police officer may issue a notice to appear, summons, citation,
complaint or other written order or request to appear directed to a
specifically named person when he or she has reasonable grounds to believe that
the person is committing or has committed an offense under this chapter. An
officer may effect an entry into any property, driveway, parking lot or part
thereof to issue and serve such a complaint or other process.
(Ord. 968. Passed 1-12-98; Ord. 1332. Passed 11-12-07; Ord. 1404. Passed 3-9-
09; Ord. 1513. Passed 2-27-12; Ord. 1631. Passed 12-12-16; Ord. 1840. Passed 5-
30-24.)
426.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be
deemed committed each day on which a vehicle is used upon the streets, avenues
or alleys of the Village without a proper registration decal or metal plate or
without otherwise complying with the provisions of this chapter.
   (b)   Whoever violates Section
426.07 shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), for each offense.
(Ord. 968. Passed 1-12-98; Ord. 1332. Passed 11-12-07; Ord. 1404. Passed 3-9-
09; Ord. 1513. Passed 2-27-12; Ord. 1631. Passed 12-12-16; Ord. 1687. Passed 1-
14-19; Ord. 1840. Passed 5- 30-24.)

430.01 BLOCKING INTERSECTION OR CROSSWALK.
   Notwithstanding any traffic control signal to proceed, no driver of a
vehicle shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is
sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to
accommodate vehicles or pedestrians.
(1976 Code § 22-28; Ord. 490. Passed 12-13-76.)

   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be subject to the penalty provided in Section
202.99  of the Administration Code, for each offense.

CHAPTER 434
Commercial and Heavy Vehicles
434.01   Definitions of words and phrases
434.02   Authority to establish weight limits.
434.03   Overweight and/or over dimension vehicles.
434.04   Permits for overweight and/or over dimension vehicles.
434.05   Vehicles prohibited on certain streets.

Ch. 872
434.01 DEFINITIONS OF WORDS AND PHRASES.
   Definition of words and phrases shall mean the following words and phrases
when used in this Code shall, for the purpose of this Code, have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them in this Chapter, except when the context
otherwise requires and except where another definition set forth in another
section of this Code and applicable to that section or a designated part
thereof is applicable.
   (a)   "Axle load" shall mean the total load transmitted to the road by all
wheels whose centers may be included between two parallel transverse vertical
planes forty inches apart extending across the full width of the vehicle.
   (b)   "Commercial vehicle" shall mean any vehicle operated for the
transportation of persons or property in the furtherance of any commercial or
industrial enterprise, for-hire or not-for-hire, but not including a commuter
van, a vehicle used in a ride-sharing arrangement when being used for that
purpose, or a recreational vehicle not being used commercially.
   (c)   "Construction vehicle" shall mean any vehicle over ten thousand pounds
actual weight; registered gross weight or GVWR that is required to comply with
625 ILCS 5/ 12-712 and 12-713 on identification required to be displayed.
   (d)   "Gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR)" shall mean the value specified by
the manufacturer or manufacturers as the maximum, loaded weight of a single
vehicle. The GVWR, of a combination of vehicles (commonly referred to as the
"gross combination weight rating" or GCWR) is the GVWR of the power unit plus
the GVWR of the towed unit or units. In the absence of a value specified by the
manufacturer, GCWR is determined by adding the GVWR of the power unit and the
total weight of the towed unit and any load on the unit.
   (e)   "Gross weight" shall mean the weight of a vehicle whether operated
singly or in combination without load plus the weight of the load thereon.
   (f)   "Highway" shall mean the entire width between the boundary lines of
every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the
public for purposes of vehicular travel.
   (g)   "Implement of husbandry" shall mean every vehicle designed and adapted
exclusively for agricultural, horticultural, or livestock raising operations,
including farm wagons, wagon trailers or like vehicles used in connection
therewith, or for lifting or carrying an implement of husbandry.
   (h)   "Motor vehicle" shall mean every vehicle which is self-propelled and
every vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead
trolley wires, but not operated upon rails, except for vehicles moved solely by
human power and motorized wheelchairs. For this Chapter, motor vehicles are
divided into two divisions:
      (1)   First division: Those motor vehicles, which are designed for the
carrying of not more than ten persons.
      (2)   Second division: Those motor vehicles which are designed for
carrying more than ten persons, those motor vehicles designed or used for
living quarters, those motor vehicles which are designed for pulling or
carrying freight, cargo or implements of husbandry, and those motor vehicles of
the first division remodeled for use and used as motor vehicles of the second
division.
   (i)   "Permit route" shall mean the route authorized by the issuing
authority with proper jurisdiction over the roadway(s) for which permission has
been granted to move a vehicle or combination of vehicles that is in itself
indivisible or carrying an indivisible load that exceeds normal dimensions or
weight or a combination thereof.
   (j)   "Semitrailer" shall mean every vehicle without motive power, other
than a pole trailer, designed for carrying persons or property and for being
drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that some part of its weight and
that of its load rests upon or is carried by another vehicle.
   (k)   "Tandem axles" shall mean any two or more single axles whose centers
are more than forty inches and not more than ninety-six inches apart, measured
to the nearest inch between extreme axles in the series, except as provided in
625 ILCS 5/15-111 for special hauling vehicles.
   (l)   "Trailer" shall mean every vehicle without motive power in operation,
other than a pole trailer, designed for carrying persons or property and for
being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that no part of its weight
rests upon the towing vehicle.
   (m)   "Truck tractor" shall mean every motor vehicle designed and used
primarily for drawing other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry a load
other than a part of the weight of the vehicle and load so drawn.
   (n)   "Village" shall mean the Village of Richton Park.
(Ord. 1666. Passed 3-26-18.)
434.02 AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH WEIGHT LIMITS.
   (a)   The Chief of Police is hereby authorized, after consultation and upon
the advice of the Village Engineer or his or her representative, to establish
appropriate weight limitations for all vehicular traffic over and upon the
streets, roads, highways and thoroughfares in the Village.
   (b)   The Chief of Police shall cause to be promptly and properly displayed,
upon the streets, roads, highways and thoroughfares in the Village, appropriate
signs indicating the weight limitations for all vehicular traffic on such
streets, roads, highways and thoroughfares.
(Ord. 1666. Passed 3-26-18.)
434.03 OVERWEIGHT AND/OR OVER DIMENSION VEHICLES.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to be in control of, to drive, to
park, or move on, upon or across or for the owner to cause or knowingly permit
to be parked, driven, or moved upon or across, any street or highway under the
jurisdiction of the Village, any vehicle or combination of vehicles exceeding
the size and weight limitations stated in the 625 ILCS 5/15-102 (width), 5/15-
103 (height), 5/15-107 (length), and 5/15-111 (weight).
   (b)   Where lower size and weight limits or other restrictions are imposed
as provided in Section 434.02, as allowed under authority of 625 ILCS 5/15-111,
15-316 and 15-317, and signs indicating such limitations or restrictions are
posted, it shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle or combination of vehicles
in excess of such size or weight limitations or in violation of such
restrictions.
   (c)   Size and weights limitations while operating on Village streets shall
not apply to fire apparatus or equipment for snow or ice removal operations
owned or operated by or for any governmental body or to implements of husbandry
temporarily operated or towed in a combination in the furtherance of a farm or
agricultural endeavor or to garbage trucks, tow trucks, buses, private utility
trucks or to vehicles registered and used as recreational vehicles or to any
vehicle or combination of vehicles operating under the terms of a valid
oversize and/or dimension permit issued by the Village.
   (d)   Whenever any vehicle or combination of vehicles is operated in
violation of this Section, the owner and/or driver of such vehicle shall be
deemed guilty of such violation and either or both the owner and. driver of
such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation.
(Ord. 1666. Passed 3-26-18.)
434.04 PERMITS FOR OVERWEIGHT AND/OR OVER DIMENSION VEHICLES.
   (a)   A permit shall be required for the movement of any vehicle or
combination of vehicles with a non-divisible load on roadways and bridges
within the jurisdiction of the Village which exceeds the dimensions and weights
permitted for the particular roadways to be traversed whether they be non-
designated or designated roadways.
   (b)   The Village with respect to any street or highway under its
jurisdiction may upon application to the Richton Park Police Department on
forms provided by the Community and Economic Development department and good
cause being shown therefore issue a special permit authorizing the applicant to
operate or move a vehicle or combination of vehicles of a size or weight of
vehicle or load exceeding the maximum specified in Section
434.03 of this chapter. The applicant shall furnish the following information
in the special permit application:
      (1)   The name and address of the owner or lessee of the vehicle;
      (2)   Applicant's name;
      (3)   Type of permit request whether it be for a single trip, round trip,
or multiple routine;
      (4)   The description and registration (or the Illinois Department of
Transportation's (IDOT) registration number or classification) of the power
unit;
      (5)   Description of the object or vehicle to be moved;
      (6)   The number of axles of the vehicle or combination of vehicles;
      (7)   The maximum axle weights of all single, tandem or series axles;
      (8)   Maximum gross weight of the vehicle;
      (9)   The maximum width, length and height of the vehicle and load;
      (10)   Requested routing over Village streets to and from a specific
location.
   (c)   For purposes of this section, the following definitions apply:
      (1)   A one-way or single trip movement shall mean one move from the
point of origin to the point of destination. Any additional stops between the
point of origin and the point of destination are expressly prohibited. Single
trip permits are effective for seven consecutive days from the date of issuance
unless otherwise directed by the police department.
      (2)   Round trip movement shall mean two trips over the same route in
opposite directions. Round trip permits are effective for fourteen consecutive
days from the date of issuance.
      (3)   Multiple moves shall mean those in such close proximity to each
other in distance or in time that the police department would consider
incorporating two or more permit moves within one permit application. Multiple
move permits when granted by the police department shall be for a period time
not to exceed ninety days from the date of issuance.
   (d)   The owner or his or her agent shall submit an application fee based on
the below chart for a single routing which will be valid for seven calendar
days, round trip routing valid for fourteen calendar days and multiple routings
valid for a base period of three months. Permits maybe issued for a maximum of
four consecutive permit periods (three hundred sixty-five days) with the permit
fee calculated in the appropriate multiples of the base three-month multiple
trip permit. Permits are valid only for the date periods specified on the
permit and for the specific vehicle, load and routing as established by the
chief of police, or designee. No substitution of vehicle, load or routing is
permitted without expressed written permission by chief of police, or his or
her designee and the permit must be earned in the vehicle to which the permit
applies.
Permit size-weight Fee
(with load)        Single Trip Round Trip Multiple

   Note: If a vehicle requires a permit due to multiple weight and/or dimension
issues, the total fee will be based on the largest individual weight or
dimension factor only.
   (e)   The Chief of Police or designee is authorized to approve the
application for approved routes. Upon approval and payment of all required
fees, the Community and Economic Development department shall issue a permit
allowing passage of the oversize and/or overweight vehicles over Village
streets. The permit shall be specific and contain:
      (1)   Permit number;
      (2)   The dates the permit is valid;
      (3)   Whether the permit is for single, round or multiple trip routing;
      (4)   The description of object or vehicle to be moved;
      (5)   Authorized gross weight, axle weights, width, length and height;
      (6)   The authorized routing over Village streets including the origin
and termination point within the Village;
      (7)   The fee paid;
      (8)   The date and signature of the Chief of Police or his or her
designee;
      (9)   In addition, the permit will specify general conditions that the
permittee must comply with that are consistent and reasonable for the
protection of the general public and Village streets. A copy of all permits
issued will be provided to the chief of police or designee for informational
purposes.
   (f)   It is the duty of the permittee to read and familiarize himself or
herself with the permit provisions upon receipt. Undertaking of the permit move
is deemed prima facie evidence of acceptance of the permit and that:
      (1)   The permittee is in compliance with all operation requirements;
      (2)   All dimension and weight limitations specified in the permit will
not be exceeded;
      (3)   All operation, registration and license requirements have been
complied with;
      (4)   All financial responsibilities, obligations and other legal
requirements have been met; and
      (5)   The permit is only valid on weekdays during daylight, and not valid
on holidays.
      (6)   The permittee assumes all responsibility for injury or damage to
persons or to public or private property, including his or her own, or to the
object being transported, caused directly or indirectly by the transportation
or movement of vehicles and objects authorized under the permit. He or she
agrees to hold the Village harmless from all suits, claims, damages, or
proceedings of any kind and to indemnify the Village for any claim it may be
required to pay arising from the movement.
   (g)   The permit shall be carried in the vehicle to which the permit applies
at all times while operating on streets within the Village and shall be
exhibited upon demand to any law enforcement officer, police officer or
authorized official of the Village.
   (h)   Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of a
Village permit whether it be by size, weight or general provisions, and either
or both the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty and either
or both the owner or the driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such
violation.
(Ord. 1666. Passed 3-26-18.)
434.05 VEHICLES PROHIBITED ON CERTAIN STREETS.
   (a)   As provided under the authority of 625 ILCS 5/15-111 and 15-316, it
shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle upon any street where the operation of
that vehicle is prohibited by ordinance and where signs of such prohibition are
posted. Vehicles operating under the authority of 625 ILCS 5/15-111 or 15-316
while utilizing Village streets under "reasonable access" rules will be
considered in violation of this Section if they are not utilizing the most
direct route to points of loading and unloading.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful to park a commercial motor vehicle on a
residential street between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. the following
day.
(Ord. 1666. Passed 3-26-18.)
434.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter, for which no penalty is otherwise provided, shall be subject to the
penalty provided in §
202.99 of the Administration Code, for each offense.
(Ord. 1666. Passed 3-26-18; Ord. 1687. Passed 1-14-19.)

662.04(c)
438.01 PARKING ON RIGHT SIDE: EXCEPTION FOR ONE-WAY STREETS.
   (a)   No person shall park a vehicle against any curb in the Village with
the left side of the driver's side nearest the curb.
   (b)   Subsection (a) hereof applies to all roads, roadways and streets in
the Village with the exception of the roads designated by proper signs as one-
way streets.
(1976 Code § 22-24.1; Ord. 483. Passed 11-22-76.)
438.02 STREET PARKING PROHIBITED FOR LARGE OR NONMOTORIZED VEHICLES.
   (a)   Violations.
      (1)   No driver of a vehicle with a gross weight exceeding eight thousand
(8,000) pounds or a height exceeding nine (9) feet shall park such vehicle, or
permit such vehicle to be parked, on any street in the Village.
      (2)   No person shall park a nonmotorized vehicle, or permit a
nonmotorized vehicle to be parked, on any street in the Village.
   (b)   Penalties. Any person found to have violated the provisions of
subsections (a)(1) or (2), shall be fined the following:
      (1)   Two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first violation
      (2)   Five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the second violation
      (3)   Seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00) for any further
violations.
   (c)   Towing. Any vehicle found in violation of this subsection (c) or more
times may be towed without a pre-towing hearing. The owner of the vehicle will
be responsible for the payment of all costs associated with towing.
(Ord. 459. Passed 3-8-76; 1976 Code § 22-24.2; Ord. 1700. Passed 9-9-19.)
438.03 PARKING AT ALLEYS AND DRIVEWAYS.
   (a)   As used in this section, "alley" means a public thoroughfare which
affords only secondary means of access to abutting property.
   (b)   No operator of a vehicle shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in the
following places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or
in compliance with the directions of a police officer or official traffic sign
or signal:
      (1)   At any place where the standing of a vehicle will block the use of
a driveway; or
      (2)   In an alley. However, a vehicle making a local delivery to the
owner of property abutting an alley may park in such alley for not longer than
thirty minutes.
438.04 UNAUTHORIZED USE OF PARKING SPACES RESERVED FOR PERSONS WITH
DISABILITIES.
   (a)   Definitions. As used in this section, “authorized holder” means an
individual issued a disability license plate under Section 3-616 of the
Illinois Vehicle Code, an individual issued a parking decal or device under
Section 11-1301.2 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, or an individual issued a
disabled veteran’s license plate under Section 3-609 of the Illinois Vehicle
Code.
   (b)   Proper Usage of Disability License Plates/Parking Decals or Devices.
      (1)   When using the parking privileges for persons with disabilities,
the parking decal or device must be displayed properly in the vehicle where it
is clearly visible to law enforcement personnel, either hanging from the
rearview mirror or placed on the dashboard of the vehicle in clear view.
      (2)   Proper usage of the disability license plate or parking decal or
device requires the authorized holder to be present and enter or exit the
vehicle at the time the parking privileges are being used.
      (3)   Any motor vehicle properly displaying a disability license plate or
a parking decal or device containing the International symbol of access issued
to persons with disabilities by any local authority, state, district, territory
or foreign country shall be recognized by the Village as a valid license plate
or device and receive the same parking privileges as residents of the Village.
      (4)   Disability license plates and parking decals and devices are not
transferable from person to person.
   (c)   Parking Violations.
      (1)   It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle which is not
properly displaying registration plates or decals issued to a person with
disabilities, as defined in Section 1-159.1, pursuant to Sections 3-616, 11-
1301.1 or 11-1301.2, or to a disabled veteran pursuant to Section 3-609 of the
Illinois Vehicle Code, as evidence that the vehicle is operated by or for a
person with disabilities or a disabled veteran, in any parking space, including
any private or public offstreet parking facility, specifically reserved by the
posting of an official sign as designated under Section 11-301 of the Illinois
Vehicle Code, for motor vehicles displaying such registration plates.
      (2)   It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle in a designated
access aisle adjacent to any parking place specifically reserved for persons
with disabilities, by the posting of an official sign as designated under
Section 11-301 of the Illinois Vehicle Code for motor vehicles displaying such
registration plates.
      (3)   It shall be unlawful to park in a space reserved for a person with
disabilities if the authorized holder of the disability license plate or
parking decal or device does not enter or exit the vehicle at the time the
parking privileges are being used.
   (d)   Usage Violations.
      (1)   It shall be unlawful if an individual with a vehicle displaying
disability license plates or a parking decal or a device issued to a qualified
person with a disability or a disabled veteran if: (i) the person using the
disability license plate or parking decal or device is not the authorized
holder of the disability plate or parking decal or device or is not
transporting the authorized holder to or from the parking location; and (ii)
the person uses the disability license plate or parking decal or device to
exercise any privileges granted through the disability license plate or parking
decal or device under the Illinois Vehicle Code.
      (2)   It shall be unlawful if a driver of a vehicle displaying disability
license plates or a parking decal or device issued to a qualified person with a
disability or to a disabled veteran: (i) the person to whom the disability
license plate or parking decal or device was issued is deceased; and (ii) the
driver uses the disability license plate or parking decal or device to exercise
any privileges granted through a disability license plate or parking decal or
device under the Illinois Vehicle Code.
   (e)   Towing. Any vehicle parked within a public stall or space or private
offstreet parking facility reserved for use by a person with disabilities which
does not display person with disabilities registration plates or a special
decal or device may be towed after notifying the Village Police Department
without a pre-towing hearing.
   (f)   Signage. All signs erected and used to designate the reservation of
parking facilities for a person with disabilities shall be in a form and manner
described under Section 11-301 of the Illinois vehicle Code, and shall exhibit
the words “$250 Fine”. If the fine amount is at any time changed by the State
or Village, the signs shall be changed to indicate the current amount of the
fine. All parking spaces for a person with disabilities, except those reserving
on-street parking areas, shall be at least 16 feet wide.
   (g)   Penalties.
      (1)   Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of subsections
(c)(1), (2), or (3) shall be fined $250.00 in addition to any costs or charges
connected with the removal or storage of any motor vehicle authorized to be
towed under this Section. It is not a defense to a charge of violating
subsections (c)(1), (2) or (3) that the sign posted pursuant to this Section or
the intended accessible parking place does not comply with the technical
requirements of Section 11-301 of the Illinois Vehicle Code or this Section if
a reasonable person would be made aware by the sign or notice on or near the
parking space that the place is reserved for a person with disabilities.
      (2)   Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of subsection
(d)(1) shall be fined $600.00 for the first violation and $1,000.00 for a
second and subsequent violations. Additionally, such person may have his or her
driving privileges suspended or revoked by the Illinois Secretary of State for
a period of time determined by the Secretary of State.
      (3)   Any person found guilty of violation the provisions of subsection
(d)(2) is guilty of a Class A misdemeanor and shall be fined $2,500.00.
Additionally, such person shall have his or her driving privileges revoked by
the Illinois Secretary of State. The Secretary of State may also suspend or
revoke the disability license plates or parking decal or device for a period of
time determined by the Secretary of State.
      (4)   A Village police officer may seize the parking decal or device from
any person who commits a violation of this Section. A Village police officer
may seize the disability license plate upon authorization from the Illinois
Secretary of State. The Police Department may request that the Secretary of
State revoke the parking decal or device or the disability license plate of any
person who commits a violation of this Section.
      (5)   Every day a violation of this Section shall occur shall be deemed a
separate offense.
(1976 Code § 22-25.1; Ord. 536. Passed 6-11-79; Ord. 1576. Passed 7-28-14.)
438.05 PARKING PROHIBITED OR LIMITED AS POSTED.
   (a)   No operator of a vehicle shall park such vehicle on a street when such
parking has been prohibited by order of the Police Department and a sign has
been erected which indicates that parking is prohibited at designated hours or
at all times.
   (b)   No operator of a vehicle shall park such vehicle on a street, where a
sign has been erected by order of the Police Department prohibiting such
parking for a longer time than that indicated on such sign.
(1976 Code § 22-26; Ord. 490. Passed 12-13-76.)
438.06 PARKING IN AND UNAUTHORIZED USE OF LOADING ZONES.
   (a)   No curb loading zone authorized and established as a passenger loading
zone shall be used as a commercial loading zone, and no commercial loading zone
shall be used as a passenger loading zone, except as may otherwise be specified
by ordinance.
   (b)   No operator of a vehicle shall stop, stand or park such vehicle in any
place marked as a loading zone other than for the expeditious loading and
unloading of passengers, and then for not longer than three minutes, or for the
unloading and delivery or pick-up and loading of materials. In no case shall
such a stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed thirty minutes.
(1976 Code § 22-27; Ord. 490. Passed 12-13-76.)
438.07 DOUBLE PARKING.
   (a)   Prohibited Places. No person shall double park or double stop a
vehicle under the following conditions:
      (1)   Within fifty feet of any intersection except an alley intersection,
or within ten feet of an alley intersection;
      (2)   Opposite a double-parked or double-stopped vehicle across the
street;
      (3)   When such double parking or double stopping would or does block or
interfere materially with the normal movement of traffic;
      (4)   When a parking space adjacent to the curb is available; or
      (5)   When directed by a police officer to move on.
   (b)   To Load or Unload Passengers. Vehicles not used ordinarily for the
transportation of merchandise may double stop for the purpose of, but only
while actually engaged in, the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers,
subject, however, to the conditions set forth in subsection (a) hereof.
   (c)   To Load or Unload Merchandise. Vehicles used ordinarily for
transportation of merchandise may double park for the purpose of, but only
while engaged in, the expeditious loading or unloading of merchandise, subject,
however, to the conditions set forth in subsection (a) hereof. No such vehicle
shall be double parked longer than ten minutes.
(1976 Code § 22-29; Ord. 490. Passed 12-13-76.)
438.08 PARKING VEHICLES FOR SALE OR REPAIR.
   No person shall park a vehicle on any street or Municipally owned property
for the principal purpose of:
   (a)   Displaying such vehicle for sale; or
   (b)   Greasing or repairing such vehicle, except when repairs are
necessitated by an emergency.
(1976 Code § 22-30; Ord. 490. Passed 12-13-76.)
438.09 OBSTRUCTION OF TRAFFIC.
   No person shall park a vehicle on a street, other than an alley, in such
manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the
width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic.
(1976 Code § 22-31; Ord. 490. Passed 12-13-76.)
438.10 RIGHT OF WAY AT PARALLEL PARKING SPACES.
   (a)   Parallel Parking Required. Only parallel parking shall be permitted in
all residential zoning districts within the corporate limits of the Village.
   (b)   Spaces Being Vacated. The driver of a vehicle who intends such vehicle
to occupy a parallel parking space where a backing movement is necessary, and
which is being vacated by another vehicle, shall stop his or her vehicle to the
rear of the space until the vacating vehicle has cleared and entered normal
traffic. The driver then shall be deemed to have the right-of-way to such
parking space over any other vehicle attempting to park therein.
   (c)   Unoccupied Spaces. The first of two or more vehicles to reach the rear
boundary of an unoccupied parallel parking space, where a backing movement is
necessary to occupy such space, shall be deemed to have the right-of-way to
such parking space.
(1976 Code § 22-32; Ord. 490. Passed 12-13-76; Ord. 1052. Passed 9-11-00.)
438.11 LIGHTS ON PARKED VEHICLES.
   A motor vehicle which is parked upon a street or highway outside a business
or residential district between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour
before sunrise shall be equipped with one or more lamps which shall exhibit a
white light on the roadway side visible from a distance of 500 feet to the
front of the vehicle and a red light visible from a distance of 500 feet to the
rear.
(1976 Code § 22-33; Ord. 490. Passed 12-13-76.)
438.12 PARKING AND STOPPING BUSES AND TAXICABS.
   (a)   Loading Zones. The Chief of Police is hereby authorized to establish
passenger loading zones on such public streets, in such places and in such
number as he or she determines to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to
the public. Every such loading zone shall be designated by appropriate signs.
   (b)   Buses to Stand or Park Only at Bus Stands. The operator of a bus shall
not stand or park such bus on a street at any place other than a bus stand so
designated as mentioned in subsection (f) hereof.
   (c)   Buses to Stop Only at Designated Places. The operator of a bus shall
not stop such bus upon a street at any place, for the purpose of loading or
unloading passengers or their baggage, other than at a bus stop, bus stand or
passenger loading zone, except in case of an emergency.
   (d)   Buses to Pull to Curb When Loading. The operator of a bus shall enter
a bus stop, bus stand or passenger loading zone on a public street in such a
manner that the bus, when stopped to load or unload passengers or baggage, is
in a position with the right front wheel thereof not further than eighteen
inches from the curb and the bus approximately parallel to the curb so as not
to unduly impede the movement of other vehicular traffic.
   (e)   Taxicabs to Stand or Park Only at Taxicab Stands; Exceptions. The
operator of a taxicab shall not stand or park such taxicab on a street at any
place other than in a taxicab stand. This provision shall not prevent the
operator of a taxicab from temporarily stopping in accordance with other
stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of, and while
actually engaged in, the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers.
   (f)   Use of Bus and Taxicab Stands Restricted. No person shall stop, stand
or park a vehicle, other than bus, in a bus stop or stand, or stop, stand or
park a vehicle, other than a taxicab, in a taxicab stand, when any such stop or
stand has been officially designated and the appropriate signs are in place.
The driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop in a bus stop or stand
or a taxicab stand for the purpose of, and while actually engaged in, loading
or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or
taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter the zone.
(1976 Code § 22-34; Ord. 490. Passed 12-13-76.)
438.13 SNOW EMERGENCIES.
   (a)   No person shall park a motor vehicle on a City street after a snowfall
of two inches or more until such time as the removal of the snow from the
streets has been completed.
   (b)   The Chief of Police is hereby directed to place or have placed
appropriate signs notifying residents of the Village of the ban imposed by
subsection (a) hereof.
(Res. R-79-5. Passed 3-12-79.)
438.14 VEHICLE IMMOBILIZATION PROGRAM.
   (a)   Implementation of Program. The Chief of Police is hereby authorized to
direct and supervise a program of vehicle immobilization as provided in this
section. The program of vehicle immobilization shall provide for the
immobilization of any eligible vehicle upon a public way by placement of a
restraint in such a manner as to prevent its operation, or if the eligible
vehicle is parked or left in violation of any provision of this chapter or
other applicable chapters concerning obstruction of traffic, access to or
egress from driveways, alleys, fire lanes, hydrants or stations, or in any
place where it constitutes an obstruction or a hazard, or where it impedes
workers during such operations as snow removal, the Chief of Police may cause
the eligible vehicle to be towed to a vehicle pound or be relocated to a legal
parking place and there restrained.
   (b)   Immobilization List; Accumulated Citations. A vehicle shall be
eligible for immobilization as provided herein anytime after inclusion of its
State registration number on an immobilization list. A vehicle State
registration number shall be included on an immobilization list only if:
      (1)   The registered owner of the vehicle has accumulated five or more
parking citations in the Village on which no payment has been made or
appearance filed within the time specified by the citations;
      (2)   At least twenty-one days prior to placing the registration plate
number of the vehicle on the immobilization eligibility list, notice of
impending vehicle immobilization has been sent to the registered owner, first
class mail, postage pre-paid, at the address of the registered owner recorded
with the Secretary of State or, in the case of a vehicle bearing a registration
number of a State other than Illinois, at the address of the registered owner
recorded in that state's registry of motor vehicles.
   (c)   Notice Requirements. The notice required in subsection (b) hereof
shall state the name and address of the registered owner, the state
registration number of the vehicle, the nature of the ordinances violated and
the numbers and issue dates of the outstanding citations. The notice shall also
advise that a person may challenge the validity of notice of impending vehicle
immobilization by appearing in person and submitting evidence which would
conclusively disprove liability, such as the following:
      (1)   That the person was not the owner or lessee of the vehicle on the
date or dates the citations were issued;
      (2)   That the fines or penalties for the violations cited in the report
were paid; or
      (3)   That the registered owner has not accumulated five or more parking
citations which were unpaid, or not adjudicated, or for which no appearance has
been filed.
   (d)   Notice of Liability for Damage to Restraint.
      (1)   Upon immobilization of an eligible vehicle, a notice shall be
affixed to the vehicle in a conspicuous place. Such notice shall warn that the
vehicle is immobilized and that any attempt to move the vehicle may result in
its damage.
      (2)   The notice shall also state that the unauthorized removal of or
damage to the immobilizing restraint is a violation of 720 ILCS 5/16-1 and 5/
21. The notice shall also provide information specifying how release of the
immobilizing restraint may be had and how the registered owner may obtain an
immobilization hearing pursuant to this section.
   (e)   Towing and Impoundment. Except where the vehicle is otherwise subject
to towing, if the immobilizing restraint has not been released within seventy-
two hours of its placement, the restraint shall be released and the vehicle
towed and impounded. Within ten days after a vehicle has been impounded, a
notice of impoundment shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt
requested, to the registered owner of the vehicle at the address to which the
notice was mailed. The notice shall state that the owner has the right to a
post-immobilization and post-towing hearing, and that if the car is not claimed
within thirty days from the date of the notice, the vehicle may be sold or
otherwise disposed of in accordance with this chapter.
   (f)   Hearings. The owner of an immobilized vehicle shall have the right to
a hearing to determine whether the immobilization or any subsequent towing was
erroneous or whether the vehicle was property included on an immobilization
list, if the owner files a written demand for a hearing with the Village within
fourteen days after issuance of the notice specified in subsection (e) hereof
or within fourteen days of the immobilization, whichever is later. A hearing
shall be conducted within forty-eight hours of receipt of a written demand for
the same unless otherwise mutually agreed to by the parties. Failure to request
or attend a scheduled hearing shall be deemed a waiver of the right to a
hearing. In the event of such failure, any amount deposited pursuant to
subsection (g) hereof shall be forfeited. A hearing provided by this section
shall not determine the validity of or otherwise adjudicate any citation or
notice of parking violation issued relative to the immobilized vehicle.
   (g)   Release of an Immobilized Vehicle. Prior to a hearing on the validity
of the immobilization, as provided in subsection (f) hereof, the owner of an
immobilized vehicle or other authorized person shall be permitted to secure
release of the vehicle by:
      (1)   Paying the immobilization, towing and storage fees, if applicable;
and
      (2)   Paying all the fines and penalties, if any, on the outstanding
complaints specified in the notice of impending vehicle immobilization, or
arranging for the payment as approved by the Chief of Police.
   The fee for immobilization shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). The fee
for towing subsequent to immobilization shall be two hundred and fifty dollars
($250.00). The storage fee shall be set by the towing company at an amount not
to exceed what is allowed by state law. However, no fees shall be assessed for
any immobilization or tow which has been determined to be erroneous.
   (h)   Unauthorized Removal of Immobilization Device. No person shall
relocate or tow any vehicle restrained by an immobilizing device without the
approval of the Chief of Police or his designee.
   (i)   Suspension of Driving Privileges. Pursuant to the provisions of 625
ILCS 5/6- 306.5, the Secretary of State shall be provided a certified report
indicating that:
      (1)   The registered owner or lessee of the vehicle has accumulated ten
or more parking citations in the Village on which no payment has been made or
appearance filed within the time specified by the citations and therefore
requesting suspension of the registered owner's or lessee's driving privileges.
      (2)   Any person whose license is suspended pursuant to this section and
State statute may challenge the accuracy of the certified report submitted to
the Secretary of State by the Village. The challenge shall be heard by an
individual to be designated by the Village President. The grounds for the
challenge shall be limited to the following issues:
         A.   Whether the person was the owner or lessee of the vehicle or
vehicles receiving ten or more parking violation notices on the date or dates
such notices were issued; and
         B.   Whether the person has already paid the fine or penalty for the
ten or more violations indicated on the certified report.
(Ord. 825. Passed 7-25-94; Ord. 1700. Passed 9-9-19.)
438.15 PARKING ON UNPAVED SURFACES; EXCEPTIONS.
   (a)   No person shall park on an unpaved portion of any village street,
parkway or other right-of-way unless the area is in a residential zoning
district, is an uncurbed street, and also is a surface which by improvement has
become compacted to a degree that continued parking will not cause any further
damage to the public property (“exempt area”).
   (b)   No person shall place any gravel, concrete or otherwise alter any
Village parkway or other unpaved right-of-way area without a permit issued by
the Village. Any such improvements shall be constructed according to Village
specifications.
   (c)   The Police Chief and Public Works Director shall compile a list by
address of those properties where a surface thereon qualifies the property to
be considered an exempt area as of May 1, 2002. Upon approval of the
recommended list by the Board of Trustees, said list of properties with exempt
areas shall be on file at the office of the Village Clerk and the Police
Department and shall be available for public inspection. No exempt area shall
be expanded.
(Ord. 1103. Passed 4-8-02.)
438.16 RESIDENTIAL PARKING FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES.
   (a)   Generally. Upon the recommendation of the Village Manager, the Village
Board may authorize the erection of signs to prohibit parking except by
vehicles displaying a person with a disability registration plate or other
disability parking decal or identifier as allowed by the Illinois Motor Vehicle
Code. Only residents living in single-family homes shall be eligible for such
authorization.
   (b)   Application; Required Information. Any party seeking a revocable
permit for a restricted parking space shall complete an application form as
provided by the Village. The application shall be made to the Village Manager
and shall be accompanied by an application fee of $100.00.
   (c)   The application shall include, but shall not be limited to the
following information:
      (1)   That the applicant holds a valid, current permanent person with a
disability license plate, parking decal, or device issued pursuant to the
Illinois Motor Vehicle Code;
      (2)   That any vehicle that will be parked by or for the applicant in the
restricted parking space bears license plates issued to the applicant; and
      (3)   That the applicant resides at the primary residence that is
accessible to the parking space for which application is made.
   (d)   Recommendation and Determination. The application shall be reviewed by
the Village Police and Public Works Departments. Each Department shall make its
recommendation based on relevant factors, including but not limited to the
following:
      (1)   Whether there is available alternative accessible off-street
parking at the applicant’s primary residence;
      (2)   Whether there are particular circumstances resulting in an
applicant’s off- street parking to be less than fully accessible;
      (3)   The number of restricted parking spaces currently installed on the
particular residential street;
      (4)   The proximity of the requested restricted parking space to
crosswalks, curb cuts, alleys, intersections, and fire hydrants; and
      (5)   Such other information concerning the applicant’s needs and local
traffic restrictions as the Village Manager may require.
   (e)   Notification of Change of Status. The applicant shall promptly notify
the Village as to any change in status of the person for whose benefit the
license has been issued, including, but not limited to death or change in
medical status.
   (f)   Approval; Renewal. Upon recommendation of the Village Manager, the
Village Board may approve a recommendation for a restricted parking space. The
applicant shall promptly notify the Village of any change in the primary
residence of the applicant. The permit is subject to annual renewal upon the
payment of a fee of $35.00.
   (g)   Permit Revocable. The permit may be revoked by the Village Board at
any time at the discretion of the Village Board.
(Ord. 1848. Passed 11-11-24.)
438.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter, for which no penalty is otherwise provided, shall be subject to the
penalty provided in §
202.99 of the Administration Code, for each offense.
(Ord. 1687. Passed 1-14-19.)
CHAPTER 442
Off-Street Parking

Ch. 858
442.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall hav ethe
meanings respectively ascribed to them by this chapter:
   (a)   "Park" or "Parking" means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied
or not, other than when temporarily and actually engaged in the loading or
unloading of merchandise or passengers.
   (b)   "Parking lot area" means:
      (1)   The designated area owned, operated or controlled by the Village
pursuant to any agreements entered into with property owners, the terms of
which are established in accordance with Sections 11-209 and 11-209.1 of the
Ill. Rev. Stats.
      (2)   Designated areas in a fee or private parking lot established under
Chapter 858;
      (3)   Designated areas within the Village commuter parking lot; or
      (4)   Any other strip parking areas designated and controlled by the
Village.
   (c)   "Parking space" has the same meaning as is set forth in the Village
Zoning Ordinance, as amended.
   (d)   "Vehicle" means any device in, upon or by which any person or property
is or may be transported upon a street or highway, except those operated upon
rails or tracks. "Vehicle" includes, but is not limited to, motor vehicles,
motor carriers, motorcycles, motor-driven cycles, motorized pedalcycles,
bicycles, trucks and other vehicle types as defined in Chapter 95 ½ of the
Illinois Vehicle Code.
(Ord. 628. Passed 9-12-83; Ord. 1405. Passed 3-9-09.)
442.02 PUBLIC PARKING LOTS AND AREAS.
   (a)   Parking, Boarding, Discharging Passengers. No vehicle shall enter upon
a public or private parking lot within the Village except for the purpose of
parking, boarding or discharging of passengers and provided that such entry or
parking is directly related to the functions or services of the public or
private agencies furnishing such public parking lot when appropriate signs are
posted.
   (b)   Entrance and Exit. No vehicle shall enter upon or exit from a public
parking lot except at places specified for entry or exit.
   (c)   Speed Limit. The maximum rate of speed at which a vehicle may be
operated upon a public parking lot shall be such slow speed as is reasonable
and proper considering existing traffic conditions and the safety of others.
   (d)   Designated Spaces. No vehicle shall be parked in a public parking lot
except within designated parking spaces.
   (e)   Restricted Parking. No vehicle shall be parked in a public parking lot
where signs or markings prohibit or restrict such parking.
   (f)   Unauthorized Use of Parking Places Reserved for Handicapped Persons.
      (1)   It shall be prohibited to park any vehicle which is not bearing
registration plates or decals issued to a physically handicapped person
(pursuant to Section 3-616 or 11-1301.2 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, as
amended) or to a disabled veteran (pursuant to Section 3-609 of such Code, as
amended), as evidence that the vehicle is operated by or for a handicapped
person or disabled veteran, in any parking place, including any private or
public off-street parking facility specifically reserved, by the posting of an
official above-grade sign, for motor vehicles bearing such plates.
      (2)   Any person or local authority owning or operating a public or
private off-street parking facility may, after notifying the Police or
Sheriff’s Department, remove or cause to be removed, to the nearest garage or
other place of safety, any vehicle parked in a stall or space reserved for use
by the physically handicapped, which vehicle does not display handicapped
registration plates or decals as required in paragraph (f)(1) hereof.
   (g)   Towing of Vehicles. The Chief of Police of any other police officer
may cause to be towed away and stored any vehicle parked in violation of this
chapter in conformance with the Village ordinance regarding towing and towing
procedures. The costs of towing and storage shall be borne by the owner of the
vehicle or the driver of the vehicle who caused the violation.
   (h)   Selling, Hawking, Soliciting. No vendor of goods, wares, merchandise
or services shall use a public parking lot or any portion thereof for the
conduct of such business or for display purposes unless properly licensed in
accordance with other established ordinances.
   (i)   Traffic Control Signs. Vehicles shall be operated in conformance with
all traffic control devices or signs properly posted or placed.
   (j)   Keys, etc. in Parked or Unattended Motor Vehicle. No person shall park
or leave unattended a motor vehicle:
      (1)   Which contains keys capable of starting such vehicle;
      (2)   Which is running but from which the keys have been removed; or
      (3)   Which is capable of being started without an ignition key.
(Ord. 628. Passed 9-12-83; Ord. 1405. Passed 3-9-09.)
442.03 PARKING IN METERED SPACES.
   (a)   Use of Parking Spaces. It shall be unlawful and an offense for any
person to back an automobile or other motor vehicle into any parking space
serviced by a parking meter or to park a vehicle in any metered vertical or
angular parking space in such a manner that the rear wheels of such vehicle are
closer to the meter than the front wheels of such vehicle.
   (b)   Vehicles parked at a metered parking space shall be parked wholly
within the space designated and marked off.
   (c)   Deposit of Coin. When any vehicle is parked within a parking meter
zone, the driver of such vehicle shall, immediately upon entering the parking
space, deposit a United States coin in the amount posted, in the parking meter
alongside of or next to such parking space, and the parking space may then be
used by such vehicle during the parking time limit as prescribed for such
parking space.
   (d)   Overtime Parking. If a vehicle is parked in a parking space, at a
parking meter area within the Village, beyond the parking limits established by
the Village for such parking space, such vehicle shall be considered as parked
overtime and beyond the time established by the Village. The parking of a
vehicle overtime or beyond the period of time established by the Village in any
such metered parking space shall be a violation of this section.
   (e)   Removal from Hourly Parking Space. Any vehicle parked in a metered
parking space in excess of twenty-four consecutive hours may be removed by the
Police Department at the expense of the owner of the vehicle or the driver in
violation of this section.
   (f)   Parking in Handicapped Metered Zones. If any vehicle is parked in any
metered parking space designated as a handicapped parking area without
displaying a handicapped license plate or permit issued pursuant to the
registration system of the Secretary of State of Illinois or a political
subdivision issuing identification to persons meeting the definition of a
physically handicapped person, as defined by the Illinois Vehicle Code, whether
parked otherwise legally or not, will be considered illegally parked and
subject to immediate removal at the expense of the owner or the driver in
violation of this section.
(Ord. 628. Passed 9-12-83; Ord. 1405. Passed 3-9-09.)
442.04 FEE PARKING LOTS.
   (a)   Daily Fee. Persons parking a vehicle in a fee parking lot shall pay
the daily fee as required.
   (b)   Payment and Method of. Such parking fee shall be inserted in the coin
receptacle provided at the authorized exit, or shall be paid to the attendant,
as the case may be.
   (c)   Operation, Tampering, Damaging Devices. It shall be unlawful to
attempt to operate, tamper with or damage the devices installed to regulate
entrance to or exit from a fee parking lot, except in accordance with posted
instructions.
(Ord. 628. Passed 9-12-83; Ord. 1405. Passed 3-9-09.)
442.05 COMMUTER PARKING LOT.
   (a)   Description. The Village of Richton Park has acquired parcels of
property for the purpose of establishing a Village Commuter Parking Lot in the
area described as follows:
   Governor's Highway bordering on the west; Sauk Trail bordering on the south;
Illinois Central Gulf Railroad bordering on the east; and Lioncrest Towers
bordering on the north in Richton Park, Illinois.
   (b)   Manner of Parking, and Use by Passenger and Commercial Vehicles. It
shall be unlawful for any driver to park any vehicle in the Village commuter
parking lot in violation of this section, or to so park in a manner that the
rear wheels of such vehicle are closer to the front of the designated parking
space than the front wheels, or otherwise park contrary to the rules
established by the Village Board for the use of such parking facilities; and
the parking of a commercial passenger or freight-carrying vehicle or trailer in
the Village commuter parking lot shall be prohibited unless authorized by
permit.
   (c)   Tampering, Damaging of Devices. It shall be unlawful to attempt to
operate, tamper with, or damage the devices installed to regulate entrance to
or exit from the commuter parking lot, except in accordance with posted
instructions.
   (d)   Fees. No person shall park without paying the indicated fee
established by the Board of Trustees. Effective May 1, 2020, the daily parking
fee shall be $2.00.
      (1)   Persons parking a vehicle in the Village commuter parking lot shall
pay the requisite fee. The parking fee shall be inserted in the coin receptacle
provided at the authorized exit.
      (2)   Residents may pay for commuter parking passes over the internet for
a five dollar ($5.00) service charge.
   (e)   Parking Permits. No person shall park a vehicle in a designated
monthly or quarterly lot without having paid the applicable monthly or
quarterly fees established below and displaying the current hanging permit
issued and required by the Village verifying the receipt of such payment.
 
Monthly Lots       Quarterly Lots
Effective:  Fee:   Effective:  Fee:
May 1, 2020 $35.00 May 1, 2020 $90.00
 
   (f)   Display of Current Parking Decal. Vehicles shall not park in a
designated monthly, quarterly or daily lot without having paid the appropriate
fees and displaying the current decal issued and required by the Village
verifying the receipt of payment prior to parking such vehicle.
   (g)   Placement of Parking Decal. Persons shall display a valid parking
decal issued by the Village in the lower right rear window of the vehicle. Only
decals for the current and immediately prior validation periods shall be
displayed at any one time.
   (h)   Designated Parking Space. It shall be unlawful to park in any
designated area in any public parking without paying the indicated fee
established by the Village Board.
(Ord. 628. Passed 9-12-83; Ord. 1405. Passed 3-9-09; Ord. 1719. Passed 4-27-
20.)
442.06 SUPERVISION.
   The Chief of Police shall establish such rules or orders as may be necessary
to carry out the enforcement of this chapter.
(Ord. 628. Passed 9-12-83; Ord. 1405. Passed 3-9-09.)
442.99 PENALTY.
   The penalties prescribed for violations of any provision contained in this
chapter shall be the same penalties as prescribed in Section
214.03 of this Code.
(Ord. 1405. Passed 3-9-09.)
CHAPTER 446

446.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Crossing at other than crosswalk - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 95 1/2, § 11-1003
   Drivers exercising due care to avoid confused, incapacitated or intoxicated
pedestrians - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 95 1/2, § 11-1003.1
   Pedestrians walking on highways - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 95 1/2, § 11-1007
   Pedestrians to yield to authorized emergency vehicles - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 95
