Section
814.49, the grantor reserves the right to impose the following remedies if the
grantee violates or fails to comply with any other material provision of the
franchise, provided that the grantee has not commenced corrective action within
thirty days of written notice, by certified mail, to the general manager of the
grantee:
      (1)   The grantor may impose a financial penalty, not to exceed one
thousand dollars ($1,000) per day or per incident, for the grantee's individual
willful and/or repeated violation of any provision of the franchise or the
failure to take corrective action with respect to such a violation.
      (2)   The grantor may require the grantee to make rate rebates or
payments to the customers or classes of customers in such amount and on such
basis as the grantor may deem reasonable.
      (3)   The grantor may require the grantee to correct or otherwise remedy
the violation prior to any rate increase becoming effective.
   (b)   If the stated violation or noncompliance is not reasonably curable
within sixty days of the date of the written notice provided for in subsection
(a) hereof, the franchise will not be terminated or revoked, and a remedy will
not be imposed pursuant to Section
814.35 or this section, if the grantee provides, within the sixty days, a plan,
satisfactory to the grantor, to remedy the violation and continues to
demonstrate good faith in seeking to correct the violation.
   (c)   In determining which remedies for the grantee's violation are
appropriate, the grantor shall take into consideration the nature of the
violation, the person bearing the impact of the violation, the nature of the
remedy required in order to prevent further such violations and such other
matters as the grantor may deem appropriate. However, adequate penalties must
be imposed if service is in any way materially lessened or if any material
provision of the franchise is not complied with.
   (d)   Within ten days after receipt of the written notice provided for in
subsection (a) hereof, the grantee may request a hearing before an impartial
hearing officer or commission in a full public proceeding affording due
process. Such hearing shall be held within thirty days of the receipt of the
request therefor.
   (e)   Any appeal from the determination of the hearing officer or the Cable
Television Commission shall, within thirty days of the issuance of such
determination, be made to the Board of Trustees.
   (f)   The grantor and the grantee acknowledge that damages at law are an
inadequate remedy for violations of the franchise and agree that either party
may obtain injunctive relief to enforce the provisions of the franchise.
(Ord 593. Passed 7-12-82.)
814.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 815
Cannabis Business Establishments
EDITOR’S NOTE: Chapter 815 was repealed by Ordinance 1759, passed September 13,
2021
CHAPTER 816
Cigarette Dealers
816.01   Definitions.
816.02   Licenses.
816.03   Sanitary condition of premises.
816.04   Adulteration of cigarettes.
816.05   Vending machine or self- service display unlawful.
816.06   Sales to minors. (Repealed)
816.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Health, safety and sanitation - see GEN. OFF.
Ch. 634
   Sales of cigarettes and tobacco to minors - see GEN. OFF.
650.05
   Commercial establishments and licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 802
   Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 882
816.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Cigarette" includes any smokers' article commonly known as a
cigarette.
   (b)   "Cigarette papers" includes any small papers used for the making of
cigarettes.
   (c)   "Cigarette wrappers" includes all wrappers which are or can be used
for the wrapping or making of cigarettes.
   (d)   "Self-service displays" means open displays of tobacco or cigarette
products and point of sale tobacco or cigarette promotional products that the
public has access to without the intervention of a store employee.
(1976 Code § 6-19; Ord. 1112. Passed 8-26-02.)
816.02 LICENSES.
   (a)   Required. No person shall sell cigarettes, cigars, cigarette papers or
wrappers, or tobacco in any form, at retail without first having obtained a
license therefor.
(Ord. 168. Passed 6-15-55; 1976 Code § 6-20.)
   (b)   Applications. An application for such license shall set forth the full
name of the applicant and the location at which such sales are proposed to be
made.
(Ord. 168. Passed 6-15-55; 1976 Code § 6-21.)
   (c)   Issuance. The President of the Board of Trustees, at his or her
discretion, shall cause the Village Clerk to issue a license to such applicant.
(Adopting Ordinance)
   (d)   Fee; Term. The fee for the license is as set forth in Section
802.09 (b)(4). No such license shall be issued for less than a one-year period,
such period to commence May 1 and end April 30 of the following year.
(Ord. 168. Passed 6-15-55; 1976 Code § 6-23.)
816.03 SANITARY CONDITION OF PREMISES.
   The premises or building used for the purpose of the retail sale of
cigarettes, cigars or any other form of tobacco must be kept in a clean and
sanitary condition.
816.04 ADULTERATION OF CIGARETTES.
   No person shall expose for sale, sell or offer for sale, or give to or
exchange with any person directly or indirectly, in the Village, any cigarette,
cigar or other form of tobacco which has been adulterated in any way.
816.05 VENDING MACHINE OR SELF-SERVICE DISPLAY UNLAWFUL.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or maintain a vending machine
or self- service display for the sale or dispensing of tobacco or cigarette
products. All cigarette and tobacco products must be displayed from behind a
sales/service counter so that no consumer can access cigarette or tobacco
products without assistance by an employee of the licensee.
(Ord. 1112. Passed 8-26-02.)
816.06 SALES TO MINORS. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 816.06 was repealed by implication by Ordinance 847-
A, passed February 27, 1995. See Section
650.05 of the General Offenses Code.)
816.99 PENALTY.
   The sale of cigarettes or tobacco products in violation of this chapter is
hereby declared a public nuisance. The Village Manager may, in addition to
other remedies provided for in the Code, recommend that the Village Attorney
seek injunctive relief.
(Ord. 1112. Passed 8-26-02; Ord. 1687. Passed 1-14-19.)
CHAPTER 818
Secondhand Dealers
818.01   Definitions.
818.02   License required.
818.03   Hours of operation.
818.04   License application.
818.05   Prohibited purchases.
818.06   Recordkeeping.
818.07   Report to police.
818.08   Disassembling, smelting and destruction of secondhand goods.
818.09   Removal of identifying marks prohibited.
818.10   Transfer of license.
818.11   Exemptions.
818.99   Penalty.
818.01   DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this section, the following terms shall have the following
meanings:
   (1)   "Audio-video equipment" includes, but is not limited to, any stereo,
speaker, radio, video recorder, video camera, television, tape or disk player,
telephone or satellite signal device.
   (2)   "Precious metal" means gold, silver, platinum or palladium or any
other precious metal that is suitable for use in jewelry and that is not gold,
silver, platinum or palladium.
   (3)   "Precious stone or gem" means any genuine diamond, emerald, ruby,
sapphire or pearl, and any other precious or semi-precious gem, jewel or stone
that is suitable for use in jewelry and that is not a diamond, emerald, ruby,
sapphire or pearl.
   (4)   "Secondhand dealer" means any person who engages in the business of
purchasing, selling, receiving, trading, consignment selling, or otherwise
transferring for value any secondhand property.
   (5)   "Secondhand property" means any previously owned audio-video
equipment, camera, computer equipment, GPS device, watch, precious metal,
precious stone or gem, jewelry made of precious metal or made of precious stone
or gem, bicycles and sporting or athletic gear or equipment. Secondhand
property does not include audio-video equipment, cameras or computer equipment
that are accepted for recycling at a commercial recycling center without any
transfer for value.
(Ord. 1522. Passed 5-14-12.)
818.02   LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate as a secondhand dealer or engage in the business of
keeping or conducting a store for the purpose of buying, selling or otherwise
transferring for value secondhand property, without first having obtained a
license therefore from the Village on a form prepared by the Village. Persons
who are currently engaged in the business of keeping or conducting a store for
the purpose of buying, selling or otherwise transferring for value secondhand
property in the Village as of the effective date of this chapter, and who have
a current business license from the Village, shall be required to obtain a
license from the Village and fully comply with the requirements of this chapter
by January 1, 2013.
(Ord. 1522. Passed 5-14-12.)
818.03   HOURS OF OPERATION.
   No secondhand dealer shall receive in the conduct of his or her business any
secondhand property, goods, articles or things from any person between the
hours of 7:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m.
(Ord. 1522. Passed 5-14-12.)
818.04   LICENSE APPLICATION.
   (a)   An application for the license required by Section
818.02 shall be made in conformity with the general license application
requirements of
Chapter 802. The applicant shall specify the location of the building,
structure, premises, enclosure or other place where he or she proposes to
conduct the business of secondhand dealer. If his or her business will include
smelting precious metals, the application shall also identify the facilities
and ventilation equipment to be utilized for such smelting operations.
   (b)   Every such application shall be approved by the Chief of Police, and
by the Fire Chief if precious metal smelting will be conducted on the licensed
premises, before the license is issued.
(Ord. 1522. Passed 5-14-12.)
818.05   PROHIBITED PURCHASES.
   (a)   No secondhand dealer shall purchase any article of secondhand property
from a minor except with the written consent of the minor's parent or guardian,
which consent must be signed in the presence of the secondhand dealer. The
written consent shall be included in the record required under Section 818.06
of this chapter.
   (b)   No secondhand dealer shall keep, maintain or conduct a place for the
purchase, reception or storage of stolen goods or any article of secondhand
property from any person known to be a thief or to have been convicted of theft
or burglary. If any article of property purchased by a secondhand dealer is
determined to be stolen and the rightful owner has been identified, then the
article property shall be returned to the rightful owner without charge.
   (c)   No secondhand dealer shall purchase any article of secondhand property
from any person who appears intoxicated or under the influence of any drug.
(Ord. 1522. Passed 5-14-12.)
818.06   RECORDKEEPING.
   Every secondhand dealer shall maintain a record of all transactions
involving articles of secondhand property, which record shall be legibly typed
or printed in ink in the English language and shall contain the following
items;
   (a)   A description of each person selling or desiring to sell an article of
secondhand property, including the person's fall name, address of residence,
date of birth, height, weight and gender.
   (b)   The secondhand dealer shall require each person desiring to sell an
article of secondhand property to produce one (1) form of state or federal
government issued identification, including either a driver's license or state
identification, provided that the form of identification includes a color
photograph of the seller. The secondhand dealer shall make and record a
photocopy or electronic scan of such identification.
   (c)   A description of each article of secondhand property including the
brand name, the model number (if applicable) and a description of all
identifying markings.
   (d)   If the article of secondhand property is precious metal or jewelry,
the description must also include the type of jewelry, the precious metal or
metals of the jewelry's composition, the type, cut and shape of each precious
stone or gem, and a description of all inscriptions. The description must be
accompanied by a color photograph of the article of jewelry.
   (e)   Every secondhand dealer shall keep the records required by this
section for three (3) years after the date of each transaction.
(Ord. 1522. Passed 5-14-12.)
818.07   REPORT TO POLICE.
   (a)   Every secondhand dealer shall prepare and deliver to a location or
locations designated by the Chief of Police each Monday, or the following
Tuesday if the Monday falls on a holiday, before the hour of 12:00 noon, a
legible and correct copy of the records required in Section
818.06 of all secondhand property purchased by the dealer during the preceding
week.
   (b)   The photographs required under Section
818.06 shall not be included in the records delivered to the Chief of Police,
but must remain available for inspection and duplication by the Richton Park
Police Department.
   (c)   The records required under Section
818.06, as well as all articles of secondhand property currently in the
possession of the secondhand dealer, must be open for inspection by any member
of the Richton Park Police Department at all times during the secondhand
dealer's business hours.
(Ord. 1522. Passed 5-14-12.)
818.08   DISASSEMBLING, SMELTING AND DESTRUCTION OF SECONDHAND GOODS.
   No secondhand dealer shall sell, dispose of, smelt, disassemble, destroy or
remove from the place of business any article of secondhand property until he
or she has kept such article intact and available for inspection in his or her
licensed place of business for ten (10) calendar days. Notwithstanding this
requirement, no secondhand dealer shall take apart, smelt, destroy, deface or
remodel any article of secondhand property until he or she has documented his
or her intent to do so in the records required under Section
818.06.
(Ord. 1522. Passed 5-14-12.)
818.09   REMOVAL OF IDENTIFYING MARKS PROHIBITED.
   No secondhand dealer shall remove, alter or obliterate any manufacturer's
make, model or serial number, personal identification number, or identifying
marks engraved or etched upon an article of secondhand property that was
purchased by the secondhand dealer; provided, however, that a secondhand dealer
may smelt precious metal after he or she has kept such article intact and
available for inspection in his or her licensed place of business for ten (10)
calendar days. Notwithstanding this requirement, no secondhand dealer shall
smelt any precious metal until he or she has documented his or her intent to do
so in the records required under Section
818.06.
(Ord. 1522. Passed 5-14-12.)
818.10   TRANSFER OF LICENSE.
   No license granted under this chapter shall be assigned or transferred to
any person other than the licensee named in the license to do business or act
under the license.
(Ord. 1522. Passed 5-14-12.)
818.11   EXEMPTIONS.
   The provisions of this
Chapter 818 do not apply to the following:
   (a)   Agencies or instrumentalities of the State of Illinois or of the
United States, to units of local government, or their agents or
representatives.
   (b)   Not-for-profit organizations that receive secondhand property for
charitable purposes in which the individual receives no compensation.
   (c)   Auctions of secondhand property conducted by a licensed auctioneer.
(Ord. 1522. Passed 5-14-12.)
818.99   PENALTY.
   Business license violations may be settled and compromised as provided in
Section
214.03 of the Administration Code.
(Ord. 1522. Passed 5-14-12.)
CHAPTER 828
Filling Stations
828.01   Defined.
828.02   License required.
828.03   License applications.
828.04   Construction without neighbors' consent prohibited.
828.05   License fee.
828.06   Location.
828.07   Change of location of business.
828.08   Compliance with fire regulations; annual inspections.
828.09   Transfer of license.
828.10   Storage of flammable liquids.
828.11   Smoking near pumps.
828.12   Construction of lockers.
828.13   Waste disposal.
828.14   Exceptions to chapter.
828.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Commercial establishments and licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 802
   Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 882
   Storage of flammable liquids - see F.P. 1616.05(c), (d)
   Dangerous buildings as fire hazards - see F.P.
1614.06
828.01 DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "filling station" means any building, structure,
premises, enclosure or other place in the Village where a container or tank,
either portable or stationary, containing flammable liquids is kept or located
for the purpose of selling, offering for sale or distributing such liquids from
such container or tank.
(Ord. 154. Passed 1-11-55; 1976 Code § 6-29.)
828.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in the business of operating a filling station in the
Village without first obtaining a license therefor.
(Ord. 154. Passed 1-11-55; 1976 Code § 6-30.)
828.03 LICENSE APPLICATIONS.
   (a)   An application for the license required by Section
828.02 shall be made in conformity with the general license application
requirements of
Chapter 802. The applicant shall specify the location of the building,
structure, premises, enclosure or other place where he or she proposes to
operate the filling station and the capacity in gallons of every container or
tank installed or to be installed upon the premises.
   (b)   Every such application shall be approved by the Chief of Police and
the Fire Chief before the license is issued.
(Ord. 154. Passed 1-11-55; 1976 Code § 6-31.)
828.04 CONSTRUCTION WITHOUT NEIGHBORS' CONSENT PROHIBITED.
   No gasoline or oil filling station or public garage shall be constructed on
any street, avenue or other public highway in the Village without the written
consent of property owners of a majority of the property within 200 feet of
such proposed gasoline or oil filling station or public garage, excluding any
street or alley.
(1976 Code § 6-32.)
828.05 LICENSE FEE.
   The annual fee for the license required by Section
828.02 shall be as stated in Section
802.09(b)(7).
(Ord. 621. Passed 5-23-83.)
828.06 LOCATION.
   No tank, container, pipe or other equipment for the storage and handling of
flammable liquids shall be installed within 200 feet of the nearest boundary of
any lot or plot of ground used for a school, hospital, church or theater.
(Ord. 154. Passed 1-11-55; 1976 Code § 6-34.)
828.07 CHANGE OF LOCATION OF BUSINESS.
   (a)   If any person who is licensed to engage in the business of a filling
station wishes, before the expiration of such license, to change the location
of the business engaged in under such license, the licensee shall notify the
Village Clerk and shall furnish all of the information which is required to be
furnished on an original application for such a license.
   (b)   Every application for a change of location shall be approved by the
Chief of Police and the Fire Chief before a change in location is authorized.
(Ord. 154. Passed 1-11-55; 1976 Code § 6-35.)
828.08 COMPLIANCE WITH FIRE REGULATIONS; ANNUAL INSPECTIONS.
   All filling stations shall be conducted and maintained in accordance with
the provisions of this chapter and other ordinances with regard to fire
prevention and the storage of inflammable liquids. Such stations shall be
inspected by the Fire Chief or his or her duly authorized representative at
least once every year.
(1976 Code § 6-36.)
828.09 TRANSFER OF LICENSE.
   No license granted under this chapter shall be assigned or transferred to
any person other than the licensee named in the license to do business or act
under the license.
(1976 Code § 6-37.)
828.10 STORAGE OF FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS.
   Except as otherwise permitted by law, flammable liquids shall be stored
outside of buildings.
(1976 Code § 6-38.)
828.11 SMOKING NEAR PUMPS.
   No person shall permit smoking in the immediate vicinity of a gasoline pump.
(Ord. 154. Passed 1-11-55; 1976 Code § 6-39.)
828.12 CONSTRUCTION OF LOCKERS.
   Lockers for clothing of workmen at a filling station shall be constructed of
metal.
(Ord. 154. Passed 1-11-55; 1976 Code § 6-40.)
828.13 WASTE DISPOSAL.
   Waste oil or other flammable liquids shall be stored in metal containers on
the premises of a filling station pending removal therefrom. No such waste
shall be permitted to drain into any sewer or storm water drainage system. Rags
and soiled waste shall be kept in metal containers.
(Ord. 154. Passed 1-11-55; 1976 Code § 6-41.)
828.14 EXCEPTIONS TO CHAPTER.
   This chapter does not apply to any place where flammable liquids are kept or
sold for medicinal purposes only.
(Ord. 154. Passed 1-11-55; 1976 Code § 6-42.)
828.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
(Ord. 1687. Passed 1-14-19.)
CHAPTER 830
Food Dealers
   EDITOR'S NOTE: Chapter 830 was repealed by implication by Ordinance 791,
passed August 23, 1993. See
Chapter 831.
CHAPTER 831
Food Service Establishments
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The Village provides periodically by resolution for an
agreement with Cook County for the provision of environmental health inspection
services relating to food service sanitation and retail food store sanitation.
Copies of the latest relevant legislation may be obtained, at cost, at the
Village Hall.
831.01   Application of chapter and other laws.
831.02   Retail food establishment defined.
831.03   Operation; permit, license or certificate required; transfers;
posting.
831.04   Issuance of permit, license or certificate; inspections.
831.05   Suspension of permit, license or certificate.
831.06   Revocation of permit, license or certificate.
831.07   Service of notices.
831.08   Hearings.
831.09   Application after revocation.
831.10   Frequency of inspection.
831.11   Right of entry.
831.12   Report of inspections.
831.13   Correction of violations.
831.14   Inspection report form.
831.15   Examination and condemnation of food.
831.16   Construction and remodeling; submission of plans.
831.17   Pre-operational inspection.
831.18   Procedure when infection is suspected.

   Health Facilities Authority - see ADM.

   Health, safety and sanitation - see GEN. OFF.
Ch. 634
   Commercial establishments and licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 802
   Alcoholic liquor sales - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 806
   Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 882
831.01 APPLICATION OF CHAPTER AND OTHER LAWS.
   (a)   This chapter shall regulate the issuance, suspension and revocation of
permits, licenses and certificates to operate retail food establishments and
the sale of unsound or mislabeled food or drink. The inspection of food service
establishments shall be regulated in accordance with the 1991 edition and all
subsequent editions and amendments of the Illinois Department of Public
Health's publication currently titled Food Service Sanitation Rules and
Regulations, on file with the Secretary of State. The inspection of retail food
stores shall be regulated in accordance with the 1992 edition and all
subsequent editions and amendments of the Illinois Department of Public
Health's publication currently titled Retail Food Store Sanitation Rules and
Regulations, on file with the Secretary of State.
   (b)   Three copies of each of the Illinois Department of Public Health's
publications referred to in subsection (a) hereof shall be on file in the
Village Clerk's office.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.02 RETAIL FOOD ESTABLISHMENT DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, the term "retail food establishment" means either a
food service establishment or a retail food store.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.03 OPERATION; PERMIT, LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE REQUIRED; TRANSFERS; POSTING.
   No person shall operate a retail food establishment who does not have a
valid permit, license or certificate issued to him or her by the Village. Only
a person who complies with the requirements of this chapter shall be entitled
to receive or retain such a permit, license or certificate. Permits, licenses
and certificates are not transferable. A valid permit, license or certificate
shall be posted in every food establishment.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.04 ISSUANCE OF PERMIT, LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE; INSPECTIONS.
   (a)   Any person desiring to operate a retail food establishment shall make
written application for a permit, license or certificate on forms provided by
the Village. Such application shall include the name and address of each
applicant, the location and type of the proposed food establishment and the
signature of each applicant.
   (b)   Prior to approval of an application for a permit, license or
certificate, the Village and the Cook County Department of Public Health shall
inspect the proposed food establishment to determine compliance with the
requirements of this chapter.
   (c)   The Village shall issue a permit, license or certificate to the
applicant if its inspection reveals that the proposed food establishment
complies with the requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.05 SUSPENSION OF PERMIT, LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE.
   (a)   The Village may, without warning, notice or hearing, suspend any
permit, license or certificate to operate a food establishment if the holder of
the permit, license or certificate does not comply with the requirements of
this chapter, or if the operation of the food establishment otherwise
constitutes a substantial hazard to public health. Suspension is effective upon
service of the notice required by Section
831.06. When a permit, license or certificate is suspended, the holder of the
permit, license or certificate shall be afforded an opportunity for a hearing
within twenty days of receipt of a request for a hearing.
   (b)   Whenever a permit, license or certificate is suspended, the holder of
the permit, license or certificate, or the person in charge, shall be notified
in writing that the permit, license or certificate is, upon service of the
notice, immediately suspended and that an opportunity for a hearing will be
provided if a written request for a hearing is filed with the Village by the
holder of the permit, license or certificate within ten days. If no written
request for a hearing is filed within ten days, the suspension is sustained.
The Village may end the suspension at any time if reasons for suspension no
longer exist.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.06 REVOCATION OF PERMIT, LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE.
   (a)   The Village may, after providing an opportunity for a hearing, revoke
the permit, license or certificate for serious or repeated violations of any of
the requirements of this chapter or for interference with the Village or the
Cook County Department of Public Health in the performance of duty.
   (b)   Prior to revocation, the Village shall notify, in writing, the holder
of the permit, license or certificate, or the person in charge, of the specific
reason(s) for which the permit, license or certificate is to be revoked and
that the permit, license or certificate shall be revoked at the end of ten days
following service of such notice unless a written request for a hearing is
filed with the Village by the holder of the permit, license or certificate
within such ten-day period. If no request for a hearing is filed within the
ten-day period, the revocation of the permit, license or certificate becomes
final.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.07 SERVICE OF NOTICES.
   A notice provided for in this chapter is properly served when it is
delivered to the holder of the permit, license or certificate, or the person in
charge, or when it is sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt
requested, to the last known address of the holder of the permit, license or
certificate. A copy of the notice shall be filed in the records of the Village.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.08 HEARINGS.
   The hearings provided for in this chapter shall be conducted by the Village
at a time and place designated by it. Any oral testimony given at a hearing
shall be reported verbatim, and the presiding officer shall make provision for
sufficient copies of the transcript. The Village shall make a final finding
based upon the complete hearing record and shall sustain, modify or rescind any
notice or order considered in the hearing. A written report of the hearing
decision shall be furnished to the holder of the permit, license or certificate
by the Village.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.09 APPLICATION AFTER REVOCATION.
   Whenever a revocation of a permit, license or certificate has become final,
the holder of the revoked permit, license or certificate may make written
application for a new permit, license or certificate.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.10 FREQUENCY OF INSPECTION.
   An inspection of a food establishment shall be performed at least once every
six months. Additional inspections of the food establishment shall be performed
as often as necessary for the enforcement of this chapter.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.11 RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   Duly authorized representatives of the Village or the Cook County Department
of Public Health, after proper identification, shall be permitted to enter any
food establishment at any reasonable time for the purpose of making inspections
to determine compliance with this chapter. The representatives shall be
permitted to examine the records of the establishment to obtain information
pertaining to food and supplies purchased, received or used.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.12 REPORT OF INSPECTIONS.
   Whenever an inspection of a food establishment or commissary is made, the
findings shall be recorded on the inspection report form referred to in Section
831.14. The inspection report form shall summarize the requirements of this
chapter and shall set forth a weighted point value for each requirement.
Inspectional remarks should be written to reference, by item number, the item
violated, and should state the correction to be made. The rating score of the
establishment shall be the total of the weighted point values for all
violations, subtracted from 100. A copy of the completed inspection report form
shall be furnished to the person in charge of the establishment at the
conclusion of the inspection. The completed inspection report form is a public
document that shall be made available to any person who requests it according
to law.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.13 CORRECTION OF VIOLATIONS.
   (a)   The completed inspection report form shall specify a reasonable period
of time for the correction of the violations found, and correction of the
violations shall be accomplished within the period specified, in accordance
with the following provisions:
      (1)   If an imminent health hazard exists, such as complete lack of
refrigeration or sewage backup into the establishment, the establishment shall
immediately cease food operations. Operations shall not be resumed until
authorized by the Cook County Department of Public Health.
      (2)   All violations of four or five-point weighted items shall be
corrected as soon as possible, but in any event within ten days following
inspection. A follow-up inspection shall be conducted to confirm correction at
the discretion of the Cook County Department of Public Health.
      (3)   All one or two-point weighted items shall be corrected as soon as
possible, but in any event by the time of the next routine inspection.
      (4)   When the rating score of the establishment is less than sixty, the
establishment shall initiate corrective action on all identified violations
within forty-eight hours. One or more reinspections will be conducted at
reasonable time intervals to assure correction.
      (5)   In the case of temporary food establishments, all violations shall
be corrected within twenty-four hours. If violations are not corrected within
twenty-four hours, the establishment shall immediately cease food operations
until authorized to resume by the Cook County Department of Public Health.
   (b)   The inspection report shall state that failure to comply with any time
limits for corrections may result in cessation of food operations. An
opportunity for a hearing on the inspection findings or the time limits, or
both, will be provided if a written request is filed with the Village within
ten days following cessation of operations. If a request for a hearing is
received, a hearing shall be held within twenty days of receipt of the request.
   (c)   Whenever a food establishment is required under the provisions of this
chapter to cease operations, it shall not resume operations until it is shown
on reinspection that conditions responsible for the order to cease operations
no longer exist. Opportunity for reinspection shall be offered within a
reasonable time.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.14 INSPECTION REPORT FORM.
   (A copy of the inspection report form referred to in this chapter is
attached to original Ordinance 791, passed August 23, 1993.)
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.15 EXAMINATION AND CONDEMNATION OF FOOD.
   Food may be examined or sampled by the Cook County Department of Public
Health as often as necessary for enforcement of this chapter. The Cook County
Department of Public Health may, upon written notice to the owner or person in
charge, specifying with particularity the reasons therefor, place a hold order
on any food which it believes is in violation of Section 750.100, 750.110,
760.100 or 760.110 of the Illinois Department of Public Health's publications
currently titled Food Service Sanitation Rules and Regulations and Retail Food
Store Sanitation Rules and Regulations, respectively, or any other provision of
this chapter. The Cook County Department of Public Health shall tag, label or
otherwise identify any food subject to a hold order. No food subject to a hold
order shall be used, served or moved from the establishment. The Cook County
Department of Public Health shall permit storage of the food under conditions
specified in the hold order, unless storage is not possible without risk to the
public health, in which case immediate destruction shall be ordered and
accomplished. The hold order shall state that a request for a hearing may be
filed within ten days and that if no hearing is requested the food shall be
destroyed. If a request for a hearing is received, the hearing shall be held
within twenty days after receipt of the request. On the basis of evidence
produced at that hearing, the hold order may be vacated, or the owner or person
in charge of the food may be directed by written order to denature or destroy
such food or to bring it into compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.16 CONSTRUCTION AND REMODELING; SUBMISSION OF PLANS.
   Whenever a food establishment is constructed or extensively remodeled, and
whenever an existing structure is converted to use as a food establishment,
properly prepared plans and specifications for such construction, remodeling or
conversion shall be submitted to the Village and the Cook County Department of
Public Health for review and approval before construction, remodeling or
conversion is begun. The plans and specifications shall indicate the proposed
layout, arrangement, mechanical plans and construction materials of work areas
and the types and models of proposed fixed equipment and facilities. The
Village and the Cook County Department of Public Health shall approve the plans
and specifications if they meet the requirements of this chapter. No food
establishment shall be constructed, extensively remodeled or converted except
in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the Village and the
Cook County Department of Public Health.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.17 PRE-OPERATIONAL INSPECTION.
   Whenever plans and specifications are required by Section
831.16 to be submitted to the Village and the Cook County Department of Public
Health, the Village and the Cook County Department of Public Health shall
inspect the food establishment prior to the start of operations, to determine
compliance with the approved plans and specifications and with the requirements
of this chapter.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.18 PROCEDURE WHEN INFECTION IS SUSPECTED.
   When the Cook County Department of Public Health has reasonable cause to
suspect possible disease transmission by an employee of a food establishment,
it may secure a morbidity history of the suspected employee or make any other
investigations as indicated and shall take appropriate action. The Cook County
Department of Public Health may require any or all of the following measures:
   (a)   The immediate exclusion of the employee from employment in food
establishments;
   (b)   The immediate closing of the food establishment concerned until, in
the opinion of the Cook County Department of Public Health, no further danger
of disease outbreak exists;
   (c)   Restriction of the employee's services to some area of the
establishment where there would be no danger of transmitting disease;
   (d)   Adequate medical and laboratory examination of the employee and of
other employees and of his and their body discharges.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.19 REINSPECTION COSTS.
   In the event a re-inspection is deemed necessary by the inspector, the cost
of any and all subsequent re-inspections shall be borne by the holder of the
license.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.20 CONDITIONAL LICENSE OR PERMIT.
   When structural, plumbing, electrical or ventilation defects, or similar
defects, exist in an established food facility that may require significant
expenditures to correct, but are not considered to be imminent health hazards,
a conditional license or permit may be granted at the discretion of the health
authority. Under no circumstances will a conditional license or permit be
issued for more than two consecutive twelve-month periods. The purpose of the
conditional license or permit is to allow a reasonable period of time for
correction of existing defects.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.21 INJUNCTIONS.
   The Village shall have the right to enjoin any person or establishment in
the event violations of this chapter occur on a continuing basis.
(Ord. 791. Passed 8-23-93.)
831.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 832
Foreign Fire Insurance Companies
832.01   Compliance required; liability.
832.02   Payments to Village.
832.03   Annual report to Village.
832.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Foreign Fire Insurance Board - see ADM.
Ch. 288
   BOCA National Fire Prevention Code - see F.P.
Ch. 1610
   Fire control - see F.P.
Ch. 1612
   Fire inspections and hazards - see F.P.
Ch. 1614
832.01 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED; LIABILITY.
   (a)   No company, corporation or association, not incorporated under the
laws of the State, shall engage in effecting fire insurance, or transact any
business of fire insurance, in the Village, which company, corporation or
association has failed to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter,
without fully complying with such provisions.
   (b)   Subsection (a) hereof shall not relieve any such company, corporation
or association from the payment of any risk that may be undertaken in violation
of this chapter.
(Ord. 357. Passed 5-11-71; 1976 Code § 6-54.)
   (c)   No insurance agent in the Village shall have any insurance business or
dealings with any company, association or corporation, not incorporated under
the laws of the State, which has not reported or made payments, as provided in
this chapter, until it has complied with all the requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. 357. Passed 5-11-71; 1976 Code § 6-58.)
832.02 PAYMENTS TO VILLAGE.
   (a)   Any fire insurance corporation, company or association, not
incorporated under the laws of the State, which is engaged in the Village in
effecting fire insurance, shall pay the Village Treasurer, for the maintenance,
use and benefit of the Fire Department, a sum of money equal to two percent of
the gross receipts as premiums upon fire insurance policies by any and all
agents of such corporation, company or association, during the year ending on
July 1 in each year, for any insurance effected or agreed to be effected, on
property located in the Village by or with such corporation, company or
association during the year.
(Ord. 357. Passed 5-11-71; 1976 Code § 6-55.)
   (b)   The sum of money for which the foreign fire insurance company,
corporation or association is chargeable may be recovered from it or its agent
by an action for money had and received in the name of and for the use of the
Village.
   (c)   Nothing in this section shall be held to exempt any person from
indictment and conviction under the provisions of an act entitled "An Act to
Enable Cities, Towns, and Villages, Organized under any Federal or Special Law,
to Levy and Collect a Tax or License Fee from Foreign Insurance Companies for
the Benefit of Organized Fire Departments" (in force July 1, 1895), as amended.
(Ord. 357. Passed 5-11-71; 1976 Code § 6-56.)
832.03 ANNUAL REPORT TO VILLAGE.
   (a)   Each person acting in the Village as an agent for or on behalf of a
corporation, company or association regulated under this chapter shall, on or
before July 15 of each year, render to the Village Clerk a full, true and just
account, verified by his or her oath, of all premiums upon fire insurance
policies which, during the year ending on July 1 preceding such report, have
been received by him or her, or by another person for him or her on behalf of
such corporation, company or association on property located in the Village.
   (b)   At the time of rendering the report, the agent shall also pay to the
Village Treasurer the sum of money for which the company, corporation or
association represented by him or her is chargeable under Section
832.02.
(Ord. 357. Passed 5-11-71; 1976 Code § 6-57.)
832.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 845
Under-Aged Entertainment Businesses and Services

   CROSS REFERENCES
   Codified ordinances - see ADM.

Ch. 806
845.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings ascribed to them by this section:
   (a)   "Exemptions." Events or programs operated by or within the following
shall not be considered to be an under-age establishment for purposes of this
chapter:
      (1)   Not-for-profit or charitable groups or organizations;
      (2)   Houses of religious worship;
      (3)   Units of state or local government;
      (4)   The Village Park and Recreation Department;
      (5)   Sports stadiums, and facilities whose principal activities are in
the nature of athletic entertainment (such as skating facilities, pools and the
like);
      (6)   Schools licensed by the State of Illinois;
      (7)   Movie houses and performing arts theaters;
   (b)   "Licensee" means the owner and/or operator of an under-age
establishment.
   (c)   "Person" means any individual, partnership, firm, association, limited
liability company, joint stock company, corporation or combination of
individuals of whatever form or character.
   (d)   "Under-Age Establishment" means a commercial establishment, club,
cabaret, roadhouse, or other similar place of business which, either on a
regular basis or on occasion, is open for business after dusk and before dawn,
and which offers live or recorded music and dancing, either alone or in
conjunction with the sale of food and non-alcoholic beverages for the
entertainment of its patrons, and which invites or permits the patronage of
under-age persons.
   (e)   "Under-Age Person" means any person over sixteen years of age or older
and less than twenty-one years of age.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
845.02 UNDER-AGE ESTABLISHMENT LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall engage in, conduct or carry on, or
permit to be engaged in, conducted or carried on, the business of an under-age
establishment within the Village without first having obtained an under-age
establishment license issued by the Village pursuant to the provisions of this
chapter for each and every premises used for the purpose of conducting the
business of an under-age establishment. The applicant for such license must be
twenty-one years of age or older.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
845.03 APPLICATION FOR UNDER-AGE ESTABLISHMENT LICENSE.
   (a)   An application for an under-age establishment license shall be filed
in the office of the Village Clerk. The Village Clerk need not be present for
the filing of the application. The application shall be made upon a form
provided by the Village Clerk and shall be completed in full and signed by the
applicant, if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof, if not an
individual, verified by oath or affidavit, and shall set forth:
      (1)   The type of ownership of the business, i.e., whether individual,
partnership, corporation, or otherwise.
      (2)   The name under which the business is to be conducted.
      (3)   A description of the services to be conducted on the premises.
      (4)   The location and description of the premises or place of business
which is to be operated under such license.
         A.   If a leased premises, a copy of the lease shall be provided. The
term of such lease must not end until after the expiration date of the license
for which application is being made.
         B.   The name and address of the owner(s) of the premises, and, if
said premises is held in trust, the names and addresses of all the owners of
the beneficial interest of the trust.
      (5)   All telephone numbers and internet addresses of the business.
      (6)   In the case of an individual, the full name, home address with zip
code, social security number, drivers license number, date of birth, sex and a
physical description of the applicant, including height, weight, color of hair
and eyes.
      (7)   In the case of a partnership, the full name, home address with zip
code, social security number, drivers license number, date of birth, sex and a
physical description including height, weight, color of hair and eyes of all
partners and any other persons entitled to share in the profits thereof.
      (8)   In the case of a corporation, the object for which organized, the
names, home addresses with zip codes, drivers license number, date of birth,
social security number, sex and a physical description including height,
weight, color of hair and eyes of all officers, directors, and all persons
owning directly or beneficially more than ten percent of the stock of such
corporation and the persons acting as managers or assistant managers or other
persons principally in charge of the operation of the business.
      (9)   The date of formation of the partnership, if a partnership, the
date of incorporation, if an Illinois corporation, or the date of becoming
qualified under the Illinois Business Corporation Act, 805 ILCS 5/1.01 et seq.,
to transact business in Illinois if a foreign corporation.
      (10)   A complete list of the name (and any alias) and residence
addresses of all employees employed by the business and the name (and any
alias) and residence addresses of all managers, assistant managers or other
persons principally in charge of the operation of the business.
      (11)   The business, occupation, and employment history of the applicant
for three years preceding the date of application.
      (12)   Whether applicant ever made an application for a license under
this chapter or for a liquor license under
Chapter 806, or for a similar license to a state, county, city, village or
other unit of local government, and if so, where and when; and, whether the
application was granted or denied, and if such application was denied, the
reasons for the denial.
      (13)   Whether a license was ever issued to the applicant under this
chapter, or a liquor license under
Chapter 806, or any similar license was ever issued by any state, county, city
or village or other unit of local government, and if so, where and when; and,
if any such license has ever been suspended or revoked and the reasons for the
suspension or revocation.
      (14)   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter or any similar ordinance of any other
Illinois municipality.
      (15)   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of
any ordinance of the Village or any other Illinois Municipality, or any law of
the State of Illinois, regulating or prohibiting the sale of alcoholic
beverages or any other controlled substance, including but not limited to
illicit drugs.
      (16)   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission of
a felony under the laws of this State, or any other state, or under the laws of
the United States.
      (17)   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a misdemeanor sex
offense as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-6 to 5/11-22, or any equivalent law of any
other state, within five years of the date of the application.
      (18)   Whether the applicant has been convicted of any other criminal
offense involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or moral turpitude within five
years of the date of the application.
      (19)   Proof that the applicant is twenty-one years of age or older.
      (20)   Evidence that the applicant has the ability to obtain liability
insurance for the business in an amount not less than one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) per occurrence. Such insurance shall be furnished at the time a
license is issued.
   (b)   The applicant shall submit a complete set of fingerprints with the
application. All such fingerprinting shall be done by the Village Police
Department. Said fingerprints shall be submitted to the appropriate State and/
or Federal agencies for processing as available. The cost of fingerprinting
shall be paid by the applicant in addition to any license application or
renewal fee.
   (c)   The applicant shall submit a written authorization for the Village,
its agents and employees to seek information and conduct an investigation into
the truth of the statements set forth in the application and the qualifications
of the applicant for a license.
   (d)   The applicant shall submit such other information, documentation, and
identification of the applicant as the Village President and/or the Chief of
Police shall deem necessary to determine the identity of the applicant or to
process the application.
   (e)   The applicant shall notify the Village President of each change in any
data required to be furnished by this section within ten days after such change
occurs.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
845.04 PERSONS INELIGIBLE FOR LICENSE.
   No under-age establishment license shall be issued to:
   (a)   A person who is not a citizen of the United States;
   (b)   A person who has been convicted of a felony under the laws of any
state or under Federal law;
   (c)   A person who has been convicted of being the keeper of, or who is
keeping, a house of ill-fame;
   (d)   A person who has been convicted of pandering or any other offense
against decency or morality;
   (e)   A person whose license issued under this chapter was revoked for
cause;
   (f)   A person who, at the time of application for renewal of a license
issued under this chapter, would not be eligible for such license upon a first
application;
   (g)   A copartnership, unless all of the members of such copartnership are
qualified to obtain such license;
   (h)   A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any
stockholder owning in the aggregate more than five percent of the stock
thereof, is not eligible to receive such a license for any reason other than
citizenship;
   (i)   A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent
unless such manager or agent possesses the same qualifications as required of
the licensee. Should a corporation qualify for a license under this chapter,
then the licensee shall have a manager or a principal agent working on the
premises who is a resident of the Village or otherwise available during all
working hours;
   (j)   A person who has been convicted of a violation of any Federal or state
law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor or other
contraband, including but not limited to illicit drugs, subsequent to the
passage of this chapter, or who has forfeited his or her bond to appear in
court to answer charges for any such violation;
   (k)   A person who does not beneficially own the premises for which the
license is sought, who does not have a lease thereon for the full period for
which the license is to be issued or who is not a beneficial owner of the
business to be operated by the licensee;
   (l)   Any person who has been convicted of a gambling offense under Federal
or state law, or as prescribed by a statute replaced by any state or federal
gambling law;
   (m)   Any person convicted of a misdemeanor sex offense as defined in 720
ILCS 5/11-6 to 5/11-22, or any equivalent law of any state within five years of
the date of the application; or
   (n)   Any person who is not twenty-one years of age or older.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
845.05 TERM OF LICENSE; LICENSE FEES; LICENSE RENEWAL.
   (a)   The term of licenses issued under this chapter is for one year
beginning January 1, as provided by Section
802.08 of the Village's Business Regulation Code and incorporated herein.
   (b)   All license fees shall be paid as provided by Section
802.08 of the Business Regulation Code and incorporated herein. All applicable
license fees and any other required fees, including costs of fingerprinting,
shall be paid prior to the issuance of any license.
   (c)   License renewal shall be made as provided by Section
802.16 of the Business Regulation Code and incorporated herein.
   (d)   A license may be revoked for failure to pay the license fee, as
provided by Section
802.15 of the Business Regulation Code and incorporated herein.
   (e)   A business duly licensed under this
Chapter 845 shall not be required to obtain a separate business license under
the provisions of
Chapter 802.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
845.06 SANITATION AND SAFETY REQUIREMENTS.
   All licensed premises shall be periodically inspected by the designated
building official or his duly authorized representative for safety of the
structure and adequacy of plumbing, ventilation, heating, illumination and fire
protection, as provided by
Chapter 804 of the Business Regulation Code. In addition, the premises shall
comply with the following regulations:
   (a)   Floors shall be free from any accumulation of dust, dirt, refuse or
slippery substances;
   (b)   All equipment, used in the under-age establishment, including but not
limited to equipment used to serve food or beverages, shall be maintained in a
clean and sanitary condition;
   (c)   There shall be a separate lavatory designated for use by males and
females, and members of one sex shall not be permitted to enter a lavatory
designated for the opposite sex.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
845.07 RESTRICTIONS
   An under-age establishment licensed under this chapter shall operate subject
to the following restrictions:
   (a)   Upon application to the President and Board of Trustees, an
establishment may receive a temporary license to remain open for business on up
to three occasions (by way of example, for New Year's Eve, special holidays,
special events), in any license year. No such establishment shall be open for
business between the hours of 11:30 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.
   (b)   At all times during which such establishment is open for business, the
establishment shall have on premises and in its employ at least three off-duty,
police officers who are sworn in and actively serving as members of any
municipal police department, or private security guards from a private security
contractor licensed under the Private Detective, Private Alarm, Private
Security and Locksmith Act of 1993.
   (c)   Any window coverings within the structure shall be capable of being
opened to permit plain view of the interior of the establishment from adjacent
public rights-of-way. At all times during which such establishment is open for
business, any screen, blind, curtain, partition, or other window covering shall
be open to permit plain view into the interior of the establishment from
adjacent public rights-of-way.
   (d)   All out-of-doors areas which patrons are permitted to occupy shall be
open to plain view from any adjacent public or private rights of way.
   (e)   Children under the age of sixteen shall not be admitted under any
circumstances. No one over the age of twenty-one shall be admitted, except that
parents and guardians of patrons shall be admitted.
   (f)   No alcohol shall be permitted on the premises.
   (g)   No illegal contraband, including but not limited to illicit drugs,
shall be permitted on the premises.
   (h)   No gambling or wagering shall be permitted on the premises.
   (i)   No person who is visibly impaired or under the influence of alcohol or
a controlled substance shall be permitted to enter or remain on the premises.
   (j)   Patrons shall not be permitted to enter any area which may be closed
off or concealed by a door, except lavatories.
   (k)   No license shall be issued for any such establishment if the same is
to be located within 500 feet of any liquor establishment. Such distance shall
be measured from the primary customer entrance of the premises for which
application has been made for a license hereunder to the nearest point of the
liquor establishment building.
   (l)   Any establishment licensed under this chapter shall require
prospective patrons to provide proof of age by displaying a valid photo ID.
   (m)   The licensee, or his agents or employees, shall at all times maintain
order on the licensed premises, including the parking lot and areas immediately
surrounding the premises under control of the licensee and shall take
reasonable steps to prevent unlawful loitering on or about the premises.
   (n)   The licensee shall immediately notify the Police Department whenever a
"breach of the peace" (as defined in Section
806.31(a)(1) of the Codified Ordinances) occurs on the licensed premises
including the parking lot and areas immediately surrounding the premises under
control of licensee.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
845.08 ISSUANCE AND DENIAL OF LICENSES.
   (a)   The Village President shall act to approve or deny an application for
a license under this chapter within a reasonable period of time and in no event
shall the Village President act to approve or deny said fully completed license
later than ninety days from the date that said application was accepted by the
Village.
   (b)   In the case of an application for an under-age establishment license,
the designated building official shall cause to premises to be licensed to be
inspected to assure that the proposed operation complies with all applicable
laws, including building, electrical, plumbing, health, housing, zoning, and
fire codes of the Village and any other regulations of the Village relating to
the public health, safety and welfare. The designated building official shall
make written verification to the Village President concerning compliance with
the codes and ordinances of the Village that they administer.
   (c)   Upon receipt of a properly completed application for an under-age
establishment license, the Village President shall submit the completed
application to the Chief of Police for an investigation into the applicant's
personal and criminal history.
   (d)   The Village President shall either issue a license, or notify the
applicant in writing that the application has been denied. The license shall be
denied if the applicant fails to comply with the requirements of this chapter
or with the requirements of any other provision of this Code which is
applicable to the business and/or activities of the applicant. Specifically, no
license shall be issued to any applicant if:
      (1)   The proposed operation does not comply with all applicable laws,
including but not limited to, building, electrical, plumbing, health, housing,
zoning and fire codes of the Village, including Section
845.06 of this chapter;
      (2)   The applicant is ineligible to hold a license under this chapter
pursuant to Section
845.04 hereof;
      (3)   Any of the restrictions or requirements of Section
845.07 of this chapter apply to the premises or applicant; or
      (4)   The application is incomplete or the applicant has knowingly made
false, misleading or fraudulent statements of fact in the license application
or in any document required by the Village in conjunction with the license
application.
   (e)   In the event that the license is denied for failure to comply with the
requirements of this section, the Village President shall immediately notify
the applicant in writing or by telephone conversation of the reasons for the
proposed denial. If the failure is not cured within ten days after the date on
which the Village President denies the issuance of said license, the denial
shall become final.
   (f)   The Village President is authorized to make any rules and regulations
necessary to implement this chapter which are not inconsistent with or
prohibited by this chapter.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
845.09 DISPLAY OF LICENSE.
   Every person licensed as a under-age establishment under this chapter shall
display such license in a prominent place in the public reception area of the
under-age establishment.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
845.10 REGISTER OF EMPLOYEES.
   The licensee or person designated by the licensee of a licensed under-age
establishment shall maintain a register of the names and addresses of all
persons employed at said establishment. Such register shall be available at the
under-age establishment for inspection by representatives of the Village during
regular business hours.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
845.11 SALE, TRANSFER, OR CHANGE OF LOCATION.
   (a)   Upon sale, transfer, or relocation of an under-age establishment, the
license therefor shall be null and void and a new license shall be required.
Upon the death or incapacity of the licensee or any co-licensee of the under-
age establishment, any heir or beneficiary of a deceased licensee, or any
guardian of an heir or beneficiary of a deceased licensee, may continue the
business of the under-age establishment for a reasonable period of time not to
exceed sixty days to allow for an orderly transfer of the license.
   (b)   An under-age establishment may relocate to a new location upon written
notice to the Village of that fact, payment of a fifty dollar ($50.00)
relocation fee and inspection by the Village confirming that the new location
satisfies the requirements of this chapter.
   (c)   A license issued under this chapter shall be a purely personal
privilege, effective for a period not to exceed one year after issuance unless
sooner revoked as provided in this chapter, and shall not constitute property.
No under-age establishment license is transferable, separate or divisible, and
such authority as a license confers shall not be conferred only on the licensee
named therein.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
845.12 ENFORCEMENT.
   (a)   The Village President shall have the duty to enforce the provisions of
this chapter.
   (b)   The Village President or his authorized representative shall from time
to time make inspection of each under-age establishment for the purposes of
determining that the provisions of this chapter are fully complied with. It
shall be unlawful for any licensee to fail to allow such inspection officer
access to the premises or hinder such officer in any manner.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
845.13 COMPLAINT OF VIOLATION.
   Any complaint that any person, corporate or private, or any license, has
been or is violating the provisions of this chapter shall be made to the
Village President, the Village Clerk, or the Chief of Police. Complaints may be
made by any person, including employees and representatives of the Village.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
845.14 NOTICE.
   Whenever the Village is required to give notice under this chapter of
denial, suspension, revocation or cancellation of a license, such notice shall
be given as required by Section
202.12 of the Village's Administration Code, incorporated herein.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
845.15 REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSES.
   (a)   The Village may suspend or revoke an under-age establishment license
after notice and public hearing, as provided in Section
202.11 of the Village's Administration Code, incorporated herein, and upon the
additional basis set forth below.
   (b)   An under-age establishment license may be revoked or suspended after
public hearing if it is found that:
      (1)   The licensee has violated any provisions of this chapter;
      (2)   That any employee of the licensee has engaged in any conduct at the
licensees' premises which violate any provisions of this chapter and the
licensee knew or by due diligence should have known of such conduct;
      (3)   Any applicant for the under-age establishment license has made a
false statement on the application;
      (4)   A licensee has refused to allow any duly authorized police officer
or county enforcement officer or health or building inspector to inspect the
under-age establishment premises;
      (5)   The premises of the under-age establishment is at any time not in
compliance with the Village building, health or fire codes;
      (6)   The licensee or the premises of the under-age establishment is not
in compliance with any of the conditions and restrictions set forth in Sections
845.04 and 854.07 of this chapter.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
845.16 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   Any establishment operating as an under-age establishment, as defined by
this chapter, pursuant to a business license heretofore issued by the Village
shall be subject to the terms and conditions hereof on April 1, 2001.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
845.17 PENALTY.
   Penalties in addition to the suspension or revocation of a license may be
assessed as provided in Section
202.99 of the Village Administration Code.
(Ord. 1068. Passed 2-12-01.)
CHAPTER 846
Massage Establishments
846.01   Definitions.
846.02   Massage business license required.
846.03   Massage therapist license required.
846.04   Exemptions.
846.05   Application for massage business license.
846.06   Term of licenses; license fees; license renewal.
846.07   Sanitation and safety requirements.
846.08   Issuance and denial of licenses.
846.09   Display of license.
846.10   Register and regulation of employees.
846.11   Conditions and restrictions of license.
846.12   Sale, transfer, or change of location.
846.13   Prohibited acts and conditions.
846.14   Enforcement.
846.15   Complaint of violation.
846.16   Notice.
846.17   Revocation or suspension of licenses.
846.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Sex related offenses - see GEN. OFF.
Ch. 670
   Commercial establishments and licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 802
   Sexually oriented entertainment businesses - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 864
846.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings ascribed to them by this section:
   (a)   "Employee" means any person over eighteen years of age, other than a
massage therapist, who renders any service in connection with the operation of
a massage establishment and receives compensation from the owner or operator of
the establishment or patrons.
   (b)   "Licensee" means the owner and/or operator of a massage establishment.
   (c)   "Massage" or "practice of massage" means any method of applying
pressure on or friction against, or stroking, kneading, rubbing, tapping,
pounding, vibrating, touching or stimulating, the external parts of the body,
by another individual, with the hands, any body part, or with the aid of any
mechanical or electrical apparatus or appliance, with or without such
supplementary aids as rubbing alcohol, liniments, antiseptics, oils, powders,
creams, lotions, ointments or other similar preparations.
   (d)   "Massage establishment" means any establishment having a fixed place
of business where any person, firm, association, or corporation engages in, or
carries on, or permits to be engaged in or carried on, any of the acts of
massage as defined herein.
   (e)   "Massage therapist" means any person who is licensed to engage in
massage for compensation by the State of Illinois under the Illinois Massage
Licensing Act (ILCS Ch. 225, Act 57, § 1 et seq.).
   (f)   "Masseur" means any person who, for any consideration whatsoever,
engages in the practice of massage as defined herein.
   (g)   "Outcall massage service" means any business, the function of which is
to engage in or carry on massages for compensation at a location designated by
the customer or client rather than at a massage establishment.
   (h)   "Patron" means any person who receives a massage under such
circumstances that it is reasonably expected that he or she would pay money or
give any other consideration therefor.
   (i)   "Person" means any individual, partnership, firm, association, limited
liability company, joint stock company, corporation or combination of
individuals of whatever form or character.
   (j)   "Sexual or genital area" means the genitals, pubic area, anus, or
perineum of any person, or the vulva or breasts of a female.
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1098. Passed 3-11-02; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-
04.)
   846.02 MASSAGE BUSINESS LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall engage in, conduct or carry on, or
permit to be engaged in, conducted or carried on, the business of massage, or
otherwise provide a massage in return for compensation, in the Village of
Richton Park, without first having obtained a massage business license issued
by the Village pursuant to the provisions of this chapter for each and every
premises used for the business of conducting a massage business or otherwise
providing massages for compensation by such person. The applicant for such
business license must be at least eighteen years of age.
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
846.03 MASSAGE THERAPIST LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall provide a massage to another person as a masseur, employee
or otherwise, on any premises for which a business license has been issued or
is required under Section
846.02 unless duly licensed by the state under the Illinois Massage Licensing
Act (ILCS Ch. 225, Act 57, § 1 et seq.) or qualifies for an exemption
therefrom.
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
846.04 EXEMPTIONS.
   (a)   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following
businesses and entities:
      (1)   Hospitals, sanitariums, nursing homes, home health agencies,
hospice programs and other such programs as defined and licensed by the State
under Chapter 210 of the Illinois Compiled Statutes.
      (2)   Massages provided in the course of not-for-profit special events,
such as corporate health and wellness days, fundraisers, and athletic events.
      (3)   Beauty parlors, where massages are offered as an incidental part of
the primary business of hair care and beauty service.
   (b)   No provision contained in this chapter shall be construed to apply to
any business regulated by the provisions of the Illinois Physical Therapy
Registration Act, ILCS Ch. 225, Act 90, § 1 et seq. 
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1098. Passed 3-11-02; Ord. 1122. Passed 11-25-
02; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
846.05 APPLICATION FOR MASSAGE BUSINESS LICENSE.
   (a)   An application for a massage business license shall be filed with the
Village of Richton Park. The application shall be made upon a form provided by
the Village Clerk and shall be completed in full and signed by the applicant,
if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof, if not an individual,
verified by oath or affidavit, and shall set forth:
      (1)   The type of ownership of the business, i.e. individual,
partnership, corporation, or otherwise.
      (2)   The name under which the business is to be conducted.
      (3)   A description of the services to be provided on the premises.
      (4)   The location and description of the premises or place of business
which is to be operated under such license.
         A.   If a leased premises, a copy of the lease shall be provided. The
term of such lease must not end until after the expiration date of the license
for which application is being made.
         B.   The name and address of the owner of the premises, and, if said
premises are held in trust, the names and addresses of all the owners of the
beneficial interest of the trust.
      (5)   All telephone numbers and internet addresses of the business.
      (6)   In the case of an individual, the full name, home address with zip
code, Social Security number, driver's license number, date of birth, sex and a
physical description of the applicant, including height, weight and the color
of hair and eyes).
      (7)   In the case of a partnership, the full name, home address with zip
code, Social Security number, driver's license number, date of birth, sex and a
physical description including height, weight and the color of hair and eyes of
all partners and any other persons entitled to share in the profits thereof.
      (8)   In the case of a corporation, the object for which organized, the
names, home addresses with zip codes, driver's license numbers, dates of birth,
Social Security numbers, sex and physical descriptions including height, weight
and color of hair and eyes of all officers, directors, and all persons owning
directly or beneficially more than ten percent (10%) of the stock of such
corporation and the persons acting as managers or assistant managers or other
persons principally in charge of the operation of the business.
      (9)   The date of formation of the partnership, if a partnership, the
date of incorporation, if an Illinois corporation, or the date of becoming
qualified under the Illinois Business Corporation Act, ILCS Ch. 805, Act 5, §
1.01 et seq., to transact business in the State, if a foreign corporation.
      (10)   A complete list of the names (and any aliases) and residence
addresses of all massage therapists and employees employed by the business and
the names (and any aliases) and residence addresses of all managers, assistant
managers or other persons principally in charge of the operation of the
business.
      (11)   The business, occupation, and employment history of the applicant
for the three years preceding the date of application.
      (12)   Whether the applicant ever made an application for a license under
this chapter, or a massage business license or similar license to a state,
county, city, village or other unit of local government, and if so, where and
when, and if such application was granted or denied, and if such application
was denied, the reasons for the denial.
      (13)   Whether a license was ever issued to the applicant under this
chapter or a massage business license or similar license was ever issued by any
state, county, city, village or other unit of local government, and if so,
where and when, and if such license has ever been suspended or revoked and the
reasons for the suspension or revocation.
      (14)   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter or any ordinance of any other Illinois
municipality which regulates massage parlors or the provision of massages, or
any Illinois statute regulating massage establishments.
      (15)   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission of
a felony under the laws of this State, or any other state, or under the laws of
the United States.
      (16)   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a sex offense as
defined in 720 ILCS Ch. 720, Act 5, § 11, or any equivalent law of any state,
within five years of the date of the application.
      (17)   Whether the applicant has been convicted of any other criminal
offense involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or moral turpitude within five
years of the date of the application.
      (18)   Proof that the applicant is at least eighteen years of age.
      (19)   Proof that the applicant currently carries professional liability
insurance in an amount not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000) per
occurrence.
   (b)   The applicant shall submit a complete set of fingerprints with the
application. All such fingerprinting shall be done by the Village of Richton
Park Police Department. Said fingerprints shall be submitted to the appropriate
State and/or Federal agencies for processing as available. The cost of
fingerprinting shall be paid by the applicant in addition to any license
application or renewal fee.
   (c)   The applicant shall submit a written authorization for the Village,
its agents and employees to seek information and conduct an investigation into
the truth of the statements set forth in the application and the qualifications
of the applicant for a license.
   (d)   The applicant shall submit such other information, documentation, and
identification of the applicant as the Village President and/or the Chief of
Police shall deem necessary to determine the identity of the applicant or to
process the application.
   (e)   The applicant shall notify the Village President of each change in any
data required to be furnished by this section within ten days after such change
occurs, except that any prospective new massage therapist employee shall not be
employed until he or she has received a massage therapist license issued by the
State of Illinois pursuant to the Illinois Massage Licensing Act (ILCS Ch. 225,
Act 57, § 1 et seq.)
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
846.06 TERM OF LICENSE; LICENSE FEES; LICENSE RENEWAL.
   (a)   The term of massage business licenses issued under this chapter is for
one year beginning January 1, as provided by Section
802.08 of the Villages’ Business Regulation Code and incorporated herein.
   (b)   All license fees shall be paid as provided by Section
802.08. The license application fee and the annual license renewal fee for a
massage business license shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00). All applicable
license fees and any other required fees, including costs of fingerprinting,
shall be paid prior to the issuance of any license.
   (c)   License renewal shall be made as provided by Section
802.16.
   (d)   A license may be revoked for failure to pay the license fee, as
provided by Section
802.15.
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
846.07 SANITATION AND SAFETY REQUIREMENTS.
   All licensed premises shall be periodically inspected by the Building
Commissioner or his or her duly authorized representative for safety of the
structure and adequacy of plumbing, ventilation, heating, illumination and fire
protection, as provided by
Chapter 804 of the Business Regulation Code. In addition, the premises shall
comply with the following regulations:
   (a)   The walls shall be clean and painted with washable, mold-resistant
paint in all rooms where water or steam baths are given.
