   (b)   Floors shall be free from any accumulation of dust, dirt or refuse.
   (c)   All equipment used in the massage establishment shall be maintained in
a clean and sanitary condition.
   (d)   Soaps, towels, linens and laundered sheets must be provided. All such
towels, linens and items for the personal use of operators and patrons shall be
clean and freshly laundered after each use thereof and stored in a sanitary
manner.
   (e)   Towels, linens and sheets shall not be used for more than one patron.
However, heavy white paper may be substituted for sheets, provided that such
paper is changed for every patron.
   (f)   All massage services or practices are prohibited in any cubicle, room,
booth or any area within a massage establishment which is fitted with a door
capable of being locked.
   (g)   Toilets, dressing room facilities, lockers, steam baths, tubs or
showers, if provided, shall be provided separately for each sex.
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
846.08 ISSUANCE AND DENIAL OF LICENSES.
   (a)   The Village President shall act to approve or deny an application for
a massage business license under this chapter within a reasonable period of
time, and in no event shall the Village President act to approve or deny said
fully completed license later than ninety days from the date that said
application was accepted by the Village.
   (b)   The Building Commissioner shall cause the premises to be licensed to
be inspected to assure that the proposed operation complies with all applicable
laws, including the building, electrical, plumbing, health, housing, zoning,
and fire codes of the Village, and any other regulations of the Village
relating to the public health, safety and welfare. The Building Commissioner
shall make written verification to the Village President concerning compliance
with the codes and ordinances of the Village that they administer.
   (c)   Upon receipt of a properly completed application for a massage
business license, the Village President shall submit the completed application
to the Chief of Police for an investigation into the applicant's personal and
criminal history.
   (d)   The Village President shall either issue a massage business license,
or notify the applicant in writing that the application has been denied. The
license shall be denied if the applicant fails to comply with the requirements
of this chapter or with the requirements of any other provision of this Code
which is applicable to the business. In addition, no license shall be issued to
any applicant if:
      (1)   The proposed operation does not comply with all applicable laws,
including, but not limited to, building, electrical, plumbing, health, housing,
zoning and fire codes of the Village; or
      (2)   The applicant, if an individual; or any of the officers, directors,
any person owning directly or beneficially more than ten percent of the stock
of the corporation, if the applicant is a corporation; or any of the partners,
including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership; and the manager,
assistant manager or any other person principally in charge of the operation of
the business; has been:
         A.   Convicted of a felony under the laws of the State of Illinois or
any other state, or under the Federal laws of the United States, within five
years of the date of the application;
         B.   Convicted of a sex offense as defined in ILCS Ch. 720, Act 5, §§
11-5 to 11-22, or any equivalent law of any state, within five years of the
date of the application; or
         C.   Convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter;
      (3)   The applicant has had a massage business, masseur or similar
license denied, suspended or revoked by the Village, by a state or by a unit of
local government within five years of the date of the application; or
      (4)   The applicant has knowingly made false, misleading or fraudulent
statements of fact in the license application or in any document required by
the Village in conjunction with the license application.
   (e)   In the event that the license is denied for failure to comply with the
requirements of this chapter, the Village President shall immediately notify
the applicant in writing or by telephone conversation of the reasons for the
proposed denial. If the failure is not cured within ten days after the date on
which the Village President denies the issuance of said license, the denial
shall become final.
   (f)   The Village President is authorized to make any rules and regulations
necessary to implement this chapter which are not inconsistent with or
prohibited by this chapter.
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
846.09 DISPLAY OF LICENSES.
   (a)   Every person licensed as a massage business under this chapter shall
display such license in a prominent place in the public reception area of the
massage establishment.
   (b)   Every person licensed as a massage business shall prominently display
a copy of each massage therapist’s license employed at the establishment in the
applicable massage therapist’s work area.
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
846.10 REGISTER AND REGULATION OF EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   The licensee or a person designated by the licensee of a licensed
massage establishment shall maintain a register of the names and addresses of
all persons employed at any time as massage therapists or other employees. The
register shall list the massage therapists' Illinois State license numbers.
Such register shall be available at the massage establishment for inspection by
representatives of the Village of Richton Park during regular business hours.
   (b)   It shall be the responsibility of the licensee of a massage
establishment to insure that each person employed as a massage therapist shall
first have obtained a valid state license as required by this chapter. It shall
be unlawful for such a business to allow a massage therapist to practice other
than as permitted by this chapter and the Illinois Massage Licensing Act ILCS
ch. 225, Act 57, § 1 et seq..
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
846.11 CONDITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS OF LICENSES.
   (a)   Supervision. A licensee shall have the premises supervised at all
times when open for business. Any business rendering massage services shall
have at least one person who is a duly licensed massage therapist on the
premises at all times while the establishment is open. The massage business
licensee shall personally supervise the business, or shall delegate such
supervisory responsibility to a manager whose name is listed on the massage
business license as required by
846.05(a)(10) and shall not violate, or permit others to violate, any
applicable provisions of this chapter. The violation of any provision of this
chapter by any agent or employee of the licensee shall constitute a violation
by the licensee.
   (b)   Sanitary Conditions. Every portion of the massage establishment,
including appliances and apparatus, shall be kept clean and operated in a
sanitary condition as required by Section
846.07.
   (c)   Price Rates. Price rates for all services shall be prominently posted
on a framed placard no smaller than 8" x 10" in the reception area in a
location visible and available to all prospective customers. This placard must
also state the following: "No services other than those listed shall be
provided for any compensation whatsoever. There shall be no bargaining or
solicitation for services between patrons, massage therapists, or employees."
   (d)   Separate License for Each Premises. Licenses shall apply only to the
premises described in the application, and in the license issued thereon, and
only one location shall be so described in each license.
   (e)   Transfer of License. A massage business license shall be a purely
personal privilege, effective for a period not to exceed one year after
issuance unless sooner revoked as provided in this chapter, and shall not
constitute property. No massage business license is transferable, separate or
divisible, and such authority as a license confers shall be conferred only on
the licensee named therein.
   (f)   Minors Prohibited. No person licensed under the provisions of this
chapter shall permit any person under the age of eighteen to come or remain on
the premises of any massage establishment as a masseur or employee.
   (g)   Alcoholic Beverages Prohibited. No person, firm or corporation shall
sell, give, dispense, provide, keep or consume, or cause to be sold, given,
dispensed, provided, kept or consumed, any alcoholic beverage on the premises
of any massage establishment.
   (h)   Solicitations Prohibited. No massage establishment shall place,
publish or distribute, or cause to be placed, published or distributed, any
advertisement, picture, or statement which is known to be false, deceptive or
misleading in order to induce any person to purchase or utilize any massage
services.
   (i)   Hours of Operation. No portion of any business premises used in any
way for or by a massage establishment shall be kept open for any purpose
between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.
   (j)   Inspections. The Village President or his or her authorized
representative shall from time to time make inspection of each massage
establishment for the purposes of determining that the provisions of this
chapter are fully complied with. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to fail
to allow any such inspection officer access to the premises or hinder such
officer in any manner.
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
846.12 SALE, TRANSFER, OR CHANGE OF LOCATION.
   Upon the sale, transfer, or relocation of a massage establishment, the
license therefor shall be null and void and a new license shall be required.
Upon the death or incapacity of the licensee or any co-licensee of the massage
establishment, any heir or beneficiary of a deceased licensee, or any guardian
of an heir or beneficiary of a deceased licensee, may continue the business of
the massage establishment for a reasonable period of time not to exceed sixty
days to allow for an orderly transfer of the license.
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
846.13 PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate a massage
business without first obtaining and maintaining a massage business license as
required by this chapter.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or conduct any massage
establishment which does not conform to the sanitary provisions required by
this chapter.
   (c)   It shall be unlawful for any person, having a license under this
chapter, to operate under any name or conduct business under any designation
not specified in that license or permit.
   (d)   A patron's sexual and genital areas, as defined herein, must be
covered by towels, cloths or similar nontransparent garments, including
undergarments, when in the presence of a massage therapist or employee.
   (e)   It is unlawful for any person, knowingly, in a massage establishment,
to expose or fail to conceal his or her sexual and genital parts, or any
portion thereof, to any other person. It shall also be unlawful for any person,
knowingly, in a massage establishment, to expose the sexual or genital parts,
or any portion thereof, of any other person.
   (f)   It is unlawful for any person, knowingly, in a massage establishment,
to place his or her hands upon, to touch with any part of his or her body, to
fondle in any manner, or to massage, a sexual or genital area of another
person.
   (g)   It shall be unlawful for any person, owning, operating or managing a
massage establishment, knowingly to cause, allow or permit in or about such
massage establishment, any agent, employee, or any other person under his or
her control or supervision to perform any acts prohibited by this chapter.
   (h)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or conduct an outcall
massage service as defined in this chapter.
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
846.14 ENFORCEMENT.
   The Village President shall have the duty to enforce the provisions of this
chapter.
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
846.15 COMPLAINT OF VIOLATION.
   Any complaint that any person, corporate or private, or any licensee, has
been or is violating the provisions of this chapter shall be made to the
Village President or the Village Clerk. Complaints may be made by any person,
including employees and representatives of the Village.
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
846.16 NOTICE.
   Whenever the Village is required to give notice under this chapter of
denial, suspension, revocation or cancellation of a license, such notice shall
be given as required by Section
202.12 of the Administration Code, incorporated herein.
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
846.17 REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSES.
   (a)   The Village may suspend or revoke a massage business license after
notice and public hearing, as provided in Section
202.11 of the Administration Code, and upon the additional basis set forth
below.
   (b)   A massage business license may be revoked or suspended after a public
hearing if it is found that:
      (1)   The licensee has violated any provisions of this chapter;
      (2)   Any employee of the licensee, including licensed massage
therapists, has engaged in any conduct at the licensee's premises which
violates any provision of this chapter and the licensee knew or by due
diligence should have known of such conduct;
      (3)   Any applicant for a massage business license has made a false
statement on the application;
      (4)   A licensee has refused to allow any duly authorized police officer
or County enforcement officer or health inspector to inspect the massage
establishment premises;
      (5)   The premises of the massage establishment are at any time not in
compliance with the Village building, health or fire codes; or
      (6)   The premises of the massage establishment are not in compliance
with any of the conditions and restrictions set forth in Section
846.11.
   (c)   If a massage business license is revoked for any cause, no such
license shall be granted to such person for a period of one year after the date
of the revocation that will allow a massage establishment to be operated on the
premises described in the revoked license unless the revocation order has been
vacated by court order.
(Ord. 1006. Passed 3-22-99; Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
846.99 PENALTY.
   Penalties in addition to the suspension or revocation of a license may be
assessed as provided in
Chapter 202, Section 99, of the Village Administration Code.
(Ord. 1171. Passed 2-9-04.)
CHAPTER 858
Parking Lots
858.01   Defined.
858.02   License required.
858.03   License application.
858.04   License fee.
858.05   Barriers required.
858.06   Entrances and exits.
858.07   Fire safety precautions.
858.08   Changes in parking rates.
858.09   Refusal to park vehicles.
858.10   Claim checks.
858.11   Signs.
858.12   Bond or property liability insurance.
858.13   License suspension or revocation for failure to satisfy judgments.
858.14   Reports of claims against lot; liability after hours.
858.15   Notification of unclaimed parked vehicles.
858.16   Use of vehicles in lot.
858.17   Miscellaneous care and use regulations.
858.18   Approval required for receiving lots.
858.19   Temporary lots.
858.20   Transfer of license.
858.21   Effect of revocation on subsequent licenses.
858.22   Scope.
858.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Parking lots - see TRAF.
Ch. 442
   Commercial establishments and licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 802
   Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 882
858.01 DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "parking lot" means any plat, piece or parcel of
land used for the purpose of storing motor vehicles where the owners of such
vehicles or persons storing them are charged a fee for such storage. "Parking
lot" includes such plats where shelters that are not completely enclosed are
erected, which shelters are open to the general public.
(1976 Code 6-59.)
858.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in the business of operating a parking lot for motor
vehicles without first obtaining a license therefor.
(Ord. 232. Passed 2-9-60; 1976 Code 6-60.)
858.03 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   (a)   An application for the license required in Section
858.02 shall be made upon forms furnished by the Village Clerk.
   (b)   The application shall set forth the following:
      (1)   The name under which, and the place where, the parking lot is to be
operated;
      (2)   Whether the applicant is an individual, partnership or corporation.
If an individual, the name and business and residence addresses of the
applicant shall be given; if a partnership, the name, and business and
residence addresses of each partner shall be given; and if a corporation, the
following shall be furnished: the name, date and state under which such
corporation was organized, the amount and value of the capital stock issued by
such corporation, the name and business and residence addresses of the officers
and managers in charge and the directors thereof and a certified copy of the
articles of incorporation.
      (3)   Whether the premises are owned or leased by the applicant, and, if
leased, the name, and residence and business addresses of each owner or part
owner thereof;
      (4)   The number of motor vehicles which may, at any one time, be stored
upon the premises;
      (5)   The hours during which motor vehicles may be stored;
      (6)   A complete schedule of the rates to be charged for storing motor
vehicles and the hours at which changes in rate take place; and
      (7)   Such other information as the Village may deem advisable.
   (c)   The application shall be signed and verified under oath by the
applicant, if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent, if a partnership or
corporation.
(1976 Code 6-61.)
858.04 LICENSE FEE.
   The annual fee for a license to operate a parking lot in the Village shall
be as set forth in Section
858.09(b)(8).
858.05 BARRIERS REQUIRED.
   Except for places of entrance and exit, every parking lot licensed under
this chapter shall be completely enclosed by barriers constructed and
maintained so as to withstand the shocks and stresses to which they will
normally be subjected by vehicles using the premises. Such barriers shall be of
such height as to engage the bumper of any motor vehicle parked on the lot so
that no portion of the vehicle extends over the property lines. When a parking
lot abuts upon a building, barriers shall be erected, as provided in this
section, to prevent motor vehicles from striking such building.
(1976 Code 6-63.)
858.06 ENTRANCES AND EXITS.
   Every parking lot licensed under this chapter shall have at least one
entrance and one exit, which may or may not be combined, and the operator of
the parking lot shall keep such entrance and exit properly attended at all
times during the period the parking lot is in operation.
(1976 Code 6-64.)
858.07 FIRE SAFETY PRECAUTIONS.
   (a)   Every parking lot licensed under this chapter shall be equipped with
proper fire extinguishing apparatus subject to the approval of the Fire
Department.
   (b)   All motor vehicles shall be stored in such a manner that they may be
reached readily in case of fire or other emergencies.
(1976 Code 6-65.)
858.08 CHANGES IN PARKING RATES.
   No licensee under this chapter shall make any charge for storing any motor
vehicle in a parking lot in excess of that set forth in his or her application
for the license, unless he or she has:
   (a)   Notified the Village Clerk in writing of the change; and
   (b)   Posted signs showing such change in the manner set forth in Section
858.11.
(1976 Code 6-66.)
858.09 REFUSAL TO PARK VEHICLES.
   No licensee under this chapter shall refuse to park any vehicle for which
there is accommodation in his or her parking lot upon tender of the stated fee.
(1976 Code 6-67.)
858.10 CLAIM CHECKS.
   (a)   At the time of accepting a motor vehicle for storage or parking in a
parking lot licensed under this chapter, the person conducting the lot or his
or her agent, servant or employee shall furnish to the person parking his or
her motor vehicle a distinctive check.
   (b)   The check shall be numbered to correspond to a coupon placed upon such
motor vehicle and shall contain the name and address of the place and the owner
operating such parking lot. The date and, if parking is charged for on an
hourly basis, the time of acceptance of such motor vehicle shall be written,
printed, cut out or stamped on the check.
   (c)   No person shall affix any parking check on a motor vehicle so as to
obliterate, in whole or in part, any portion of the motor vehicle license plate
thereof.
   (d)   Subsections (a) through (c) hereof do not apply to cars parked in a
lot on a monthly basis.
(1976 Code 6-68.)
858.11 SIGNS.
   (a)   Each licensee under this chapter shall maintain, at each entrance to
the licensed premises, a permanently affixed sign suitable to inform persons
using the parking lot of the name of the licensee, the hours of the day or
night during which such place is open for storing motor vehicles, the rates
charged and the closing hours of such lot.
   (b)   When more than one rate is charged for parking, the figures of each
rate shall be shown on the sign in figures of the same size and dimensions. The
figures shall measure not less than eight inches in height. The letters and
figures indicating the closing hours shall be not less than four inches in
height.
   (c)   The sign shall give the number of the license, if any, under which the
lot is operated.
   (d)   Where the licensee operates a receiving lot in which cars are accepted
with the understanding that such cars may be removed to another lot, the
licensee shall post on the sign required by this section, in letters not less
than four inches in height, the following information: "Receiving Lot-Cars
Parked Here May Be Moved to No. _________ Street" (giving the address to which
such cars are moved).
   (e)   Any sign erected pursuant to this section shall be subject to the
approval of the Director of Community Development or his or her designee.
   (f)   Where separate rates or charges are made for day parking and night
parking, notice thereof shall be posted on the sign required by this section.
(1976 Code 6-69.)
858.12 BOND OR PROPERTY LIABILITY INSURANCE.
   (a)   No license shall be issued, and no parking lot shall be operated,
pursuant to this chapter, until and unless the licensee under this chapter has
deposited with the Village Clerk a bond or property liability insurance policy
in the amount set forth in paragraph (c)(3) hereof. The bond or insurance
policy shall be with one or more adequate sureties or a surety company
acceptable to the Board of Trustees and conditioned that the licensee will pay
all final judgments rendered against him or her for damages arising during the
period such bond or insurance policy is in force from the operation of any
motor vehicle in such parking lot or from the loss, damage, theft or conversion
of any motor vehicle parked therein.
   (b)   Any person who sustains damage by reason of the violation of any
provision of such bond or insurance by any licensee may institute suit upon the
same and recover any judgment that may be obtained by reason of such suit.
   (c)   The bond or insurance policy shall meet the following requirements:
      (1)   It shall contain a provision that it continues in force until ten
days after written notice of cancellation has been delivered to the Clerk or
until the license of the applicant has been revoked.
      (2)   The obligation of the bond or insurance policy shall not exceed the
principal amount of the bond.
      (3)   The bond or insurance policy shall be in the following amounts:
         A.   Where the licensee conducts one lot - ten thousand dollars
($10,000);
         B.   Where the licensee conducts two lots - fifteen thousand dollars
($15,000);
         C.   Where the licensee conducts three lots - twenty thousand dollars
($20,000); and
         D.   Where the licensee conducts four or more lots - twenty-five
thousand dollars ($25,000).
(1976 Code 6-70.)
858.13 LICENSE SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION FOR FAILURE TO SATISFY JUDGMENTS.
   The failure on the part of a licensee under this chapter to pay any final
judgment, within ten days after a judgment against him or her has become final,
shall be deemed sufficient grounds for the suspension or revocation of his or
her license.
(1976 Code 6-71.)
858.14 REPORTS OF CLAIMS AGAINST LOT; LIABILITY AFTER HOURS.
   (a)   Each licensee under this chapter shall immediately notify the Police
Department of any claim over twenty-five dollars ($25.00) made by reason of any
loss, theft or conversion occurring upon his or her premises or of any claim
for damages arising from the operation of his or her parking lot.
   (b)   The obligation of any person operating or conducting a parking lot
under this chapter to the owner of a motor vehicle parked therein shall not
extend beyond the regular hours of attendance, as posted upon the open parking
lot.
(1976 Code 6-72.)
858.15 NOTIFICATION OF UNCLAIMED PARKED VEHICLES.
   Every licensee under this chapter shall immediately notify the Police
Department, in writing, of the license number, make and, if available, the name
of the owner of every vehicle left in a parking lot for more than forty-eight
consecutive hours, unless the name and address of the owner of such vehicle are
personally known to the licensee.
(1976 Code 6-73.)
858.16 USE OF VEHICLES IN LOT.
   (a)   No person shall make any use, for any purposes whatsoever, of any
motor vehicle parked in a parking lot, unless the use is expressly authorized
by the owner or person having control of such vehicle.
   (b)   A licensee under this chapter, however, may move a motor vehicle from
a so-called receiving lot to another parking lot, if adequate signs, as
provided for in Section
858.11(d), are properly erected and maintained at each entrance of such
receiving lot. The licensee shall be liable to the owner of any motor vehicle
so moved for any damage to such motor vehicle caused by such moving.
   (c)   All cars moved to auxiliary lots shall be returned to the original
place of acceptance at the close of business hours.
(1976 Code 6-74.)
858.17 MISCELLANEOUS CARE AND USE REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Maintenance. Every operator of a parking lot licensed under this
chapter shall keep the sidewalks surrounding the premises free from dirt, ice,
sleet and snow, and shall keep the sidewalks and driveways in a safe condition
for the travel of pedestrians.
   (b)   Construction of Surface. The surface of such parking lot shall be
constructed so as to prevent retention of water thereon.
   (c)   Distribution or Placement of Handbills. No person shall distribute
literature or place handbills in or upon any vehicle while parked in such a
parking lot.
   (d)   Loading and Unloading Passengers; Obstruction of Public Way. The
loading or unloading of passengers or drivers of vehicles across or upon a
public sidewalk is prohibited, and no operator or employee of a parking lot
licensed under this chapter shall receive or deliver a vehicle at or to a
location outside the property line of the parking lot in such a way as to block
any sidewalk or street.
   (e)   Use of Lot by Vendors. No licensee under this chapter shall sublease
or otherwise permit any licensed parking lot or public garage or portion
thereof to be used by any vendor of goods, wares, merchandise or services for
the conduct of such vendor's business unless the same is conducted in a
permanent building or structure licensed by the Village for that purpose. This
subsection shall not be construed to prohibit the maintenance and use of
cigarette, candy and soft drink vending machines on or in any licensed parking
lot or public garage.
(1976 Code 6-75.)
858.18 APPROVAL REQUIRED FOR RECEIVING LOTS.
   Parking lots designated and used as receiving lots from which cars may be
received and removed to other lots shall first be approved and designated as
such by the Police Chief. No lot shall be used as a receiving lot without such
approval and designation.
(1976 Code 6-76.)
858.19 TEMPORARY LOTS.
   (a)   Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to require the licensing of
temporary parking lots operated for the accommodation of motorists attending
public functions, circuses or sports events, even though a fee may be charged
the patrons of such temporary lots. No such temporary lot, however, shall be
operated more than two days in any week.
   (b)   At the entrance of such a temporary lot, there shall be placed a sign
on which is printed the words, in letters of sufficient size to be legible to
all patrons, "Temporary Parking Lot-Not Licensed."
(1976 Code 6-77.)
858.20 TRANSFER OF LICENSE.
   No parking lot license issued under this chapter shall be transferred or
assigned to or used by any person other than one to whom it is issued or at any
location other than the one for which it is issued.
(1976 Code 6-78.)
858.21 EFFECT OF REVOCATION ON SUBSEQUENT LICENSES.
   No license required by this chapter shall be issued to any person whose
parking lot license has, within five years prior to the date of the
application, been revoked or to any firm, partnership, association or
corporation any of whose members, officers or managers has had his or her
parking lot license revoked within five years prior to the date of the
application.
(1976 Code 6-79.)
858.22 SCOPE.
   This chapter does not apply to:
   (a)   A car lot operated by a new car dealer for the purpose of displaying
his or her cars and offering them for sale;
   (b)   A person operating a business who provides parking space free of
charge to bona fide employees or customers; or
   (c)   A lessee of lands owned by the Village where such lands are not leased
for the purpose of public parking but are used as an adjunct to the conduct of
the lessee's business.
(1976 Code 6-80.)
858.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
(Ord. 1687. Passed 1-14-19.)
CHAPTER 860
Peddlers and Hawkers
860.01   Definitions.
860.02   Licenses.
860.03   Mobility of licensees required.
860.04   Periodic inspection of licensee's goods.
860.05   Attracting attention by loud noises.
860.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to license peddlers - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 24, 11-42-5
   Peddlers of liquor - see B.R. & T.
806.02
   Peddlers in parking lots - see B.R. & T.
858.17(e)
   Solicitors - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 868
860.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, "peddler" or "hawker" means a person who sells, or
offers for sale, barter or exchange, any goods, wares, merchandise or other
commodities, traveling from place to place on, along or upon the streets of the
Village, or who sells and delivers, from any wagon, pushcart or other vehicle
going from place to place, any goods, wares, merchandise, meat, poultry, fish,
cheese, lard, vegetables, baked products or other commodities.
(1976 Code 6-81.)
860.02 LICENSES.
   (a)   Required. No person shall hawk or peddle any commodity in the Village
without first obtaining a license therefor, as provided in this section.
(Ord. 11. Passed 11-14-27; 1976 Code 6-82.)
   (b)   Application. Every person who desires such a license shall make an
application to the Village Clerk, in writing, which shall conform to the
general application requirements of
Chapter 802 and which shall state whether the applicant desires to be licensed
to peddle or hawk from a vehicle or from a pack, basket or other like
receptacle carried by himself or herself. Such application shall also state
what commodity or article of merchandise such peddler or hawker desires and
intends to deal.
(1976 Code 6-83.)
   (c)   Fees. The Village Manager shall grant the license, to be issued and
attested by the Clerk, to any person who complies with subsection (b) hereof
and who pays, to the Village treasury, the fees set forth in Section
802.09 (b)(9). Such fees do not authorize the use of more than one pack,
basket, receptacle, wagon or other vehicle thereunder.
(Ord. 11. Passed 11-14-27; 1976 Code 6-84.)
   (d)   Exhibition. A person who hawks or peddles in the Village shall, upon
the demand of any officer of the Village, forthwith produce his or her license
for the inspection of the person so demanding the same.
(Ord. 11. Passed 11-14-27; 1976 Code 6-85.)
   (e)   Transferability. Hawker's and peddler's licenses are not transferable.
(Ord. 11. Passed 11-14-27; 1976 Code 6-86.)
   (f)   Compliance with Application. No hawker or peddler shall sell, or offer
for sale, barter or exchange, any kind of goods, wares or merchandise other
than that specified in his or her license application.
(1976 Code 6-88.)
   (g)   Revocation. Any hawker's or peddler's license may be revoked by the
Manager upon proof of the licensee's violating any of the provisions of this
chapter or any other ordinance of the Village covering the subject matter
embraced in this chapter.
(Ord. 11. Passed 11-14-27; 1976 Code 6-92.)
   (h)   Records. The Clerk shall keep a record of the number of peddler's and
hawker's licenses issued, the names and addresses of the persons to whom the
licenses were issued and the amounts of fees paid to the Village Treasurer as
shown by his or her receipts therefor, which receipts shall be kept on file by
the Clerk.
(Ord. 11. Passed 11-14-27; 1976 Code 6-91.)
860.03 MOBILITY OF LICENSEES REQUIRED.
   All peddlers and hawkers shall keep moving from place to place, except when
in the act of showing goods or selling goods to customers.
(1976 Code 6-87.)
860.04 PERIODIC INSPECTION OF LICENSEE'S GOODS.
   The Chief of Police shall, from time to time, inspect the goods, wares or
merchandise of each peddler or hawker as to sanitation and as to the kinds of
goods, wares or merchandise as stated in the license application.
(1976 Code 6-89.)
860.05 ATTRACTING ATTENTION BY LOUD NOISES.
   No person who is hawking or peddling in the Village shall make or cause, or
permit or allow to be made, any noise of any kind by crying, calling or
shouting or by means of any whistle, rattle, bell, gong, clapper, hammer, drum,
horn or similar mechanical device, for the purpose of advertising any goods,
wares or merchandise or of attracting the attention or inviting the patronage
of any person.
(Ord. 11. Passed 11-14-27; 1976 Code 6-90.)
860.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
(Ord. 1687. Passed 1-14-19)
CHAPTER 864
Sexually Oriented Entertainment Businesses
864.01   Definitions.
864.02   License required for sexually oriented entertainment businesses.
864.03   License required for managers, servers and entertainers.
864.04   License classifications and fees.
864.05   SOE business licenses.
864.06   SOE manager, server and entertainer licenses.
864.07   Processing of applications.
864.08   Examination of applications; issuance or nonissuance of licenses;
transfers; posting; review.
864.09   SOE business licenses; ineligibility and disqualification.
864.10   SOE manager, server or entertainer licenses; eligibility and
disqualification.
864.11   Standards of conduct.
864.12   Responsibility of owners.
864.13   Responsibility of manager.
864.14   Inspections.
864.15   Suspension or revocation of license.
864.16   Renewal of license.
864.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Sex related offenses - see GEN. OFF.
Ch. 670
   Commercial establishments and licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 802
   Massage establishments - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 846
864.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Employee" means any and all persons, including managers, servers and
entertainers, who work or render services directly related to the operation of
a sexually oriented entertainment business.
   (b)   "Entertainer" means any person who provides sexually oriented
entertainment within a sexually oriented entertainment business, as defined in
this section, whether or not a fee is charged or accepted for entertainment.
   (c)   "Manager" means any person who manages, directs, administers or is in
charge of the affairs and/or conduct of any portion of any activity involving a
sexually oriented entertainment business.
   (d)   "Operator" means any person operating, conducting or maintaining a
sexually oriented entertainment business.
   (e)   "Patron" means any person attending, viewing the performance of an
entertainer at, purchasing or consuming food or drink in, or otherwise
entering, a sexually oriented business, regardless of whether a fee or charge
was exacted.
   (f)   "Person" means any individual, partnership, corporation, trust,
incorporated or unincorporated association, joint venture, governmental entity,
or other entity or group of persons, however organized.
   (g)   "Premises" means the physical location of a sexually oriented
entertainment business, including all private property under ownership, lease
or right of access by the owner of a sexually oriented business adjacent to the
primary business location, including private parking lots and entrance areas.
   (h)   "Server" means any person who serves food or drink at a sexually
oriented entertainment business.
   (i)   "Sexually oriented entertainment" (SOE) means any exhibition,
performance, display or dance of any type, including, but not limited to,
talking, singing, reading, listening, posing, serving food or beverages,
soliciting for the sale of food, beverages or entertainment, pantomiming,
modeling, removal of clothing, or any service offered for amusement on a
premises where such exhibition, performance, display or dance is intended to
arouse or excite the sexual desires of the entertainer, other entertainers or
patrons, or if the entertainment involves a person who is partially nude or in
such attire, costume or clothing as to expose to view any portion of specified
anatomical areas.
   (j)   "Sexually oriented entertainment business" means any premises to which
the public, patrons or members are invited or admitted and wherein an
entertainer provides sexually oriented entertainment to a member of the public,
a patron, an employee or a member. A sexually oriented entertainment business
is sometimes hereinafter referred to as an "SOE business."
   (k)   "Specified anatomical areas" means uncovered or exposed human
genitals, the pubic region, vulva, pubic hair, buttock, female breast or
breasts below a point immediately above the top of the areola or nipple, or the
human male genitals in a discernible erect state, even if completely and
opaquely covered.
   (l)   "Specified sexual activities" means sexual conduct, being actual or
simulated, acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse or physical contact
in an act of apparent sexual stimulation or gratification, with a person's
clothed or unclothed genitals, pubic area, buttocks or the breast of a female,
or any sadomasochistic abuse or acts, including with animals or any latent
objects in an act of apparent sexual stimulation or gratification.
(Ord. 792. Passed 8-9-93.)
864.02 LICENSE REQUIRED FOR SEXUALLY ORIENTED ENTERTAINMENT BUSINESSES.
   (a)   No person shall operate or maintain an SOE business in the Village
unless the owner, operator or lessee has obtained an SOE business license
therefor from the Village as hereinafter provided.
   (b)   No entertainer, employee or manager shall knowingly perform any work,
service or entertainment directly related to the operation of an unlicensed SOE
business.
   (c)   It shall be prima-facie evidence that any SOE business that fails to
have an SOE business license posted has not obtained a license. In addition, it
shall be prima-facie evidence that any entertainer, employee or manager who
performs any service or entertainment in an SOE business in which an SOE
license is not posted, in the manner required by this chapter, had knowledge
that such business was not licensed.
(Ord. 792. Passed 8-9-93.)
864.03 LICENSE REQUIRED FOR MANAGERS, SERVERS AND ENTERTAINERS.
   No person shall work as an entertainer, server or manager at an adult
entertainment business without first obtaining a license to do so pursuant to
this chapter. All managers, servers and entertainers shall be a minimum of
twenty-one years of age. All managers, servers and entertainers shall be
employees of the owner.
(Ord. 792. Passed 8-9-93.)
864.04 LICENSE CLASSIFICATIONS AND FEES.
   (a)   The license year for all licenses required under this chapter shall be
from each January 1 through December 31. The application for a license shall be
accompanied by payment in full of the fee stated in this section. Fees for a
partial year shall be pro-rated on a monthly basis. No application shall be
considered complete until such fee is paid.
   (b)   All licenses shall be issued for a specific location and shall be
nonrefundable, nontransferable and nonassignable.
   (c)   The classification of licenses and fees for each year shall be as
follows:
      (1)   The SOE business license fee is two thousand, five hundred dollars
($2,500) per year;
      (2)   The SOE manager's license fee is one hundred dollars ($100.00) per
year;
      (3)   The SOE entertainer's license fee is one hundred dollars ($100.00)
per year;
      (4)   The SOE server's license fee is one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 792. Passed 8-9-93.)
864.05 SOE BUSINESS LICENSES.
   All persons desiring to secure a license to operate an SOE business under
the provisions of this chapter shall make a verified application therefor with
the Village Clerk. All applications shall be submitted in the name of the
person proposing to conduct or operate the SOE business. All applications shall
be submitted on a form supplied by the Village Clerk and shall require the
following information:
   (a)   The name, residence address, home telephone number, occupation, date
and place of birth and social security number of the applicant.
   (b)   The name of the SOE business, a description of the SOE to be performed
on the premises, and the name of the owner of the premises where the SOE
business will be located.
   (c)   The names, residence addresses, social security numbers and dates of
birth of all partners, if the applicant is a partnership, and if the applicant
is a corporation, the same information for all corporate officers, directors
and stockholders who own more than a ten percent interest in the corporation.
   (d)   The addresses of the applicant, all partners or all corporate officers
and directors for the five years immediately prior to the date of the
application.
   (e)   A statement from the applicant, all partners or all corporate officers
and directors, as to whether any such person or other entity, in previously
operating in this or any other village, city, town, county or state, has had a
business license of any type revoked or suspended and, if so, the reason for
the suspension or revocation and the business activity subjected to the
suspension or revocation.
   (f)   A statement of the business, occupation or employment of the
applicant, all partners or all corporate officers and directors, for the three
years immediately preceding the date of the application.
   (g)   A statement from the applicant, each partner or each corporate officer
and director, that each such person has not been convicted of, or plead guilty
or nolo contendere to a felony criminal act within five years immediately
preceding the application, or a misdemeanor criminal act within two years
immediately preceding the application, where such felony or misdemeanor
criminal act involved sexual offenses, prostitution, promotion of prostitution,
sexual abuse of a child, pornography or related offenses as defined in the
Illinois Criminal Code, or involved controlled substances illegal drug or
narcotic offenses as defined in the Illinois Controlled Substances Act.
   (h)   A full set of fingerprints and a photograph, to be taken by the Police
Department, of the applicant, all partners if the applicant is a partnership,
or all corporate officers and directors if the applicant is a corporation.
   (i)   If the applicant is a corporation, a current certificate of good
standing issued by the Secretary of State of the state of incorporation and, if
incorporated in a state other than Illinois, a current certificate of
registration within the State of Illinois as a foreign corporation.
   (j)   A statement signed under oath that the applicant has personal
knowledge of the information contained in the application, that the information
contained therein is true and correct, and that the applicant has read the
provisions of this chapter regulating SOE businesses.
(Ord. 792. Passed 8-9-93.)
864.06 SOE MANAGER, SERVER AND ENTERTAINER LICENSES.
   All persons desiring to secure a license under the provisions of this
chapter to be an SOE manager, server or entertainer shall make a verified
application therefor to the Village Clerk. All applications shall be submitted
in the name of the person proposing to be an SOE manager, server or
entertainer. All applications shall be submitted on a form supplied by the
Village Clerk and shall require the following information:
   (a)   The applicant's name, home address, home telephone number, date and
place of birth, and social security number.
   (b)   The name and address of each SOE business where the applicant intends
to work as a manager, server or entertainer, and an "intent-to-hire" statement
from an SOE business that is licensed, or that has applied for a license, under
the provisions of this chapter, indicating that the SOE business intends to
hire the applicant to manage, serve or entertain on the premises.
   (c)   A statement from the applicant that the applicant has not been
convicted of, released from confinement for conviction of, or diverted from
prosecution for a felony criminal act within five years immediately preceding
the application, or a misdemeanor criminal act within two years immediately
preceding the application, where such felony or misdemeanor criminal act
involved sexual offenses, prostitution, promotion of prostitution, sexual abuse
of a child, pornography or related offenses as defined in the Illinois Criminal
Code, or involved controlled substance, illegal drug or narcotic offenses as
defined in the Illinois Controlled Substances Act.
   (d)   A full set of fingerprints and a photograph, to be taken by the Police
Department, of the applicant.
   (e)   The applicant shall present to the Village Clerk a document that
establishes that the applicant has attained the age of twenty-one years at the
time the application is submitted. Any of the following shall be accepted as
documentation of age:
      (1)   A motor vehicle operator's license issued by the State, bearing the
applicant's photograph and date of birth;
      (2)   A State-issued identification card bearing the applicant's
photograph and date of birth;
      (3)   An official and valid passport issued by the United States of
America; or
      (4)   An immigration card issued by the United States of America.
   An application shall be deemed incomplete if the information required by
this chapter is not provided, and such an application shall, therefore, not be
processed.
(Ord. 792. Passed 8-9-93.)
864.07 PROCESSING OF APPLICATIONS.
   (a)   Upon receipt of a complete application for an SOE business or an SOE
manager, server or entertainer license, the Village Clerk shall immediately
transmit one copy of the application to the Chief of Police for investigation
of the application. In addition, the Village Clerk shall immediately transmit a
copy of the application to the Building Inspector and the Fire Department.
   (b)   It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to investigate such
application to determine whether the information contained in the application
is accurate and whether the applicant is qualified to be issued the license
applied for. The Chief of Police shall report the results of the investigation
to the Village Manager not later than fifteen working days from the date the
application is received by the Village Clerk.
   (c)   It shall be the duty of the Building Inspector and the Fire Department
to determine whether the structure where the SOE business will be conducted
complies with the requirements and meets the standards of applicable Zoning
Code, Building Code and Fire Code provisions. The Building Inspector and the
Fire Department shall report the results of their investigation to the Village
Manager not later than fifteen working days from the date the application is
received by the Village Clerk.
(Ord. 792. Passed 8-9-93.)
864.08 EXAMINATION OF APPLICATIONS; ISSUANCE OR NONISSUANCE OF LICENSES;
TRANSFERS; POSTING; REVIEW.
   (a)   If the application for an SOE business license or an SOE manager,
server or entertainer is in proper form, accompanied by the appropriate license
fee and found to be in compliance with all of the requirements of this chapter,
the Village Manager shall issue the license as provided by law. The Village
Manager shall either approve or disapprove a license application within thirty
working days from the date the application is received by the Village Clerk.
   (b)   The license shall state that it is not transferable to other persons
and shall also indicate the calendar year for which it is issued. The license
shall be kept posted in a conspicuous place in the place of business that is
licensed or where the licensee is working.
   (c)   If the application for a license is disapproved, the applicant shall
be immediately notified by mail at the applicant's last known address, and the
notification shall state the basis for such disapproval. Any applicant
aggrieved by the disapproval of a license application may seek review as
hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 792. Passed 8-9-93.)
864.09 SOE BUSINESS LICENSES; INELIGIBILITY AND DISQUALIFICATION.
   An SOE business license shall not be issued if any one of the following
conditions is applicable:
   (a)   The applicant's premises are located within 1,000 feet of any school,
church or bona fide religious assembly location, child care center licensed by
the State, and property zoned residential pursuant to the Zoning Code.
Measurements shall be made in a straight line, without regard to intervening
structures or objects, from the nearest point on the property line of the
applicant's premises to the nearest point on the property line of such school,
church or bona fide religious assembly location, licensed child care center or
property zoned residential;
   (b)   The applicant's premises are located within 1,000 feet of any other
SOE business for which there is a license issued. Measurements shall be made in
a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the
nearest point on the property line of the applicant's premises to the nearest
point on the property line of such other SOE business;
   (c)   The applicant's premises is located within 100 feet of any business
licensed by the Village to sell alcoholic liquor. Measurements shall be made in
a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the
nearest point on the property line of the applicant's premises to the nearest
point on the property line of such business licensed to sell alcoholic liquor;
   (d)   The applicant failed to supply all of the information required on the
application;
   (e)   The applicant gave materially false, fraudulent or untruthful
information on the application;
   (f)   The applicant's proposed business premises does not comply with or
meet the requirements of the applicable Zoning, Building and Fire Codes;
   (g)   The applicant has been convicted of, or plead guilty or nolo
contendere to, any of the crimes set forth in Section
864.05 during the time period set forth in such section;
   (h)   The applicant has had an SOE license revoked or suspended in this or
any other jurisdiction within the past five years.
(Ord. 792. Passed 8-9-93.)
864.10 SOE MANAGER, SERVER OR ENTERTAINER LICENSES; ELIGIBILITY AND
DISQUALIFICATION.
   No person is eligible for an SOE manager, server or entertainer license, nor
shall such a license be issued to an applicant, if one or more of the following
conditions exist:
   (a)   The employer for whom the applicant intends to work does not have or
is ineligible to receive an SOE business license for any of the reasons stated
in this chapter;
   (b)   The applicant has been convicted of or plead guilty or nolo contendere
to any of the crimes set forth in Section
864.06 during the time period set forth in such section;
   (c)   The applicant failed to provide all of the information required on the
application;
   (d)   The applicant gave materially false, fraudulent or untruthful
information on the application;
   (e)   The applicant has had an SOE manager, server or entertainer license
revoked or suspended in this or any other municipality, county or state during
the past five years.
(Ord. 792. Passed 8-9-93.)
864.11 STANDARDS OF CONDUCT.
   No licensee, owner, manager, server, entertainer or patron of an SOE
business, while on or about the premises of the business, shall fail to comply
with the following standards of conduct:
   (a)   Age Restriction. Only persons twenty-one years of age or older shall
be permitted on the premises of an SOE business. The manager or manager's
representative shall verify a person's age by one of the following methods:
      (1)   A motor vehicle operator's license issued by any state, bearing the
applicant's photograph and date of birth;
      (2)   A state-issued identification card bearing the applicant's
photograph and date of birth;
      (3)   An official and valid passport issued by the United States of
America;
      (4)   An immigration card issued by the United States of America.
         Failure to verify the age of a patron shall be considered a violation
of this chapter.
   (b)   Exterior Observation. The premises of all of the SOE businesses shall
be constructed to include a partition or other physical barrier on all customer
entrances that will ensure that observation of the interior of the business is
not possible from the exterior. In addition, all windows will be covered to
prevent viewing of the interior of the building from the outside and all
doorways not constructed with a partition or other physical barrier shall be
covered so as to prevent observation of the interior of the premises from the
exterior of the building. No SOE business shall be conducted in a manner that
permits the observation of live entertainers, servers or employees from the
exterior of the building.
   (c)   Exterior Signs. The SOE business shall only be permitted to install a
single sign which conforms to the Village sign ordinance and shall not display
or depict specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas.
   (d)   Nudity Prohibited. No employee, server, entertainer or patron in an
SOE business shall appear in any fashion that exposes to view any specified
anatomical area.
   (e)   Certain Acts Prohibited.
      (1)   No employee, server or entertainer shall perform any specified
sexual activities, wear or use any device or covering exposed to view which
simulates any specified anatomical area, use artificial devices of inanimate
objects to perform or depict any specified sexual activities, or participate in
any act of prostitution.
      (2)   No employee, server, entertainer or patron of an SOE business shall
knowingly touch, fondle or caress any specified anatomical area of another
person, or knowingly permit another person to touch, fondle or caress any
specified anatomical area of such employee, server, entertainer or patron,
whether such specified anatomical areas are clothed, unclothed, covered or
exposed.
      (3)   No employee, server or entertainer of an SOE business shall be
visible from the exterior of the SOE business while such person is unclothed or
in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose to view any specified
anatomical area.
      (4)   No SOE entertainer shall solicit, demand or receive any payment or
gratuity from any patron or customer for any act prohibited by this chapter and
no SOE entertainer shall receive any payment or gratuity from any customer for
any entertainment except as follows:
         A.   While such entertainer is on the stage, a patron may place such
payment or gratuity into a box affixed to the stage, or
         B.   While such entertainer is not on the stage and is clothed so as
to not expose to view any specified anatomical area, a patron may either place
such payment or gratuity into the entertainer's hand, or under a leg garter
worn by such entertainer at least four inches below the bottom of the pubic
region.
      (5)   No owner, operator, manager or other person in charge of the
premises of an SOE business shall knowingly:
         A.   Permit alcoholic liquor to be brought upon or consumed on the
premises;
         B.   Allow or permit the sale, distribution, delivery or consumption
of any controlled substance or illegal drug or narcotic on the premises;
         C.   Allow or permit any person under the age of twenty-one years of
age to be in or upon the premises;
         D.   Allow or permit any act of prostitution or patronizing
prostitution on the premises; or
         E.   Allow or permit a violation of this chapter or State law.
   (f)   Hours of Operation. No sexually oriented entertainment business may be
open or in use between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. Only employees of
the SOE business shall be permitted in or upon the premises of the business
between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m.
   (g)   Closed Booths or Rooms Prohibited. Every SOE business shall be
physically arranged in such a manner that the entire interior portion of the
booths, cubicles, rooms or stall, wherein sexually oriented entertainment is
provided, shall be visible from the common area of the premises. Visibility
shall not be blocked or obscured by doors, curtains, partitions, drapes or any
other obstruction whatsoever.
   (h)   Alcoholic Liquor Prohibited. No employee, patron, manager,
entertainer, owner or other person shall consume or possess any alcoholic
liquor in an SOE business or premises. An SOE business shall not share a common
interior entrance or access area with a business licensed by the Village to
sell alcoholic liquor. The owner and manager of the SOE business shall be
responsible for prohibiting the consumption or possession of alcoholic liquor
by patrons on the premises, including adjacent private parking facilities which
serve the business.
   (i)   Interior Lighting Required. The interior premises of an SOE business
shall be equipped with overhead lighting of sufficient intensity to illuminate
every place to which customers are permitted access at an illumination of not
less than one foot candle as measured at floor level, and such illumination
must be maintained at all times that any customer or patron is present in the
interior premises.
(Ord. 792. Passed 8-9-93.)
864.12 RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNERS.
   Every act or omission by an employee of an SOE business constituting a
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed the act or
omission of the owner if such act of omission occurs either with the
authorization, knowledge or approval of the owner or as a result of the owner's
negligent failure to supervise the employee's conduct, and the owner shall be
punishable for such act or omission in the same manner as if the owner
committed the act or caused the omission. The owner shall be responsible for
the conduct of all employees while they are on the premises and any act or
omission of any employee, while he or she is on the premises, that constitutes
a violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed the act or
omission of the owner for purposes of determining whether the owner's license
shall be revoked, suspended or renewed.
(Ord. 792. Passed 8-9-93.)
864.13 RESPONSIBILITY OF MANAGER.
   An SOE manager shall be on duty at an SOE business at all times the premises
are open for business. The name of the manager on duty shall be prominently
posted during business hours.
(Ord. 792. Passed 8-9-93.)
864.14 INSPECTIONS.
   An SOE business shall permit representatives of the Police Department or any
other Village official acting in his or her official capacity to inspect the
premises as necessary to ensure that the business is complying with all
applicable regulations and laws.
(Ord. 792. Passed 8-9-93.)
864.15 SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   (a)   A notice of license revocation shall be issued whenever the Village
Manager has information that:
      (1)   The owner or operator of an SOE business or a holder of an SOE
manager, server or entertainer license has violated, or knowingly allowed or
permitted the violation of, any of the provisions of this chapter;
      (2)   The SOE license or the SOE manager, server or entertainer license
was obtained through false statements in the application for such license or a
renewal thereof;
      (3)   The SOE licensee or the SOE manager, server or entertainer licensee
failed to make a complete disclosure of all information in the application for
such license or a renewal thereof;
      (4)   The owner or operator, or any partner, corporate officer or
director holding an SOE business license, has become disqualified from having a
license by a conviction as provided in Section
864.09; or
      (5)   The holder of an SOE manager, server or entertainer license has
become disqualified from having a license by a conviction as provided in
Section
864.10.
   (b)   The Village Manager shall notify the person holding the license, in
writing, at the address provided in the application or subsequent amended
address, by certified mail, that pending an opportunity for a hearing before
the Village President, the license shall be revoked. Such notification shall
include the specific Code violation alleged. The person shall have ten days
from the mailing of the notice to request in writing a hearing before the
Village President on the pending revocation. Failure to request a hearing shall
result in a revocation of the license by the Village Manager. Based upon the
evidence produced at the hearing, the Village President may take any of the
following actions:
      (1)   Suspend the license for up to ninety days.
      (2)   Revoke the license for the remainder of the license year.
      (3)   Place the license holder on administrative probation for a period
of up to one year, on the condition that no further violations of this chapter
occur during the period of probation. If a violation does occur, and after a
hearing the violation is determined to have actually occurred, the license will
be revoked for the remainder of the license year.
(Ord. 792. Passed 8-9-93.)
864.16 RENEWAL OF LICENSE.
   A license may be renewed by making application to the Village Clerk on
application forms provided for that purpose. Upon timely application and review
as provided for a new license, a license issued under the provisions of this
chapter shall be renewed by issuance of a license in the manner provided by
this chapter.
(Ord. 792. Passed 8-9-93.)
864.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
(Ord. 1687. Passed 1-14-19)
CHAPTER 868
Solicitors
868.01   Definitions.
868.02   Certificates of registration.
868.03   Residents to determine acceptance of solicitors.
868.04   Notices regulating soliciting.
868.05   Responsibilities of solicitors on premises.
868.06   Soliciting prohibited at certain times.
868.07   Uninvited soliciting.
868.08   Applicability of chapter to government officials.
868.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to license peddlers - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 24, 11-42-5
   Soliciting in public parking lots - see TRAF.
442.02
   Soliciting by real estate agents - see GEN. OFF.
624.07
   Soliciting in parks - see GEN. OFF.
662.05
   Solicitation for prostitution or purchase of alcoholic liquor - see B.R. &
T.
806.28
   Peddlers and hawkers - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 860
   Soliciting taxicab business - see B.R. & T.
872.12
868.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Commercial Soliciting" means the door-to-door selling or offering for
sale of property, goods, wares, merchandise, food or services of any kind,
character or description whatever, for any kind of consideration, for future
delivery or performance, but excluding noncommercial solicitation as defined in
this chapter. "Commercial solicitation" shall not include the sale of goods by
persons conducting fundraising activities for local schools or youth scouting
organizations where the goods will be delivered at a future date.
   (b)   "Noncommercial Soliciting" means the door-to-door soliciting of gifts,
support or contributions of money, clothing or any other valuable thing for the
support of any bona fide charitable, political, religious or not-for-profit
organization purposes.
   (c)   "Registered solicitor" includes any person who has obtained a valid
certificate of registration as provided in this chapter, which certificate is
in the possession of the solicitor on his or her person while engaged in
soliciting.
   (d)   "Residence" means a separate living unit occupied for residential
purposes by one or more persons, in any type of building or other structure.
   (e)   "Soliciting" means the following door-to-door activities:
      (1)   Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares,
merchandise, foodstuffs or services of any kind, character or description, for
any kind of consideration;
      (2)   Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase
of insurance of any type, kind or character;
      (3)   Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals,
newspapers or any other type or kind of publication; or
(Ord. 347. Passed 9-8-70; 1976 Code § 6-94; Ord. 1532. Passed 8-27-12.)
868.02 CERTIFICATES OF REGISTRATION.
   (a)   Required. Every person who wishes to engage in commercial soliciting
from persons in residences in the Village shall make a written application for
a certificate of registration therefor, as provided in this section. Person who
wish to engage in noncommercial soliciting are encouraged to make application
for a certificate of registration as provided herein.
(Ord. 347. Passed 9-8-70; 1976 Code § 6-95; Ord. 1532. Passed 8-27-12.)
   (b)   Applications.
      (1)   An application for a certificate of registration shall be made upon
a form provided by and filed with the Police Chief. The applicant shall
truthfully state in full the information requested on the application,
including the following:
         A.   The name of the applicant, the address of his or her present
place of residence and the length of his or her residence at such address, his
or her business address, if other than the residence address, and his or her
Social Security number;
         B.   The address of his or her place of residence during the past
three years, if other than the present address;
         C.   The age and marital status of the applicant and, if married, the
name of his or her spouse;
         D.   A physical description of the applicant;
         E.   The name and address of the person, firm, corporation or
association by whom the applicant is employed or whom he or she represents, and
the length of time of such employment or representation;
         F.   The name and address of the applicant's employer during the past
three years if other than the present employer;
         G.   A description, sufficient for identification, of the subject
matter of the soliciting which the applicant will engage in;
         H.   The period of time for which the certificate is applied for;
         I.   The date or approximate date of the latest previous application
for a certificate under this chapter, if any;
         J.   A statement as to whether or not a certificate of registration
issued to the applicant under this chapter has ever been revoked;
         K.   A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever been
convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or an
ordinance of another Illinois municipality regulating soliciting;
         L.   A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever been
convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the State or any
other state of the United States; and
         M.   Such additional information as the Chief may deem necessary to
process the application.
         N.   All statements made by the applicant upon the application or in
connection therewith shall be under oath.
         O.   The Chief shall require every applicant to submit to
fingerprinting by the Police Department in connection with the application.
(Ord. 347. Passed 9-8-70; 1976 Code 6-96.)
   (c)   Issuance; Statement of Expiration Date.
      (1)   When the applicant is found to be duly qualified, the certificate
of registration shall be issued forthwith.
      (2)   The certificate of registration shall state the expiration date
thereof.
(Ord. 347. Passed 9-8-70; 1976 Code 6-97.)
   (d)   Denial.
      (1)   After consideration of the application and all information obtained
relative thereto, the Police Chief shall deny the application if the applicant
does not possess the qualifications for such certificate required in this
section or if the issuance of a certificate of registration to the applicant
would not be in accordance with the intent and purpose of this chapter.
      (2)   No certificate of registration shall be issued to any person who
has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the State,
any other state or the United States, within five years of the date of the
application; to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any of the
provisions of this chapter; or to any person whose certificate of registration
issued hereunder has previously been revoked as herein provided.
      (3)   Endorsement of the denial of the application shall be made by the
Chief on the application.
(Ord. 347. Passed 9-8-70; 1976 Code 6-98.)
   (e)   Revocation.
      (1)   A certificate of registration issued under this chapter shall be
revoked by the Chief if the holder of the certificate:
         A.   Is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter;
         B.   Has made a false material statement in the application or
otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a certificate under this
chapter;
         C.   Violates an ordinance or a State or Federal Regulation in
connection with or subsequent to the issuance of an approved solicitor's
certificate of registration; or
         D.   Makes a nuisance of himself or herself to the community or to the
Police Department.
      (2)   Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be
given by the Chief to the holder of the certificate in person or by certified
United States mail addressed to his or her residence address as set forth in
the application.
      (3)   Immediately upon the giving of such notice, the certificate of
registration shall become null and void. (Adopting Ordinance)
   (f)   Records. The Chief shall cause to be kept in his or her office an
accurate record of all applications received and acted upon, together with all
other information and data pertaining thereto; all certificates of registration
issued under this chapter; and all denials of applications. Applications for
certificates shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed, and every
certificate issued, and any renewal thereof, shall be identified with the
duplicate number of the application upon which it was issued.
(Ord. 347. Passed 9-8-70; 1976 Code 6-100.)
868.03 RESIDENTS TO DETERMINE ACCEPTANCE OF SOLICITORS.
   Occupants of residences shall make the determination whether solicitors
shall be or shall not be invited to their respective residences.
(Ord. 347. Passed 9-8-70; 1976 Code 6-93.)
868.04 NOTICES REGULATING SOLICITING.
   Every person who wishes to secure the protection intended to be provided by
the regulations pertaining to soliciting contained in this chapter shall comply
with the following directions:
   (a)   Notice of the determination by the occupant of giving invitation to
solicitors, or the refusal of invitation to solicitors, to any residence, shall
be given in the following manner:
      (1)   A weatherproof card, approximately three inches by four inches in
size, shall be exhibited upon or near the main entrance door to the residence,
indicating the determination by the occupant, containing the words, "ONLY
SOLICITORS REGISTERED IN RICHTON PARK INVITED" or "NO SOLICITORS INVITED."
      (2)   The letters on the card shall be at least one-third inch in height.
For the purpose of uniformity, the cards shall be provided, at cost, by the
Chief of Police to persons so requesting.
   (b)   Such card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any
solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the residence of the
information contained thereon.
(Ord. 347. Passed 9-8-70; 1976 Code 6-101.)
868.05 RESPONSIBILITIES OF SOLICITORS ON PREMISES.
   (a)   Every solicitor, upon going onto any premises upon which a residence
is located, shall examine the notice provided for in Section
868.04, if any is attached, and be governed by the statement contained on the
notice. If the notice states "ONLY SOLICITORS REGISTERED IN RICHTON PARK
INVITED," then a solicitor not possessing a valid certificate of registration,
as provided in Section
868.02, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises. If the
notice states "NO SOLICITORS INVITED," then the solicitor, whether so
registered or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises.
   (b)   Any solicitor who has gained entrance to a residence, whether invited
or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when
requested to do so by the occupant.
(Ord. 347. Passed 9-8-70; 1976 Code 6-102.)
868.06 SOLICITING PROHIBITED AT CERTAIN TIMES.
   No person, whether registered under this chapter or not, shall, at any time
on a Sunday or a State or national holiday, or prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 9:00
p.m. on any other day, go upon any premises and ring the door bell upon or near
any door of a residence located thereon, rap or knock upon any door or create
any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the
occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the
occupant thereof to engage in soliciting.
(Ord. 347. Passed 9-8-70; 1976 Code 6-103.)
868.07 UNINVITED SOLICITING.
   No person shall go upon any premises and ring the door bell thereof, go near
any door thereof or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract
the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an
audience with the occupant thereof and engaging in soliciting, in defiance of
the notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with Section
868.04.
(Ord. 347. Passed 9-8-70; 1976 Code 6-104.)
868.08 APPLICABILITY OF CHAPTER TO GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS.
   This chapter applies to elected or appointed Village officials and employees
and to elected or appointed officials and employees of any other local
government or the State or Federal government. However, such officials and
employees shall apply to the Village Clerk for written approval of any
solicitation.
(Ord. 393. Passed 12-26-72; 1976 Code 6-105.)
868.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
(Ord. 1687. Passed 1-14-19)
CHAPTER 872
Taxicabs
872.01   Definitions.
872.02   Certificates of public convenience and necessity.
872.03   Liability insurance.
872.04   Licensing of drivers.
872.05   Fares.
872.06   Use by multiple passengers.
872.07   Delay of service.
872.08   Refusal to provide service.
872.09   Receiving and discharging passengers.
872.10   Stopping or standing restricted.
872.11   Capacity.
872.12   Solicitation of business.
872.13   Accident reports.
872.14   Maintenance; exterior identification.
872.15   Daily manifests.
872.16   Hours of operation.
872.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to license taxicab operators - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 24, 11-42-6
   Commercial and heavy vehicles - see TRAF.
Ch. 434
   Taxicab stands - see TRAF.
438.11(e), (f)
   Parking of taxicabs - see TRAF.
438.12
   Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 882
872.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Driver" means a person who actually drives a taxicab.
   (b)   "Identification data" means the following:
      (1)   When applied to a taxicab, the following items of information:
         A.   The maker, model and year of manufacture of the taxicab;
         B.   Its engine number;
         C.   Its serial number;
         D.   Its Illinois State certificate of title number and license
number; and
         E.   The number of passengers capable of being accommodated therein at
one time; and
      (2)   When applied to a driver, the following items of information:
         A.   The full name of the driver;
         B.   His or her present residence address;
         C.   His or her residence address for the three years past;
         D.   His or her age, color, height and weight and the color of his or
her eyes and hair;
         E.   His or her citizenship and marital status;
         F.   The date and place of convictions of felonies or misdemeanors, if
any, and a statement of the nature of the offenses for which the driver was
convicted;
         G.   Whether or not he or she has ever been previously licensed as a
driver and, if so, when and by what authority;
         H.   Whether or not his or her license has ever been revoked or
suspended and, if so, for what cause; and
         I.   His or her State motor vehicle operator's license number.
   (c)   "Licensed driver" means a person who has been properly identified by a
licensee and authorized to drive a licensee's taxicabs under a certificate of
public convenience and necessity in accordance with this chapter.
   (d)   "Licensee" means a person in whose name a certificate of public
convenience and necessity has been issued by the Village Manager for the
operation of taxicabs.
   (e)   "Standard number of taxicabs" means the next whole number larger than
the quotient obtained on dividing, by 100, the number of occupied family
dwelling units in the Village, as determined from time to time by the Manager,
except that in no event shall the standard number of taxicabs be less than six.
   (f)   "Taxicab" means a vehicle transporting passengers for remuneration for
which patronage is solicited publicly. "Taxicab" does not include the
following:
      (1)   Vehicles operating on established routes which are regulated by the
Illinois Commerce Commission;
      (2)   Vehicles rented to be driven by the renter or his or her agent,
commonly known as rent-a-cars;
      (3)   Vehicles operated solely as funeral cars or ambulances; or
      (4)   Vehicles owned and/or operated by any unit or agency of the
Federal, State or a local government.
(Ord. 203. Passed 7-9-57; Ord. 235. Passed 3-31-60; 1976 Code 17-1.)
872.02 CERTIFICATES OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY.
